DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 58-26—58-35. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FAIR HOUSING 
 
Sec. 58-36. - Declaration of policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to bring about, through fair, orderly and lawful procedures, the opportunity for each person to obtain housing without regard to his race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status. It is further declared that this policy is grounded upon a recognition of the inalienable right of each individual to provide for himself and his family a dwelling according to his own choosing; and further, that the denial of such rights through considerations based upon race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status is detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city and constitutes an unjust denial or deprivation of such inalienable right which is within the power and the proper responsibility of government in general, and the city government of McAllen, Texas in particular, to prevent. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-11; Ord. No. 1993-16, § II, 2-22-93)  
Sec. 58-37. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Discriminatory housing practice means an act that is unlawful under sections 58-38 through 58-40. 
Dwelling means any building, structure or portion thereof which is occupied as, or designed and intended for occupancy as, a residence by one or more families, and any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location thereon or any such building, structure or portion thereof. 
Person means and includes one or more individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, labor organizations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint stock companies, trusts, unincorporated organizations, trustees, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers, fiduciaries and any other organization or entity of whatever character. 
To rent means and includes to lease, sublease, to let and otherwise to grant for consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-12) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 58-38. - Discrimination in the sale or rental of housing. 
Except as exempted by section 58-41, it shall be unlawful: 
(1)  To refuse the sale or rent after the making of a bona fide offer, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or otherwise make unavailable or deny, a dwelling to any person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status. 
(2)  To discriminate against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status. 
(3)  To make, print or publish or cause to be made, printed or published any notice, statement or advertisement with respect to the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status, or any intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination. 
(4)  To represent to any person because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status, that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available. 
(5)  For profit, or with the hope or expectation of profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person or persons of a particular race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-13; Ord. No. 1993-16, § II, 2-22-93)  
Sec. 58-39. - Discrimination in the financing of housing. 
It shall be unlawful for any bank, building and loan association, insurance company or other corporation, association, firm or enterprise whose business consists in whole or in part in the making of commercial real estate loans to deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling, or to discriminate against him in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance, because of the race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status of such person or of any person associated with him in connection with such loan or other financial assistance or the purposes of such loan or other financial assistance, or of the present or prospective owners, lessees, tenants or occupants of the dwelling or dwellings in relation to which such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-14; Ord. No. 1993-16, § II, 2-22-93)  
Sec. 58-40. - Discrimination in the provision of brokerage services. 
It shall be unlawful to deny any person access to or membership or participation in any multiple listing service, real estate brokers organization or other service organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate against any person in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation on account of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-15; Ord. No. 1993-16, § II, 2-22-93)  
Sec. 58-41. - Exemptions and exclusions. 
(a)  There shall be exempted from the application of section 58-37: 
(1)  Any single-family house sold or rented by an owner; provided, that such private individual owner does not own more than three such single-family houses, wherever located, at any one time; provided further, that in the case of the sale of any such single-family house by a private individual owner not residing in such house at the time of such sale or who was not the most recent resident of such house prior to such sale, the exemption granted by this subsection shall apply only with respect to one such sale within any 24-month period; provided further, that such bona fide private individual owner does not own any interest in nor is there owned or reserved on his behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement, title to or any right to all or a portion of the proceeds from the sale or rental of more than three such single-family houses at any one time; provided further, the sale or rental of any such single-family house shall be excepted from the application of this division only if such house is sold or rented: 
a.  Without the use of any manner of the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services of any real estate broker, agent or salesman, or of such facilities or services of any person in the business of selling or renting dwellings, or of any employee or agent of any such broker, agent, salesman or person; and 
b.  Without the publication, posting or mailing of any advertisement or written notice in violation of section 58-38(3); 
but nothing in this subsection shall prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstractors, title companies and other such professional assistance as is necessary to perfect or transfer the title; 
(2)  The rental of rooms or units in dwellings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four families living independently of each other if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of such living quarters as his residence. 
(b)  Nothing in this division shall prohibit a religious organization, association or society or any nonprofit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association or society from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion or from giving preference to such persons, unless membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose or purposes provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-16; Ord. No. 1993-16, § II, 2-22-93)  
Sec. 58-42. - Complaints. 
(a)  Any person who claims to have been injured by a discriminatory housing practice or believes that he will be irrevocably injured by a discriminatory housing practice that is about to occur (referred to in this section as the "person aggrieved") may file a complaint with the municipal court of the city. Such complaints shall be in writing and shall identify the person alleged to have committed or alleged to be about to commit the discriminatory housing practice and shall set forth the particulars thereof. The municipal court and the administrative personnel and employees of the municipal court may assist in the clerical preparation of such complaints. 
(b)  The municipal court of the city shall receive and accept notification and referral of complaints from the secretary of Housing and Urban Development pursuant to the provisions of title VIII, Fair Housing Act of 1968, PL 90-284, and shall treat such complaints in the same manner as complaints filed directly by the person aggrieved. 
(c)  If, in the course of any investigation as provided in section 58-43 on a complaint filed with or referred to the municipal court, the city attorney's office shall receive credible evidence and shall have probable cause to believe that the person or persons named in such complaint have committed a discriminatory housing practice on grounds not stated in such complaint, the city attorney may prepare and file a supplementary complaint upon his own motion and in his own name and such supplementary complaint shall thereafter be treated in the same manner as an original complaint filed by the person aggrieved. 
(d)  If at any time the city attorney or his office shall receive or discover credible evidence and shall have probable cause to believe that any person or persons have committed a discriminatory housing practice as to which no complaint has been filed or is about to be filed, the city attorney may prepare and file complaint upon his own motion and in his own name, and such complaint shall thereafter be treated in the same manner as a complaint filed by the person aggrieved. 
(e)  Upon the filing or referral of any complaint under this section, the city attorney shall furnish a copy of the complaint to the person or persons named in the complaint. 
(f)  A complaint under subsections (a), (c), (d) and (e) of this section shall be filed within 180 days after the alleged discriminatory housing practice has occurred. Complaints shall state the facts upon which the allegations of the discriminatory housing practice are based. Complaints may be reasonably and fairly amended at any time. A respondent may file an answer to the complaint against him and, with the leave of the municipal court, which shall be granted whenever it would be reasonable and fair to do so, may amend his answer at any time. Both complaints and answers shall be signed. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-17)  
Sec. 58-43. - Investigation. 
(a)  Upon the filing of a complaint as provided in section 58-42, the city attorney's office, with the aid and cooperation of any and all city departments, as applicable, shall cause to be made a prompt investigation of the matter stated in the complaint. 
(b)  In connection with the investigation provided for in subsection (a) of this section, the city attorney's office may provide for the questioning, taking and recording of testimony and statements of such persons who appear and may provide for the examination, recording and copying of any and all documents which are produced. 
(c)  During or after the investigation, the city attorney's office shall, if it appears that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred, or is about to occur, attempt by informal endeavors to effect conciliation, including voluntary discontinuance or rectification of the discriminatory housing practice and voluntary compliance and adequate assurance of future voluntary compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(d)  If conciliation is effected, the city attorney's office shall disclose nothing said or done in the course of such conciliation in such a way as to make public identification of the person or persons named in the complaint without the written consent of the persons concerned. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-18; Ord. No. 1993-16, § II, 2-22-93)  
Sec. 58-44. - Legal proceedings. 
(a)  Upon the completion of the investigation and informal endeavors of conciliation by the city attorney's office, the city attorney shall then institute a charge in municipal court and prosecute the same to a final conclusion. 
(b)  The final instituting of the charge by the city attorney's office in the municipal court and the other actions to be taken by the city attorney's office under this article shall be cumulative of all other remedies and procedures for the effectuation and enforcement of this article and the prosecution of alleged violators of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-19)  
Sec. 58-45. - Cooperation with secretary of Housing and Urban Development. 
The city attorney's office and the personnel of the municipal court who are authorized are encouraged to cooperate with the secretary for Housing and Urban Development and/or designee pursuant to the provisions of title VIII, Fair Housing Act of 1968, PL 90-284, and may render such service to the secretary as they shall deem appropriate to further the policies of this article and may accept remuneration from the secretary for services rendered to assist with the carrying out of the provisions of the federal law cited in this section. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-20; Ord. No. 1993-16, § III, 2-22-93)  
Sec. 58-46. - Unlawful intimidation. 
It shall be unlawful for any persons, whether or not acting under color of law, by force or threat of force to willfully injure, intimidate or interfere with, or attempt to injure, intimidate or interfere with: 
(1)  Any person because of his race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status and because he is or has been selling, purchasing, renting, financing, occupying or contracting or negotiating for the sale, purchase, rental, financing or occupation of any dwelling, or applying for or participating in any service organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings; or 
(2)  Any person because he is or has been, or in order to intimidate such person or any other person or class of persons from: 
a.  Participating, without discrimination on account of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status, in any of the activities, services, organizations or facilities described in subsection (1) of this section; or 
b.  Affording another person or class of persons opportunity or protection so to participate; or 
(3)  Any person because he is or has been or in order to discourage such person or any other person from lawfully aiding or encouraging other persons to participate, without discrimination on account of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, handicap, or familial status, in any of the activities, services, organizations or facilities described in subsection (1), or participating lawfully in speech or peaceable assembly opposing any denial of the opportunity so to participate. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-21; Ord. No. 1993-16, § II, 2-22-93)  
Sec. 58-47. - Penalty for violation of division. 
Any person violating the terms and provisions of this division shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be punished as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(Code 1966, § 12½-22)  
Chapter 62 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Police department, art. 4, § 1. 
Cross reference— Airport security police, § 18-61 et seq.; alarm systems, § 42-26 et seq.; smoking prohibited in certain public places, § 54-122. 
State Law reference— Public safety, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.003 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 62-1. - Procedure upon arrest for violation of Code. 
(a)  Whenever any police officer in the city arrests any person for any violation of this Code, the police officer shall take the person arrested or have him taken without unnecessary delay before a magistrate who has jurisdiction of such offense, except as specifically provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  A police officer who is charging a person with committing an offense as a class C misdemeanor, under the state penal code, other than an offense under V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.08, or for any offense in violation of this Code may, instead of taking a person before the magistrate, issue a citation to a person that contains written notice of the time and place that the person must appear before a magistrate, the name and address of the person charged, and the offense charged. The citation shall specify in the notice to appear that such person must appear before the municipal court or other magistrate not less than three days nor more than 14 days from the date of the issuance of the citation. 
(c)  The arrested person, in order to secure release as provided for in this subsection, must give his written promise to appear in court by signing in duplicate the written notice prepared by the arresting officer. The original of such notice shall be retained by the officer and a copy of that delivered to the person arrested. Thereupon, the officer shall forthwith release the arrested person from custody. 
(d)  Any person willfully violating his written promise to appear in court, given as provided for in this section, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine as provided in section 1-14, upon conviction thereof, regardless of the disposition of the charge upon which he was originally arrested. 
(e)  A written promise to appear in court may be complied with by an appearance by counsel. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person, when given a written promise to appear, or given a written notice by any police officer to appear before a municipal court, to give an assumed or fictitious name or a false place of residence or address other than the true name and the true place of residence or address upon the request of such officer. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-8)  
Sec. 62-2. - Civil service authorized positions and longevity pay for police department. 
In accordance with Ordinance No. 2014-53 and Chapter 143 Muncipal Civil Service, Subchapter C, Section 143.041:

ARTICLE II. - POLICE HUMAN RELATIONS COMMITTEE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-76 et seq.; procedure for appointment and terms and qualifications of board members, § 2-77; substantial evidence rule in effect in appeals from decisions or orders of city officers or employees, § 2-196. 
 
Sec. 62-26. - Created. 
There is hereby created a police human relations committee (PHRC) for the city. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-21)  
Sec. 62-27. - Composition; terms. 
(a)  The police human relations committee (PHRC) shall be comprised of five persons, three of whom will be residents of the city appointed by the board of commissioners and two of whom will be police officers appointed by the chief of police. No police officer serving on such committee shall hold a rank higher than that of captain. One officer, to be selected by the chief of police on an ad hoc basis, shall not hold a rank higher than that of the officer under review. 
(b)  The members of the PHRC must live in different geographical areas of the city, and they shall themselves be representative of the ethnic, economic, age, and male/female makeup of the city, as determined by the most recent U.S. Census. 
(c)  The term of a PHRC member, except for the police officer to be selected on an ad hoc basis, will be for one year. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-22)  
Sec. 62-28. - Chairman. 
The PHRC shall at the earliest possible date elect one of its members to serve as its chairman. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-23)  
Sec. 62-29. - Responsibilities. 
It shall be the responsibility of the PHRC to thoroughly review complaints of police misconduct, including but not limited to complaints concerning the use of excessive force, false arrest, and malicious prosecution. It shall also be the responsibility of the PHRC to recommend disciplinary measures, where appropriate, to the chief of police. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-24)  
Sec. 62-30. - Recommendations to be in writing and kept on file. 
(a)  Within two weeks of receiving a complaint, the PHRC shall make written findings and a written recommendation to the chief of police and shall forward copies of such findings and recommendation to the city manager. 
(b)  Copies of all recommendations of the PHRC shall be maintained in the files of the city manager and of the police department, and in no case shall they be destroyed. 
(c)  Within one week of receiving the PHRC's findings and recommendation, the chief of police shall either accept the recommendation or state in writing to the city manager the reasons for rejecting the recommendation. This writing shall be preserved in the manner provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  The initial complaint concerning an officer and the results of the investigation of that complaint will be automatically placed in the file of the police officer named in the complaint and/or investigated. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-25)  
Sec. 62-31. - Lawsuits and informal complaints. 
The filing of a lawsuit or an informal complaint will also trigger the review mechanism set out in sections 62-29 and 62-30. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-26)  
Secs. 62-32—62-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LAW ENFORCEMENT ASSISTANCE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Law enforcement assistance, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 362.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 62-51. - Statutes adopted. 
The city hereby adopts and makes applicable to the city V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 362.001 et seq., concerning law enforcement officers; interlocal assistance, and makes the provision of such law applicable to the city. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-1)  
Sec. 62-52. - Mayor authorized to provide law enforcement assistance to other counties or municipalities. 
The city hereby authorizes the mayor or his successor in office to make provision for the regularly employed law enforcement officers of the city to assist any other county or municipality in the state when in the opinion of the mayor there exists in such other county or municipality a need for the services of additional law enforcement officers to protect the health, life and property of such other county or municipality, its inhabitants and the visitors thereto by reason of riot, unlawful assembly characterized by the use of force and violence or threat thereof by three or more persons acting together or without lawful authority, or during time of natural disaster or manmade calamity. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-2)  
Sec. 62-53. - Status of law enforcement officer serving in other counties or municipalities. 
While any law enforcement officer regularly employed as such by the city is in the service of a county or other municipality pursuant to this article, he shall be a peace officer of such county or other municipality and be under the command of the law enforcement officer therein who is in charge of that county or municipality as fully as though he were within the county or municipality where regularly employed and his qualification, respectively, for office where regularly employed shall constitute his qualification for office in such county or other municipality and no other oath, bond or compensation need be made. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-3)  
Sec. 62-54. - Salary, pension, etc., of law enforcement officer serving other counties or municipalities. 
Any law enforcement officer of the city who is ordered by the mayor or the chief of police to perform police or peace duties outside the territorial limits of the city where he is regularly employed as such officer shall be entitled to the same wage, salary, pension, and all other compensation, and all other rights for such service including injury or death benefits, the same as though the service had been rendered within the limits of this city where he is regularly employed, and such officer shall also be paid for any reasonable expense of travel, food or lodging that he may incur while on duty outside the city limits. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-4)  
Sec. 62-55. - Payments by city; reimbursement by serviced county, etc. 
All wages and disability payments, pension payments, damage to equipment and clothing, medical expense, and expenses of travel, food and lodging incurred while the city law enforcement officer is in the service of another county or municipality shall be paid by the city. Upon making such payments, the city shall when it so requests be reimbursed by the county or other municipality whose authorized officials requested the services out of which the payments arose. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-5)  
Sec. 62-56. - Authority of city finance officer. 
The city finance officer is hereby expressly authorized to make payments for the services of law enforcement officers of a county or any other city upon verification that such service was in fact rendered. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-6)  
Secs. 62-57—62-75. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - POLICE RECORDS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Public records of the city, § 2-341 et seq. 
 
Sec. 62-76. - Purpose. 
There is hereby created an article establishing procedures for microfilming, retention and disposal or destruction of police records and matters related thereto for the administrative benefit of the city's police department. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-30)  
Sec. 62-77. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Administrative capacity means the performance of executive and managerial duties of police affairs by any designated official of the police department. 
Notice means a written memorandum or instrument. 
Police records means any or all documents prepared as a part of the permanent record for investigation and disposition of any arrests, offenses, incidents and accident reports recorded by the police department. 
Recordkeeper means that person designated by the police department to be in charge of keeping and handling the files of police records. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-31) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 62-78. - Procedures for microfilming and retention. 
(a)  Official police records may be microfilmed in accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 201.001 et seq. and the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  All original police records, except as provided in section 62-79(d), must be retained by the police department for 18 months from the date the original police records came into existence before such original police records are microfilmed. All police records microfilmed under this article must meet the requirements of United States of America Standards Institute for archival quality, density, resolution and definition. Any person or entity providing such microfilming services will certify that such microfilm meet such standards. Such certification will be forwarded to the chief of police. 
(c)  The city police department's recordkeeper or persons under his supervision will check or cause to be checked and certify that each microfilm record of the police records is a true and correct duplication of the original police records. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-32)  
Sec. 62-79. - Destruction and disposal. 
(a)  Before any disposal or destruction of any of the original police records by the police department is made, there must first be notice of the proposed destruction or disposal of such police records to the state librarian or state archivist, and if, in the opinion of either state agency, the proposed police records are needed for the state library, such police records shall be transferred thereto. 
(b)  After the police department has complied with section 62-78, any police records which are microfilmed in compliance with this article may be destroyed as directed by the police department with the advice and consent of the city attorney, unless otherwise prohibited by federal law, state law or valid court order. 
(c)  Any original police records which are part of any pending civil or criminal litigation may not be destroyed until such litigation is final. 
(d)  Any police records which are not required to be microfilmed in compliance with this article, and are determined worthless by the police department, may be destroyed as directed by the police department by following the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-33)  
Sec. 62-80. - Public access. 
The public shall have access to the information in the original police records and microfilmed police records to the extent that the public would be entitled to under existing state and federal law. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-34)  
Sec. 62-81. - Evidentiary use. 
Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 204.011, when the microfilmed police records are issued and certified by the recordkeeper or any persons acting under the direction and supervision of the recordkeeper of the police department, a copy on paper or film of the microfilm record will be accepted as a certified copy of an original record by any court or administrative agency of the state. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-35)  
Secs. 62-82—62-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - UNCLAIMED PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 62-101. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Unclaimed property means any such property turned over to the special services division which has not been restored to its owner under the provisions of chapter 47 of the state code of criminal procedures, as amended, and shall have remained unclaimed by its rightful owner for a period of 30 days from the date of acquisition by the police department or from the date that the property is no longer required to be held by the police department for evidentiary purposes or as otherwise required under the state code of criminal procedures. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-51) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 62-102. - Responsibility for possession and processing of confiscated property. 
All property seized by the police department or otherwise acquired by the police department as a result of police department operations and otherwise owned by third parties shall be, after initial processing in accordance with the state code of criminal procedures by the responsible officer, turned over to the special services division for safekeeping and disposition according to the terms of this article or as otherwise specified by the state code of criminal procedures. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-51)  
Sec. 62-103. - Processing claims for property by owners. 
All persons claiming ownership and desiring the return of property acquired by the police department shall file an application form, which shall be promulgated by the special services division of the police department, and present proof of purchase, ownership papers with serial number or other sufficient evidence relating to ownership of the claimed property. The special services division shall, after making record thereof, turn over any such claimed property upon the presentation of satisfactory evidence of ownership to the person making such claim. Where any such claim is based upon a general description of the property without other evidence of ownership, the special services division shall record such claim and hold such property for a period of six months, and if no other person shall make a claim for the property, the property will then be released to the original claimant after such six-month period. Should any other party make a claim for property being held during such six-month period, the matter will be referred to the municipal court of the city for an evidentiary hearing after which the municipal court judge shall make a ruling for the disposition of the property based on such hearing. If any claimant disagrees with the decision of the special services division to hold such property for such six-month period, such claimant shall, within five days of the decision of the special services division, file a written appeal with the chief of police, who shall hold a hearing relating to such appeal and shall have the authority to release such property or affirm the decision of the special services division. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-52)  
Sec. 62-104. - Procedures for sale of unclaimed property. 
(a)  The special services division shall be responsible for mailing a notice to the last known address of the owner, if known, of any unclaimed property by certified mail. Such notice shall describe the property, shall give the name and address of the officer holding such property, and shall state that if the owner does not claim such property within six months from the date of notice, such property shall be sold and the proceeds of such sale after deducting the reasonable expense of keeping such property and the cost of the sale shall be placed in the city general fund. 
(b)  If the owner of such property is unknown or if the address of the owner is unknown, then the special services division shall cause to be published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city a notice containing the description of the property held; the name of the owner, if known; the name and address of the officer holding such property; and a statement that if the owner does not claim such property within six months from the date of the publication, such property will thereafter be sold, and the proceeds of such sale, after deducting the reasonable expense of keeping such property and cost of the sale, will be placed in the city general fund. 
(c)  Any person making a claim for property after notice is provided for under this section, shall follow the same procedures as provided for in this section. Provided, however, that for property being claimed by general description for which a city six-month holding period has been established, the time period for claims made as a result of this action shall be the lesser of six months or the period between filing the claim and the date of sale as provided for in this section. 
(d)  The sale of any property under this section shall be preceded by notice published once at least three weeks prior to the date of such sale in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, stating the description of the property, the name of the owner if known, and the date and place that such sale will occur. If a representative of the special services division shall consider any bid as insufficient, he need not sell such property, but may decline such bid and reoffer such property for sale or otherwise put such property to use or dispose of such property upon written order of the chief of police. 
(e)  The real owner of any property sold under this section shall have the right to file a claim to the proceeds of such sale with the board of commissioners. If a claim is allowed by the board of commissioners, the director of finance shall pay the owner such funds as were paid into the general fund of the city as proceeds of the sale less costs of holding of the sale and storage. If the claim is denied by the board of commissioners or if the board of commissioners fails to act upon any such claim within 90 days from the date of claim, the claimant may sue the city in a court of competent jurisdiction in the county, and upon sufficient proof of ownership, cover judgment against the city to recover the proceeds of the sale as provided for in this section. Failure to initiate such suit within six months from the date authorized for the filing of such claim shall be deemed a waiver of any right to cover the proceeds of such sale. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-53)  
Sec. 62-105. - Certain items exempted from provisions of article. 
The disposition of gambling paraphernalia, prohibited weapons, criminal instruments, explosive weapons, chemical dispensing devices, and other contraband as defined in chapter 18 of the state code of criminal procedures shall be processed, returned or destroyed according to the applicable provisions of chapter 18 of the state code of criminal procedures, as amended, and shall not be subject to the procedures for processing required for unclaimed property as provided for in this article. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-54)  
Secs. 62-106—62-125. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - POLICE RESERVE FORCE PROGRAM 
 
Sec. 62-126. - Establishment. 
An auxiliary police force to be known as the McAllen Police Reserve in and for the city is hereby established. It shall be composed of personnel who have volunteered to join such organization and whose application for membership has been accepted after such persons have complied with all the rules, regulations and orders provided for the conduct, control and qualifications for membership for the members thereof. Such police reserve shall be composed of not to exceed 25 members. The police reserve shall be separate and distinct from the police department of the city, but shall be under the control and the supervision of the chief of police. The number of actual members of the police reserve shall be as required by the chief of police at his sole discretion, but shall not exceed 25 members. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-60)  
Sec. 62-127. - Qualifications for membership; termination; renewal. 
(a)  The membership of the police reserve force shall be composed of applicants selected by the chief of police or by a selection committee to be established by the chief of police for such purposes. All applicants must be U.S. citizens, residents of the county and between the ages of 21 and 55 years of age. In addition, all applicants must meet the minimum criteria as established by the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education as such criteria are in effect at the time of any application. Any selected applicant must apply for a temporary reserve officer license from the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education within the time limits as set by the chief of police, or otherwise have a valid and outstanding reserve officer license issued by the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education. In order to remain a member of the police reserve force, each member must diligently comply with all the requirements in order to receive the permanent reserve law enforcement license from the state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education. The chief of police is hereby authorized to formulate any application forms and establish criteria for minimum requirements for licensing as a reserve peace officer. 
(b)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to terminate any member of the police reserve force for any cause deemed sufficient by the chief of police. The chief of police is hereby authorized to establish procedures for resignation from the police reserve force and it shall be the duty of any police reserve officer to follow such resignation procedures as established by the chief of police. 
(c)  The membership in the police reserve force shall expire automatically as to each member at midnight on December 31 of each year. Any existing member in good standing on such date shall have the right to file for a renewal of his membership with the chief of police according to the standards and specifications as established by the chief of police. Priority for selection shall be granted to each past member in good standing of the police reserve force who applies for renewal of membership. Notwithstanding this provision, the chief of police may establish procedures for extending membership in the police reserve force after midnight December 31 in any year, pending the application process or renewal of membership after such date and until members are reappointed or new members are appointed under the selection process. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-61)  
Sec. 62-128. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to establish standard operating procedures and rules and regulations for the police reserve which may be amended from time to time and which such procedures, rules and regulations shall be followed by all officers at all times. The chief of police, in establishing rules and regulations and operating procedures for the police reserve, shall follow any and all state statutes, state commission on law enforcement officer standards and education rules and regulations, or directives as may be issued from time to time by the state authority having jurisdiction thereof. 
(b)  Members of the police reserve force shall be prohibited, while on duty or otherwise, from carrying a firearm except on the express written order of the chief of police. 
(c)  Members of the police reserve force shall at all times be assigned to, and under the immediate supervision of, a regular police officer of the police force. The chief of police shall establish training procedures for the regular members of the police force to carry out the duties as established in this article or as otherwise provided by the chief of police. 
(d)  The chief of police is hereby ordered to establish procedures for establishing restrictions relating to the duties and powers of members of the police reserve force to make arrests while in the line of duty. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-62)  
Sec. 62-129. - Identification, uniforms; false impersonation. 
(a)  All current members of the reserve police force shall carry an identification card or such other insignia or evidence of identity as the chief of police may prescribe, and each member must carry such identification at all times while on duty, and shall surrender such identification upon termination of his membership. The chief of police is hereby authorized to issue equipment including uniforms to all members of the police reserve force. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than a member in good standing of the police reserve force to wear, carry or display any police reserve force identification card or otherwise represent himself to be connected with the police reserve force unless he is, in fact, a member thereof in good standing. Each incident or violation as provided for in this section shall be a separate offense, and upon conviction therefor, such person shall be subject to a fine as prescribed in section 1-14 for each conviction thereof. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-63)  
Sec. 62-130. - Annual reports. 
The chief of police is hereby directed to present an annual report of activity of the police reserve force and any and all rules and regulations and operating procedures as promulgated to the board of commissioners and the city manager. The report of the chief of police shall be furnished to the board of commissioners and to the city manager between January 1 and January 31 of each year. 
(Code 1966, § 17½-64)  
Chapter 66 - LIBRARY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 94. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 66-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Library means buildings, furniture, and physical and digital materials owned by the city or used by the city for the purpose of supplying its citizens with accepted library functions, including branch locations. 
Library director means a person so designated and appointed as provided in this chapter and who is in charge of the library department. 
(Code 1966, § 18-3; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 66-2. - Designation of name. 
The name of the public library shall be "McAllen Public Library." 
(Code 1966, § 18-2; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Sec. 66-3. - Violation of lending privileges. 
Every person who shall take from the public library any book, periodical, film, equipment, artwork, physical material or other property, except in accordance with the rules of such library, shall, upon conviction, be punished pursuant to section 1-14. It shall be the duty of each person who holds a library borrower's card to notify the library of any change of residence or contact information. 
(Code 1966, § 18-4; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Sec. 66-4. - Neglect to return materials. 
Every person who shall take or borrow from the public library any book, periodical, physical or digital material, or other property, and neglect to return the same by the due date will be sent an electronic notification. A block will be placed on the borrower's patron account and on any account linked to the borrower's account. Failure to return the overdue material shall, upon conviction, be punished pursuant to section 1-14. 
(Code 1966, § 18-5; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Sec. 66-5. - Defacing library property. 
Every person who shall intentionally cut, mutilate, mark, tear, write upon, deface or otherwise destroy or injure in whole or in part any book, periodical, map or document, picture, written or engraved or printed paper, digital or computer equipment, artwork or other property belonging to the public library, or residing on library property, or who shall suffer any such injury to be inflicted while such property is in his custody, or shall willfully or wantonly mark or deface or in any way injure the public library or any part thereof, or any fixtures therein or appertaining thereto, shall, upon conviction, be punished pursuant to section 1-14. 
(Code 1966, § 18-6; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Sec. 66-6. - Penalties not exclusive. 
(a)  The penalties prescribed in sections 66-3, 66-4 and 66-5 for the violation of lending privileges, neglect to return books and materials, and defacing of library property shall in no way be interpreted to preclude prosecution by the appropriate authorities of any person whose actions in violating such sections constitute a class B misdemeanor, class A misdemeanor, or felony under state or federal law. 
(b)  The penalties prescribed in sections 66-3, 66-4 and 66-5 shall not preclude a civil action for monetary damages or other relief brought by the city against a person violating such sections or against the parent, guardian, managing conservator, possessory conservator, or other person having the duty of control and reasonable discipline of a child under V.T.C.A., Texas Family Code ch. 41 where such child has violated such sections of this chapter. 
(Code 1966, § 18-7; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Secs. 66-7—66-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - LIBRARY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-76 et seq.; procedure for appointment and terms and qualifications of board members, § 2-77; substantial evidence rule in effect regarding appeals from decisions of boards, commissions and committees, § 2-82. 
 
Sec. 66-31. - Created; official name. 
There is hereby created a public library advisory board to be known as the McAllen Public Library Advisory Board. 
(Code 1966, § 18-12; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Sec. 66-32. - Composition; appointment. 
(a)  The McAllen Public Library Advisory Board shall be composed of seven members and one alternate. 
(b)  All members of the library board shall be appointed and shall serve as provided in sections 2-76 through 2-82, and the alternate shall be appointed by the library director. 
(c)  The alternate member shall vote in the event the full board is not present at the meeting. 
(Code 1966, § 18-13; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Sec. 66-33. - Powers and duties. 
The McAllen Public Library Advisory Board shall make recommendations to the library director concerning the review, formulation and adoption of written operating policies for the library as included in the library policies and procedures manual and assist the library director in promoting library facilities, programs, and materials. 
(Code 1966, § 18-15; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Secs. 66-34, 66-35. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-82, § II, adopted Nov. 26, 2016, repealed §§ 66-34 and 66-35, which pertained to "Constitution and bylaws" and "Incurring expenses on behalf of city," and derived from Code 1966, §§ 18-16, 18-17.  
Secs. 66-36—66-55. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LIBRARY DEPARTMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Officers and employees, § 2-196 et seq.; substantial evidence rule in effect in appeals from decisions or orders of city officers or employees, § 2-196. 
 
Sec. 66-56. - Created. 
There is hereby created the library department for the city. 
(Code 1966, § 18-1; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Sec. 66-57. - Library director—Office created; appointment; qualifications. 
There is hereby created the office of library director who shall be appointed by the city manager and who shall be a person professionally competent by experience and training, with a master's degree in library science from an american library association accredited institution, to manage the municipal library department. 
(Code 1966, § 18-18; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Sec. 66-58. - Same—Powers and duties. 
The library director shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To adopt after consulting the McAllen Public Library Advisory Board, all rules and regulations deemed necessary for administration, government and protection of the library, meeting rooms, and all other library property and to enforce all such rules and regulations. 
(2)  To cause to be purchased through the purchasing agent of the city, in the manner provided by the Charter and ordinances of the city, all books, periodicals, and audio-visual materials, whether physical or digital, and other necessary property, including furniture, appliances, equipment, and supplies for the operation of the public library and the municipal library department. 
(3)  With the approval of the city manager, to select and employ a librarian and other assistants and employees as may be necessary for the operation and maintenance of the library and public meeting rooms. 
(Code 1966, § 18-19; Ord. No. 2016-82, II, 11-28-16)  
Chapter 70 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Municipal court, ch. 34; fireworks, § 50-91 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— In order to accommodate Ord. No. 1995-37, § I, adopted July 24, 1995, which provided for establishment of Art. II, §§ 70-1—70-13 have been grouped under the heading of Art. I. 
 
Sec. 70-1. - Abandoned iceboxes, refrigerators, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or dangerously expose any refrigerator, icebox, cold storage box, or any container having attached or affixed to the door thereon a spring lock or a latch fastener or lock that permits the opening of the door thereon from the outside only, unless such refrigerator, icebox, cold storage box, or container has had removed therefrom the door thereon or the latch, lock or fastener attached to such door. 
(Code 1966, § 19-2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 756.001.  
Sec. 70-2. - Leaving a child in a vehicle. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally or knowingly leave a child in a motor vehicle for longer than five minutes, knowing that the child is: 
(1)  Younger than seven years of age; and 
(2)  Not attended by an individual in the vehicle who is 14 years of age or older. 
(b)  Any person convicted for an offense under this section in the municipal court of the city shall be subject to a fine as provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1966, § 19-9)  
Sec. 70-3. - Damaging property generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, hack, deface, break, damage, remove, paint, mark or otherwise injure any building, fence, railing, awning, post, fixture, telephone, telegraph or electric wire or post, shade tree, ornament, monument, bulletin board, sign, show frame, fruit or other stand, platform, bridge or any other thing not the property or under the control of such person. 
(Ord. No. 1993-67, § I(a), 9-27-93)  
Sec. 70-4. - Damaging, defacing or littering public or school property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this section for any person at any time to damage, destroy or injure any public property or property of the city independent school district or any improvements located thereon, or to deface any of such property by painting, marking or otherwise placing thereon any signs, paintings, words or language, whether obscene or not. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person at any time to throw upon or allow to come to rest upon any public place or property of the city independent school district any trash, garbage or litter, as such terms are defined in the litter ordinance of the city. 
(c)  The violation of any of the provisions of this section is declared to be unlawful and a misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-14. 
(d)  The penalty provisions of this section shall not preclude the use of any other remedy at law or in equity to which the city may resort to ensure that the provisions of this section are not violated. 
(Code 1966, § 19-15.1) 
Charter reference— Power to abate and remove nuisances, art. 11.  
Sec. 70-5. - Reward for furnishing information leading to apprehension and conviction of a person willfully damaging certain property. 
(a)  The city hereby authorizes payment of a reward of $50.00 for furnishing information to the chief of police of the city leading to the apprehension and conviction of any person willfully damaging any traffic signs, street name signs, traffic control devices, public buildings or furniture located therein, or any property of the city in violation of state and federal laws. 
(b)  If information is furnished to the chief of police leading to the apprehension and conviction of any person violating this section, the city treasurer is hereby authorized upon proper certification from the chief of police to issue a check on the general fund of the city in payment of the reward provided in this section. 
(Code 1966, § 19-27)  
Sec. 70-5.5. - Parental responsibility. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  "Child" means a person under 18 years of age who is not and has not been married or who has not had his disabilities of minority removed for general purposes. 
(2)  "Parent" means the mother, a man as to whom the child is legitimate, or an adopted mother or father, a court-appointed guardian or conservator or other person 18 years or older, authorized by the parent, by court order, or by the court appointed guardian or conservator to have the care and custody of a child. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a parent of a child to fail to repair or pay for any property damage proximately caused by: 
(1)  The negligent conduct of the child if the conduct is reasonably attributable to the negligent failure of the parent to exercise control and reasonable discipline of the child; or 
(2)  The willful and malicious conduct of a child who is at least 12 years of age but under 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 1995-38, § I, 7-24-95) 
Editor's note— Prior to the re-establishment of § 70-5.5 by Ord. No. 1995-38, Ord. No. 1994-59, § I, adopted Aug. 22, 1994, set out provisions repealing § 70-5.5, which pertained to graffiti and derived from Code 1966, § 19-6 and Ord. No. 1993-67, § I(b)—(j), adopted Sept. 27, 1993.  
Sec. 70-6. - Firearms, discharging. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any gun, pistol or other firearm of any kind within the city, except inside an indoor shooting range established and operated in compliance with all applicable legal requirements. This section shall not apply to police officers acting in the line of duty. 
(Code 1966, § 19-11; Ord. No. 2012-20, § I, 3-26-12)  
Sec. 70-7. - Possession of firearms by minors. 
It shall be unlawful for any minor to have in his possession or carry on his person, except within the minor's domicile, a revolver, rifle, shotgun or any firearm which is of either air compression or percussion nature unless such minor is accompanied and supervised by a parent, guardian or responsible adult. 
(Code 1966, § 19-12)  
Sec. 70-8. - Disturbing the peace. 
Any person who shall disturb the peace and quiet of any person, family or neighborhood, or who shall disturb the peace and order of any assembly or meeting of people assembled for worship or other purposes, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 19-8)  
Sec. 70-9. - Throwing stones or missiles. 
Any person who shall throw or cast any stone or missile of any kind, either with or without the aid of a catapult or sling, at or against any person or property not belonging to him, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1966, § 19-19)  
Sec. 70-10. - Advertising on public street or alley right-of-way. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, whether individually or through an agent, employee or representative, to place, erect or install any advertising sign or billboard on any public street or alley right-of-way within the city. 
(b)  The purpose of this section on advertising on the public street or alley right-of-way is to promote public safety by ensuring that signs and billboards: 
(1)  Do not obstruct the sidewalk area along public streets which have a primary purpose of safe use by pedestrians; 
(2)  Do not obstruct firefighting or police surveillance; 
(3)  Do not create traffic hazards by distracting operators of motor vehicles; and 
(4)  Do not create traffic hazards by impairing the vehicle operators' ability to see pedestrians, obstacles or other vehicles when using public streets or when entering public streets from alleys, private driveways, or other streets. 
(Code 1966, § 19-3.1)  
Sec. 70-11. - Trespassing on city drainage right-of-way/state right-of-way. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except when legally authorized, to enter or to trespass upon city drainage right-of-way property or state improved drainage right-of-way property when such person is operating a motorized vehicle or such person is using a skateboard, roller skates, coasters or other similar type devices. 
(b)  Any police officer of the city who shall detect a violation of this section shall be authorized to issue a citation under the provisions of section 62-1(b). 
(c)  Any person who shall be convicted of any violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(Code 1966, § 19-28)  
Sec. 70-12. - Blasting operations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to blast or cause to be blasted within the limits of the city any rock or other material without having such rock or other material covered with good sound timber or other material to effectively prevent fragments of rock or other material blasted from being thrown into the air. 
(Code 1966, § 19-4)  
Sec. 70-13. - Defecation, urination in public places. 
It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to urinate against any wall or in any street or alley; or to make a fecal defecation in any street or alley, or in any open lot, or under any house or platform within the city. 
(Code 1966, § 19-7)  
Sec. 70-14. - Concealed handguns prohibited. 
The carrying of any concealed handgun by any person unless such person is a licensed peace officer under the laws of the state and is carrying a concealed handgun under the course and scope of his employment, is prohibited on all city-owned premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to carry a concealed handgun in violation of the provisions of this section. The city manager is hereby authorized to post notice of this prohibition at the entrance of all city premises. Any person carrying a concealed handgun in violation of this prohibition shall be considered to be entering the premises of the city in violation of Penal Code § 30.05, being the criminal trespass statute of the state. 
(Ord. No. 1995-66, § I, 11-27-95) 
Cross reference— Discharging firearms, § 70-6; possession of firearms by minors, § 70-7.  
Secs. 70-15—70-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CURFEW HOURS FOR MINORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-21, § 1, adopted March 10, 2003, provides for an extension of the provisions of Ch. 70, Art. II. Section 2 of said ordinance provides, "That within thirty-six (36) months after the passage of this ordinance, unless another time limit is provided under State law enacted after the effective date hereof, the Chief of Police shall review this ordinance and make recommendations to the City Commission concerning the effectiveness of and the continuing need for the ordinance." Subsequently, the following ordinances provide for the extention of art. II provisions: Ord. No. 2006-15, § 1, adopted Feb. 15, 2006; Ord. No. 2009-78, § I, adopted Nov. 23, 2009; Ord. No. 2012-61, § II, adopted Sept. 24, 2012; Ord. No. 2015-72, §§ I, II, adopted Aug. 24, 2015; Ord. No. 2018-53, § I, adopted Aug. 13, 2018. 
 
Sec. 70-20. - Definitions. 
Chief of police means the Chief of Police of the City of McAllen or a designated representative. 
Curfew hours means: 
(1)  10:30 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, or Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; and 
(2)  12:01 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. on any Saturday or Sunday. 
Direct route means the shortest path of travel through a public place to reach a final destination without any detour or stop along the way. 
Emergency means, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
Establishment means any privately-owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
Holding location means a place designated by the chief of police to which a minor taken into custody for a violation of this section will be delivered to await pickup by a parent or juvenile authorities. 
Minor means any person under 17 years of age. 
Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
Parent means a person who is: 
(1)  A natural or adoptive parent of another person; 
(2)  A court-appointed guardian to have the care and custody of another person; 
(3)  At least 21 years of age and authorized by a parent or court-appointed guardian to have the care and custody of another person. 
Public place means any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, playground, park, plaza, building, or other place used by or open to the public. 
Remain means to: 
(1)  Linger or stay unnecessarily; or 
(2)  Fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator or other person in control of the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1995-37, § I, 7-24-95; Ord. No. 1995-59, § I, 10-23-95; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 1, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 2006-15, § 1, 2-15-06; Ord. No. 2006-18, § 1, 2-27-06; Ord. No. 2009-78, § I, 11-23-09; Ord. No. 2012-61, § II, 9-24-12)  
Sec. 70-21. - Offenses. 
(a)  A minor commits an offense if he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(b)  A parent of a minor commits an offense if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours. 
(c)  The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if he knowingly allows a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. 
(Ord. No. 1995-37, § I, 7-24-95; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 1, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 2006-15, § 1, 2-15-06; Ord. No. 2009-78, § I, 11-23-09; Ord. No. 2012-61, § II, 9-24-12)  
Sec. 70-22. - Defenses. 
(a)  It is a defense to prosecution under section 70-21 that the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the minor's parent; 
(2)  On an errand at the direction of the minor's parent and was using a direct route; 
(3)  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  Engaged in an employment activity, including but not limited to newspaper delivery, and was using a direct route; 
(5)  Involved in an emergency; 
(6)  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence; 
(7)  Attending an official school or religious activity or returning home by a direct route from an official school or religious activity. 
(8)  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or 
(9)  Married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with V.T.C.A. Family Code ch. 31. 
(Ord. No. 1995-37, § I, 7-24-95; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 1, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 2006-15, § 1, 2-15-06; Ord. No. 2009-78, § I, 11-23-09; Ord. No. 2012-61, § II, 9-24-12)  
Sec. 70-23. - Enforcement. 
(a)  A police officer, upon finding a minor in violation of subsection 70-21, shall: 
(1)  Ascertain the name and address of the minor; 
(2)  Issue to the minor a written warning that the minor is in violation of section 70-21; and 
(3)  Order the minor to go promptly home by a direct route. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section, a police officer, upon finding a minor in violation of section 70-21, may take the minor into custody and deliver the minor to a holding location if: 
(1)  The minor has received two previous written warnings for a violation of section 70-21; or 
(2)  Reasonable grounds exist to believe the minor has engaged in delinquent conduct or conduct indicating a need for supervision in accordance with V.C.T.A. Family Code § 51.03 and § 52.01. 
(c)  When a minor is taken into custody under this subsection, the police department shall immediately notify a parent to pick up the minor at the holding location. After a parent arrives at a holding location and provides the information required by the chief of police to file an incident report, the minor shall be released into the custody of the parent. If a parent cannot be located or fails to take charge of the minor, the minor shall be released to the juvenile authorities. 
(d)  If a minor is not taken into custody for a violation of section 70-21, the police department shall by certified mail, return receipt requested, notify a parent of the minor that the minor has violated section 70-21 and include a warning that any subsequent violation may result in prosecution of the minor and the parent under this section. If the minor was found in violation of section 70-20 at an establishment, the police department shall by certified mail, return receipt requested, notify the owner, operator, or employee of the establishment of the violation and include a warning that any subsequent violation may result in prosecution of the owner, operator, and employee under this section. 
(e)  A police officer shall, within 24 hours after finding a minor in violation of section 70-21 file a written report on the incident or assist to the extent possible in the preparation and filing of the report by a supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 1995-37, § I, 7-24-95; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 1, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 2006-15, § 1, 2-15-06; Ord. No. 2009-78, § I, 11-23-09; Ord. No. 2012-61, § II, 9-24-12)  
Sec. 70-24. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any minor who violates section 70-21 of this article three or more times within any 24-month period is subject to appropriate action by a juvenile court in accordance with V.T.C.A. ch. 51 and ch. 52. A minor may be prosecuted in municipal court for a violation of section 70-21 and upon conviction be subject to a fine not to exceed $500.00 per violation. 
(b)  A parent of a minor who violates section 70-21 of this article is, upon conviction, punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 1995-37, § I, 7-24-95; Ord. No. 2003-21, § 1, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 2006-15, § 1, 2-15-06; Ord. No. 2009-78, § I, 11-23-09; Ord. No. 2012-61, § II, 9-24-12)  
ARTICLE III. - SEX OFFENDERS 
 
Sec. 70-25. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, and terms not defined here shall be construed as in ordinary and common usage: 
Child safety area shall mean all improved and unimproved areas of a lot or tract of land that is used as a private or public elementary or secondary school, public or private school bus stop or school bus shelter, licensed day-care center or facility, private or public playground, private or public youth center, public swimming pool, video arcade facility, amusement park, carnival, public park when the use is intended primarily for children or public library. 
Child sex offender shall mean any person with a reportable conviction or adjudication for any of the following offenses: 
(1)  Continuous sexual abuse of a young child or children (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 21.02); 
(2)  Indecency with a child (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 21.11); 
(3)  Sexual assault of a child (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 22.011); 
(4)  Aggravated sexual assault of a child (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 22.021); 
(5)  Online solicitation of a minor (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 33.021); 
(6)  Sexual performance by a child, (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.25); 
(7)  Possession or promotion of child pornography (V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.26); 
(8)  A violation of the laws of another state, federal law, laws of a foreign country, or the Uniform Code of Military Justice, if the violation contained elements substantially similar to the elements of the violations described (1) through (7) of this paragraph. 
Day-care center or facility shall mean a facility licensed by the State of Texas, which provides care, training, education, custody, treatment, or supervision of children for less than 24 hours a day. 
Loiter shall mean standing or sitting idly, whether or not in a motor vehicle, in and around an area. 
Minor shall mean any person under 18 years of age. 
Permanent residence shall mean a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for 14 or more consecutive days. 
Person in authority shall mean the owner, a person authorized by the owner, or a person or business with apparent authority to act for the owner, including but not limited to, a manager or a property management business. 
Public park shall mean any land, including improvements to the land, designated for the use of the general public or any athletic field that is owned, leased, operated, managed, or maintained by the city, including, but not limited to, swimming pools, soccer fields, baseball fields, softball fields, basketball courts, water parks, conservation areas, jogging trails, and hiking trails. 
Reportable conviction or adjudication shall have the meaning assigned by V.T.C.A., Texas Code of Criminal Procedure § 62.001(5). 
Temporary residence shall mean a place where a person abides, lodges, or resides for a period of 14 or more days in the aggregate during any calendar year and which is not the person's permanent residence, or a place where a person abides, resides, or lodges for a period of four or more consecutive or nonconsecutive days in any month and which is not the person's permanent residence. 
In this article, "playground," "premises," "school," "video arcade facility," and "youth center" shall have the meanings assigned by V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 481.134. 
(Ord. No. 2016-87, § I, 12-12-16)  
Sec. 70-26. - Sex offender entry and loitering restriction. 
(a)  It is an offense for a child sex offender to intentionally or knowingly enter a child safety area. 
(b)  It is an offense for a child sex offender to intentionally or knowingly loiter within 300 feet of a child safety area. 
(c)  For purposes of subsection (b), measurement is made in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, between the location and the nearest property line of the child safety area. 
(d)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section if at the time a person prohibited from entering a child safety area is the parent or legal guardian of a child 18 years of age or younger who resides with the person and the child was on the premises of the child safety area. 
(e)  A child sex offender who has a right to be present at an official meeting is exempted from this section and may approach and enter the child safety area for such time as is necessary to attend the official meeting. This exemption shall only apply to those areas of the child safety area that are necessary for attendance at the official meeting, and any child sex offender found outside such areas shall be in violation of this article. 
(f)  When a polling place for an election is located within a child safety area, a child sex offender is exempted from this section and may approach and enter the child safety area for the limited purpose of voting if the child sex offender qualifies to vote at such place. This exemption shall only apply to those areas of the child safety area that are necessary for voting, and any child sex offender found outside such areas shall be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-87, § I, 12-12-16)  
Sec. 70-27. - Sex offender Halloween restrictions. 
(a)  A child sex offender shall on October 30 th and 31 st of each year or any other date set by the city for trick-or-treaters: 
(1)  Remain at their residence of registry between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 11:59 p.m.; 
(2)  Leave all exterior lights off; and, 
(3)  Refrain from inviting trick-or-treaters to solicit the premises at their residence of registry. 
(b)  It is an offense for a child sex offender to fail to abide by any of the restrictions under this section. 
(c)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section that the child sex offender was required to report and did report to a specified location on October 30 and 31 or any other date set by the city for trick-or-treaters as a condition of their probation or parole; 
(d)  A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of an offense under this section and need not be alleged or proved. 
(Ord. No. 2016-87, § I, 12-12-16)  
Sec. 70-28. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor and upon conviction, adjudication, or deferred disposition thereof shall be fined in an amount not to exceed $500.00 for each and every offense. Each and every violation or day that such violation shall continue or exist shall be deemed a separate offense. The penal provisions imposed under this section shall not preclude the city from filing suit to enjoin a violation of this section. The city shall retain all legal rights and remedies available to it pursuant to local, state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 2016-87, § I, 12-12-16)  
Sec. 70-29. - Enforcement. 
The police department of the City of McAllen is hereby authorized to issue citations and/or arrest any person(s) who violates any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-87, § I, 12-12-16)  
Sec. 70-30. - Savings clause. 
If any section, part, or provision of this article is declared unconstitutional or invalid, by a court of competent jurisdiction, then, in that event, it is expressly provided, and it is the intention of the city commission in passing this article that its parts shall be severable and all other parts of this article shall not be affected thereby and they shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 2016-87, § I, 12-12-16)  
Chapter 74 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages prohibited in the McAllen Nature Center, § 6-4; smoking prohibited in certain public places, § 54-122; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 94.
