ARTICLE I. - CITY OF MCALLEN PARK LAND DEDICATION AND PARK DEVELOPMENT FEES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2000-67, § 2, adopted Aug. 28, 2000, amended the title of article I to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 74-1. - Requirements for park land dedication. 
(a)  Neighborhood and community parks and recreational facilities are those facilities providing for a variety of recreational opportunities within convenient distances from a majority of the residences to be served thereby. Park zones will be established by the parks and recreation department and shown on the official city limits map for the City of McAllen and shall be prima facie proof that any park located therein is within such a convenient distance from any residence located therein. The ultimate residential property owners, who by reason of the proximity of their property to such parks, shall be the primary beneficiaries of such facilities. Therefore, the following requirements are adopted to effect the purposes stated. 
(b)  Based on the information presented to the parks and recreation advisory board for the purposes of determining the city's needs and level of park land development and park development amount, the city commission hereby makes the following findings: 
(1)  The minimum acreage per 1,000 people population to be dedicated for park purposes in order to meet that minimum standards for adequate usage, is based on five acres of land per 1,000 ultimate residents. 
(2)  The average number of persons residing in any one housing unit in McAllen is 3.18 persons. For the purpose of this article, 3.18 persons per housing unit is know as the dwelling unit equivalent. 
(3)  The average cost per acre of park land for purposes of purchase is $27,620.00 per acre. This amount does not include development costs of such park. 
(4)  The average cost per acre for development of a basic neighborhood and community parks is $60,000.00 per acre. 
(5)  For the purpose of the calculation of the parks development fees, based on the formula of five acres per 1,000 population, using the dwelling unit equivalent of 3.184 persons per dwelling unit equivalent, the cost of $27,620.00 per acre, and the cost for development is $60,000 per acre, then the city's cost per dwelling unit equivalent is calculated to be $1,393.16. The fee charged to developer/owner of the property will be 32.3 percent of $1,393.16, which equals a $450.00 per dwelling unit equivalent. 
FORMULA: 
5 Acres X ($27,620 X $60,000) X 1 Dwelling Unit X 3.18 Persons Per Unit) / 1,000 > = $1,393.16 per dwelling unit; 
(6)  For the purposes of a single-family residential subdivision, one lot equals one dwelling unit equivalent, for the purposes of multifamily subdivisions, the dwelling unit equivalents will be equal to the number of apartments, condominiums, townhomes, or similar single-family housing units. For calculation of the parks for a subdivision, other than a single-family residential subdivision, the dwelling unit equivalent calculation shall be based on the highest density authorized under the McAllen zoning ordinance for the use classification for the acreage of the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 1998-113, § 1, 11-23-98; Ord. No. 2000-67, § 2, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 2002-32, § 1, 5-31-02)  
Sec. 74-2. - General requirements. 
(a)  Whenever a final plat is filed for approval within the city for the development of a residential area under zoning use district R-1, R-2, R-3A, R-3T, R-3C and R-4 in accordance with the planning and zoning regulations of the city, such plat shall contain a clear fee simple dedication of an area of land to the city for park purposes, which area shall be calculated at a rate of not less than five acres of park land per 1,000 ultimate residents. Any proposed plat submitted to the city for approval should show the area proposed to be dedicated under this subsection. Such dedication shall be subject to the approval process as provided for below. 
EXAMPLE: 
5 Acres X 65 Dwelling Units X 3.18 Person Per Unit / 1000 = 1.0335 acres to be dedicated 
(b)  When a final plat is filed for approval within the city for the development of a residential area under zoning use districts R-1, R-2, R-3A and R-3C, R-3T and R-4, and require less than one acre of dedication all other residential use districts, then such plat shall not be finally approved until there is a payment of the park development fee of $450.00 per dwelling unit equivalent. 
(c)  Whenever a building permit for new construction, remodeling or addition is applied for, within the city limits, on property already platted, the creates additional residential dwelling units, a park development fee of $450.00 per dwelling unit shall be paid prior to issuance of the building permit. 
(d)  The park development fee required to be collected under the provisions of this section shall be increased on January 1st of each year hereafter as follows: 
(1)  January 1, 2003—$1,393.16 ×. 35.9% = $500.00; 
(2)  January 1, 2004—$1,393.16 ×. 39.5% = $550.00; 
(3)  January 1, 2005—$1,393.16 × 41.1% = $600.00; 
(4)  January 1, 2006—$1,393.16 × 46.7% = $650.00; and 
(5)  January 1, 2007—$1,393.16 × 50.2% = $700.00. 
The above referenced adjustment to the park development fee is based on projected inflationary influences of the cost of the value of real property for the City of McAllen. 
(e)  In lieu of the payment of the park development fee as provided for in subsection (b) and (c) above, the developer/owner of a property may propose to convey to the city fee simple a real property in an area of not less than one acre. The credit against park development fee for dedication of real property shall be calculated at a rate of not less than five acres of park land per 1,000 ultimate residents. The city commission may approve or disapprove the dedication and require the payment of the park development fee in the course of review process as set out in subsection (d). 
(f)  The board of commission declares a development of an area resulting in land dedications smaller than one acres, for public park purposes, may be impractical and for such reason, the park development fee will be applied to any such development which would require less than one acre dedicated for park lands, unless the developer specifically proposes that the park lands be accepted and the city commission specifically approves the same. 
(g)  In all instances where the dedication of more than five acres or greater is required under the provisions of this section, or where dedication of greater than one acre but less than five acres is proposed under the provisions of this section, the city commission shall have the right to accept the dedication for approval on the plat, or to refuse the same, after consideration of the recommendation of the park land dedication advisory board hereinafter created, and to require payment of the applicable park development fee, in lieu of the land, in the amount as provided for in this section. 
(h)  There is hereby created the park land dedication advisory board to be made up of seven members to be appointed by the board of commissioners. At least three of the members shall be chosen from the parks and recreation advisory board and the remaining four members shall be City of McAllen employees or officials. Such board will meet at any time that a property dedicated for park land purposes is pending for review by the board of commissioners. Such board shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman and secretary, and meetings of such board shall be posted in accordance with the Open Meetings Act of Texas. Such board shall make a recommendation to the board of commissioners relating to the acceptance or rejection of the proposed dedicated land for park purposes under a requirement for subdivision plat or building permit as applicable. The general criteria for determination shall be whether or not there is sufficient park area in the public domain in the area of the proposed development or if the recreation potential for that park zone would be better served by expanding or improving existing parks, or whether or not the particular property is suitable for park purposes because of traffic conditions, environmental concerns, adjacent property uses, configuration of the property or other appropriate criteria to be established by the committee. 
(i)  The city commission, upon recommendation by the park land dedication advisory board, shall review the request for dedication as applicable relating to a subdivision plat or building permit, and approve the dedication or reject the same and require a different dedication of parks land within the subdivision or require the payment of the applicable park development fee. 
(j)  The dedication required by this section shall be made by recording the final plat and contemporaneously, by separate instrument, unless additional dedication is required subsequent to the filing of the final plat. If the actual number of completed dwelling units exceeds the figure upon which the original dedication was based, such additional dedication shall be required, and shall be made by payment of cash, in lieu of land, in the amount as provided for in this section. 
(k)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to a property outside the city limits, that is voluntarily annexed into the city on or after September 1, 2019. 
(Ord. No. 1998-113, § 1, 11-23-98; Ord. No. 2000-67, §§ 2, 3, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 2001-93, § 1, 12-10-01; Ord. No. 2002-32, § 2, 5-31-02; Ord. No. 2002-57, § 8, 9-11-02; Ord. No. 2002-67, § 1, 10-14-02; Ord. No. 2019-43, § I, 8-12-19)  
Sec. 74-3. - Special fund; right to refund. 
(a)  There is hereby established a special fund for the deposit of all sums paid in lieu of land dedicated for park purposes, which fund shall be known as the park land dedication fund. All interest accruing to such account shall be deposited to same, and shall be used for the same purpose as the fund. 
(b)  The city shall account for all sums paid in lieu of land dedication under section 74-2. Any funds paid for such purposes must be expended by the city within six years from the date received by the city for the acquisition or development. Such funds should be considered to be spent on a first in, first out basis. If not so expended, the then owners of the property, subject to refund on the last day of such period shall be entitled to a prorata refund of such sums computed on a dwelling unit equivalent for monies which were collected under money in lieu of land under section 74-2. The then owners of such property must request such refund within one year of entitlement, in writing, or such right shall be forever barred. 
(Ord. No. 1998-113, § 1, 11-23-98; Ord. No. 2000-67, §§ 2, 4, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 2001-93, § 2, 12-10-01; Ord. No. 2002-32, § 4, 5-31-02) 
Editor's note— Formerly § 74-4.  
Sec. 74-4. - Additional requirements; definitions. 
(a)  Any land dedicated to the city under this section must be suitable for park and recreation uses. The following characteristics of a proposed area are generally unsuitable: 
(1)  Any area primarily located in the 100-year floodplain. 
(2)  Any areas of unusual topography, or slope, which renders same unusable for organized recreational activities. 
a.  Drainage areas may be accepted as part of a park if the channel is constructed in accordance with city engineering standards, and if no significant area of the park is cut off from access by such channel. 
b.  Each park must have ready access to a public street or roadway. 
(b)  For the purpose of this article, the following terms are defined as noted: 
(1)  City park shall mean any park which is owned, maintained or operated by the City of McAllen, Texas. 
(2)  Neighborhood park shall mean a park of three to 15 acres, suitable for intense recreational activities such as field games, court games, playground apparatus, picnicking, etc., generally serving a population within a one-quarter to one-half mile radius of the park. 
(3)  Community park shall mean a park of 15 acres or more, suitable for diverse activities, such as intense recreational activities, athletic complexes, swimming pools, etc., generally serving a population within a ½-3 mile radius of the park, or several neighborhoods. 
(4)  Residential dwelling unit shall mean any unit designed as a stand-alone dwelling, consisting of sleeping, bathing and cooking facilities. 
(5)  Commercial space shall mean any space designed to hold a separate commercial enterprise. 
(Ord. No. 1998-113, § 1, 11-23-98; Ord. No. 2000-67, § 2, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 2002-32, § 5, 5-31-02) 
Editor's note— Formerly § 74-5.  
Sec. 74-5. - Administrative procedures. 
(a)  The planning department shall be responsible for processing and collecting park fees at the time of subdivision platting. 
(b)  The building permits and inspections department shall be responsible for processing and collecting park fees at the time of issuance of a building permit. 
(c)  Before receiving a building permit or a recorded plat, the land owner shall submit, and the staff shall confirm and/or adjust according to the ordinance of the City of McAllen, the maximum total number of proposed dwelling unit equivalents which may be constructed on the plat or in the development. The required fee or land dedication shall be calculated based on the provisions of section 74-2, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 1998-113, § 1, 11-23-98; Ord. No. 2000-67, §§ 2, 3, 8-28-00; Ord. No. 2002-32, § 5, 5-31-02) 
Editor's note— Formerly § 74-6.  
Secs. 74-6—74-25. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - USE PERMITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Substantial evidence rule in effect in appeals from decisions or orders of city officers or employees, § 2-196. 
 
Sec. 74-51. - Required. 
No person, group or organization shall be entitled to exclusive use of any park or recreational facility, or part thereof, owned or operated by the city unless such person, group or organization shall first obtain a permit for such exclusive use from the director of parks and recreation or his designated representative. 
(Code 1966, § 21-3)  
Sec. 74-52. - Application; issuance or denial. 
(a)  Any person, group or organization applying for a park use permit shall complete an application and pay such fee which is on file in the office of the director of parks and recreation. The applicant shall be entitled to the issuance of such permit unless the director of parks and recreation or his designated representative shall affirmatively find the following: 
(1)  The park or recreational facility is to be used for an unlawful purpose; 
(2)  The time, place or manner of use of the facility is likely to cause substantial disturbance to persons occupying property adjoining the facility; 
(3)  The proposed use is likely to result in damage to city property; 
(4)  If the application for the permit is made such that there is not sufficient time to make the above determinations; or 
(5)  The failure to clean a facility to the satisfaction of the director of parks and recreation, or his designated representative, after a prior use of such facility, regardless of whether such prior use was under a permit provided for in this article or not. 
(b)  Any applicant denied a permit under this section may appeal such denial to the board of commissioners by filing a request for review with the city secretary within three days after written notice of such denial. The city secretary shall place such appeal on the agenda for the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners which meets the requisites of V.T.C.A., Government Code § 551.001 et seq., the Texas Open Meetings Act as a nonemergency item. The decision of the board of commissioners shall be final. If the permit is denied with insufficient time for it to be considered by the board of commissioners under the provisions of this subsection then, in that event, the permit shall be considered to have been denied by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1966, § 21-3.1(a), (b))  
Sec. 74-53. - Softball tournaments, permit procedures. 
(a)  Any person applying for a park use permit for the purposes of conducting a softball tournament shall complete an application and pay the fees which are on file in the office of the director of parks and recreation. 
(b)  The applicant for a softball tournament use permit shall execute an agreement with the director of parks and recreation for additional services and facilities required in the conduct of the tournament. All additional services and facilities and charges therefor will be approved by the city manager. The agreement shall provide that the parks and recreation department will reserve the right to cancel tournaments because of inclement weather or bad field conditions. The agreement shall provide general liability insurance as required by the city and shall include the city as an additional loss payee. 
(c)  All other provisions relating to park permits, as contained in this article, shall be met by an applicant or permit holder relating to any permit granted for the purposes of conducting any softball tournament under this article. 
(Code 1966, § 21-3.1(c))  
Sec. 74-54. - Contents. 
The park use permit when issued shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the person, group or organization issued such permit; 
(2)  The date and time for which such permit is effective; 
(3)  The activity for which the permit is issued; 
(4)  The facility or part of the facility which the permittee is authorized to use; and 
(5)  Such other conditions as the director of parks and recreation, or his designated representative, may deem appropriate to minimize disturbance to surrounding property, avoid traffic congestion, and to avoid destruction of city property. 
The items mentioned in this section are not the only items which the parks and recreation director, or his designated representative, may include in such permit but are the items which must be contained in such permit. 
(Code 1966, § 21-3.2)  
Sec. 74-55. - Political activities. 
Political organizations or persons, groups or organizations which desire a park use permit for a political activity must make their application to the city manager, who shall make the same findings regarding the issuance of such permit as would be made otherwise by the director of parks and recreation or his designated representative. If the city manager, in this regard, finds that the permit should be issued and there is no conflict in the use of the facility requested, then the city manager shall direct the director of parks and recreation to issue the permit requested. 
(Code 1966, § 21-3.3)  
Sec. 74-56. - Additional requirements. 
(a)  The director of parks and recreation, or his designated representative, may, in his discretion, require any applicant for a park use permit to post a bond in sufficient amount to indemnify the city against all loss, expense or special police protection, or expense of cleaning up the park or facility after the proposed activity. The posting of such bond, when requested, shall be a condition precedent to the issuance of the park use permit, but such bond shall not be for an amount in excess of the anticipated city expenditures with regard to the activity regarding which the bond is required. 
(b)  If the board of commissioners has approved the charging of a rent for the use of the facility for which the park use permit is requested, anyone wishing to reserve such facility must pay such rent in addition to the permit fee required in this article. 
(c)  Where special rates are provided for non-profit organizations, such non-profit status in the form of an IRS classification or similar document shall be provided along with the permit application. 
(d)  Internal use, such as that by other departments within the city organization, shall be exempt from such fees. 
(e)  Local, state or federal governmental agencies that apply for use permits for facilities where fees have been established may be granted special fee consideration upon the approval of the city manager. 
(f)  Where partnerships have been established for the betterment of the community, in cooperation with the city or the parks and recreation department, rental fees for facilities may be reduced or waived, with approval of the city manager. 
(g)  Administrative. Upon completion of an application, such application shall be reviewed by the director of parks and recreation or his designated representative as referenced in section 74-51. 
(h)  Fees shall be collected as per the city's cash handling policy. 
(Code 1966, § 21-3.4; Ord. No. 2007-44, § 1, 5-29-07)  
Secs. 74-57—74-74. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - RESTRICTIONS AND REGULATIONS[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Substantial evidence rule in effect in appeals from decisions or orders of city officers or employees, § 2-196. 
 
DIVISION 1. - PARKS PROPERTY REGULATION GENERALLY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1996-31, § II, adopted April 22, 1996, set out provisions designating §§ 74-76—74-83 as a new Div. 1, Parks Property Regulation Generally, in order to create Div. 2. 
 
Sec. 74-75. - Director authority for rules. 
(a)  Administration and supervision of the parks and recreation department shall be the responsibility of the director of parks and recreation and/or such other person as may be delegated or assigned such duties by the city manager. 
(b)  The director of parks and recreation is empowered with the day to day authority to regulate the uses and activities in the parks of the city consistent with this Code, and the reasonable enjoyment of the parks and recreation facilities by the citizens of the city. 
(c)  The director of parks and recreation is empowered with the authority to promulgate rules for the regulation of activities in the individual parks, subject to approval and revision by the city manager. 
(d)  No rule promulgated by the director of parks and recreation shall contradict or be inconsistent with any ordinance or regulation set forth in this Code. Any conflict between the promulgated rule and the city ordinance shall be resolved in favor of the city ordinance. 
(e)  To be enforceable, any rule regulating the use of any park or facility must be clearly and conspicuously set out on a sign in any park that is to be regulated by the rule. 
(f)  Violations of a park rule is hereby declared unlawful and shall be subject to the penalties and remedies as provided in section 74-84 and section 1-14. 
(Ord. No. 2010-42, § I, 7-12-10)  
Sec. 74-76. - Dogs prohibited during athletic events; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to take any dog, whether under a leash or allowed to run at large, upon any city-owned or controlled park or recreational facility during any time in which an organized athletic activity is being conducted at the park or recreational facility, whether or not such athletic activity is organized by the city or any other person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to take any dog and/or any other animal upon any city owned or controlled park or recreational facility without making adequate provision to ensure that said dog or animal is prevented from creating an unclean environment in said city owned or controlled park or recreational facility and/or without making adequate provision to restore said city owned or controlled park or recreational facility to a clean condition should said dog or animal create an unclean condition. 
(c)  It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section that the dog has been brought upon the premises of a park or recreational facility during the periods prohibited under this section as a legitimate accommodation of a person's handicap such that the same would be covered under the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(Ord. No. 1992-61, § I(21-4(a)), 7-13-92; Ord. No. 1997-70, § I, 8-11-97) 
Cross reference— Dogs generally, § 14-36 et seq.  
Sec. 74-77. - Alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
(a)  Athletic events. No person may possess or consume alcoholic beverages in a city-owned or controlled park or recreational facility during the time in which an organized athletic activity is being conducted at that park or recreational facility, whether or not such athletic activity is organized by the city or any other person. 
(b)  City parks. No person may possess or consume alcoholic beverages at the 29th Street and Zinnia Park at any time. 
(Code 1966, §§ 21-4, 21-4.1; Ord. No. 1992-61, § I(21-4(b)), 7-13-92; Ord. No. 2010-59, § I, 9-27-10) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-59, § I, adopted Sept. 27, 2010 changed the title of § 74-77 from alcoholic beverages prohibited during athletic events to alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6.  
Sec. 74-78. - Hours when entry or use prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any person to enter into or upon any of the parks and recreation facilities owned or operated by the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. the following morning, unless otherwise posted by appropriate lawful signs erected by the city. 
(b)  The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to the actual use of jogging trails, fitness facilities and parking areas in conjunction with such use. Further, the authorized use of sports facilities equipped with lights for their intended use, including but not limited to baseball and softball diamonds, tennis courts and swimming pools, when their use beyond the hours indicated in subsection (a) of this section is authorized in writing by the director of parks and recreation. The police department shall also be notified of such authorization. 
(c)  This section shall also include no parking in parking areas designed for such use by park or recreational facility patrons, but shall not include public roadways adjacent to the park or recreational facilities. 
(Code 1966, § 21-2)  
Sec. 74-79. - Parks considered public places. 
For the purposes of the enforcement of the state penal code relating to activities in the parks or recreational facilities owned or operated by the city, all such parks or recreational facilities are considered to be public places as that term relates to offenses in such places in the penal code. 
(Code 1966, § 21-5) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 94.  
Sec. 74-80. - Damage to equipment. 
No person shall intentionally or maliciously injure, damage, deface, mar or destroy any property owned, operated or maintained by the parks and recreation department of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 21-5.1)  
Sec. 74-81. - Vehicles on park property. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this section for anyone to operate, drive, station or move any vehicles onto or upon any park or recreational area owned, leased by, or operated by the parks and recreation department of the city, except on areas of such parks or recreational areas clearly marked, designated or defined as public roadways, streets, vehicle passageways or parking areas, except for city vehicles or vehicles of another local subdivision of this state, and then only to operate, repair, maintain or inspect property under such subdivision control. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this section for anyone to operate, drive, station or move any vehicles onto or upon any public roadways, streets, vehicle passageways or parking areas within any park or recreational area owned, leased by, or operated by the city or the parks and recreation department in such a manner as to violate any of the provisions of chapter 102, Traffic, of the Code of Ordinances, or any amendments to such chapter or the provisions of any state law relating to the operation of motor vehicles as incorporated within the provisions of such chapter 102. 
(c)  The speed limit in city parks, parking areas, and interior roadways of such parks is hereby set at 15 miles per hour, and it shall be a violation of this section to operate in any manner a vehicle in excess of such speed limit. 
(Code 1966, § 21-5.2) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 102; stopping, standing and parking, § 102-226 et seq.  
Sec. 74-82. - Swimming pool regulations. 
(a)  The parks and recreation department is hereby authorized to promulgate any and all rules and regulations needed for the operation of the municipal swimming pools, tennis facilities, and skate park. Such rules and regulations shall be posted in the city's official Internet website and at the entrance to the applicable facility, and shall take effect immediately upon posting at such facility. A copy of such rules and regulations shall be kept on file in both the offices of the parks and recreation department and the city secretary for public inspection. All future amendments to such rules and regulations shall take effect in the same manner as provided in this section and shall have the same force and effect as the original rules and regulations promulgated under the provisions of this section. A violation of any of the rules and regulations promulgated under this section shall constitute a violation of this article and is hereby declared to be unlawful. Further, any person violating this section or the rules and regulations promulgated under this section shall be subject to immediate removal from the premises upon which the violation occurs. 
(b)  The provisions of this article regarding the acquisition of a park use permit shall not apply to the municipal swimming pools, tennis facilities, or skate park. The restricted use of such facilities will be governed by the rules and regulations adopted pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1966, § 21-5.3; Ord. No. 2002-72, § 1, 10-28-02)  
Sec. 74-83. - McAllen Nature Center. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this section for any person to walk, stand or in any other manner traverse or use any portion of the McAllen Nature Center, except those areas designated as pedestrian walk-ways or trails. 
(b)  It shall be a violation of this section for any person to enter into or upon any part of the McAllen Nature Center at any time when said park is closed to the public. The city manager and/or the city manager's designee shall have authority to close the McAllen Nature Center to the public at any time and for such times as he deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1997-71, § II, 8-11-97; Ord. No. 2016-06, § I, 1-25-16) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2016-06, changed the name of § 74-83 as herein set out. Formerly entitled McAllen Botanical Gardens.  
Sec. 74-84. - Penalties and remedies. 
(a)  Any person, group or organization violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to summary ejection from the facility in which the violation occurs by either a member of the staff of the parks and recreation department or a police officer of the city. 
(b)  In addition to ejection, as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the violation of any of the provisions of this article is declared to be unlawful and a misdemeanor punishable as provided in section 1-14. 
(c)  The provisions in this section of the two remedies set out in this section shall not be deemed to preclude the use of any other remedy at law or equity to which the city may choose to resort to ensure that the provisions of this article are not violated. 
(Code 1966, § 21-6; Ord. No. 1997-71, § I, 8-11-97)  
Sec. 74-85. - McAllen War Memorial. 
(a)  The McAllen War Memorial, as constructed and operated by the Veterans' War Memorial Foundation of Texas, located at the southwest corner of 29th Street and Galveston is hereby declared a city public park facility for the duration of the use of such property for the war memorial purposes as set out in an agreement between the City of McAllen and the Veteran's War Memorial Foundation of Texas dated October 1, 1993; and as such, all regulations and restrictions generally applicable to parks as provided for in this article shall be applicable to the McAllen War Memorial in addition to all restrictions as set out herein. 
(b)  The McAllen War Memorial contains an area known as the walkways which are made up of 85,000 brick pavers which have been auctioned for purposes to raise money to fund the Memorial. Because of the uniqueness of such pavers, certain activities must be prohibited to maintain the aesthetic integrity of such area. Upon marking by the City of McAllen providing for such prohibition, possession, use or consumption of any food, gum, drinks, tobacco products, fuel products or solvents is hereby prohibited and it shall be unlawful for any person to use, possess or consume any of such products on the marked pavers. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motorized vehicle upon walkway areas marked as exclusive walkway areas on the McAllen War Memorial property, save and except vehicles driven for official business and with the specific permission of the president of the Veteran's War Memorial Foundation of Texas or the City Manager of the City of McAllen. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, § 1, 6-12-00)  
Secs. 74-86—74-89. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - AFTER-SCHOOL RECREATION PROGRAMS 
 
Sec. 74-90. - Minimum standards for after-school recreation programs. 
The parks and recreation department is hereby authorized to provide for an after-school recreation program from time to time provided budgeted funds are otherwise made available therefore. Any of such programs shall be operated under the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Staff requirements: 
a.  The after-school recreation program shall maintain a minimum staffing ratio of one staff member to every 25 participants, based on the daily average attendance at the site. Exceptions in staffing levels shall be allowed in the case of unforeseen absences of staff members. 
b.  Each staff member employed by the City of McAllen shall meet the employment eligibility requirements as set forth in the parks and recreation department supervised playgrounds and gyms operations manual as promulgated by the director of parks and recreation. These requirements shall be reviewed and updated by the parks and recreation department director on an annual basis. 
c.  Each after-school recreation program site shall have a minimum of one staff member who is certified in first aid and cardio pulmonary resuscitation by the American Red Cross or other recognized agency. 
(2)  Every program site shall have, at a minimum, the following type facilities: 
a.  A gathering room or rooms capable of containing the entire number of participants enrolled at the site and subject to occupancy level set by the fire marshal. 
b.  Separate restrooms for boys and girls, which are sufficiently close to each other to be monitored by one staff member. 
c.  Each site shall maintain a first aid kit containing a minimum of supplies as approved by the city health advisor. 
d.  The parks and recreation director is authorized to close the facility to access to the public during such times as the program is in session. 
(3)  Program requirements: 
a.  The program shall be monitored by the parks and recreation director or his designated representative. The director or his designated representative shall make every effort to visit each site a minimum of once a week. 
b.  Each after-school recreation program site supervisor shall submit biweekly activity and attendance reports to the director of parks and recreation. 
c.  Each site supervisor shall submit any and all accident reports to the parks and recreation department and any other reports deemed necessary by the director of parks and recreation or his designated representative. 
d.  All parents or guardians shall be advised, at the time the participant is registered, that the program is not a day care program, licensed by the State of Texas or any other agency. 
e.  Participants must be of elementary age (ages five to 13). 
(Ord. No. 1996-31, § II, 4-22-96; Ord. No. 1997-25, § I, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 1998-41, § I, 4-15-98; Ord. No. 2002-09, § 1, 1-28-02; Ord. No. 2003-11, § 1, 1-27-03; Ord. No. 2004-33, § 1, 4-12-04; Ord. No. 2005-51, § 1, 5-9-05; Ord. No. 2007-82, § 1, 10-8-07)  
Secs. 74-91—74-94. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CITY-RELATED YOUTH ATHLETIC PROGRAMS 
 
Sec. 74-95. - Certification for coaches on city-related youth athletic programs required. 
All managers or head coaches of any team participating in an organized youth sports program, which program is either held in a city-owned facility or conducted or sponsored by an entity receiving city funds, shall be certified by the National Youth Sports Coaches Association (NYSCA). The director of parks and recreation is hereby authorized and directed to establish a certification program, including the authority to charge and collect reasonable fees for services relating thereto. 
(Code 1966, § 21-8; Ord. No. 2000-67, § 1, 8-28-00) 
Note— Formerly § 74-1.  
Secs. 74-96—74-105. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - GOLF COURSE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference— Substantial evidence rule in effect in appeals from decisions or orders of city officers or employees, § 2-196; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 94. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 74-106. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Golf course means the Palmview Municipal Golf Course and the entire premises thereof, including but not limited to the clubhouse, restaurant, pro shop, cart shed and golf course itself, and all other parts or portions thereof. 
Lessee means any person or organization of whatever nature that uses the golf course premises, facilities or equipment. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 74-107. - Director of golf. 
The administrator in charge of the golf course shall be the director of golf, who shall be employed and discharged by the city manager, subject to the approval of the board of commissioners. The terms, conditions and duties of the director of golf's employment shall be prescribed by the city manager. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-2; Ord. No. 2016-07, § I, 1-25-16)  
Sec. 74-108. - Use fees. 
The golf course manager is hereby authorized to collect fees for the use of all golf course facilities and equipment, such fees to be set from time to time upon the recommendation of the golf course advisory board by minute order of the board of commissioners. All fees charged for the use of facilities or equipment under this section shall be due and payable to the city. The free use of all facilities and equipment of the golf course is hereby prohibited to any individual or group or to any employee or officer of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-3)  
Sec. 74-109. - Sale of merchandise; concessions. 
(a)  Only the city and its assigns may sell merchandise at the golf course. The use of any portion of the golf course by any individual, group, firm or corporation other than the city for the purpose of selling merchandise is hereby prohibited without the written consent of the manager of the golf course. Sale of merchandise by tax-exempt/nonprofit charitable organizations or civic groups is hereby excepted from such prohibition and shall be permitted upon the approval of the golf course manager. 
(b)  Only the city and its assigns shall have the right to operate concessions for the sale of food, drinks (including alcoholic beverages), programs, novelties, souvenirs, etc. Sale of concessions by tax-exempt charitable organizations and civic groups are hereby exempted from such prohibition and shall be permitted upon the approval of the golf course manager. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-4)  
Sec. 74-110. - Damaging golf course property. 
It is unlawful for any person to intentionally cut, mutilate, deface, defoliate, or otherwise destroy or cause injury, in whole or in part, to any part or portion of the golf course premises, facilities or equipment. It is unlawful for any person to willfully or wantonly mark or deface or in any way injure the golf course facilities or any part thereof, or any fixtures therein or appertaining thereto. A violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-7)  
Sec. 74-111. - Use of golf course property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into, pass through, or congregate with other persons on the golf course property at a time, whether night or day, when such property is closed to the general public. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into, pass through, or congregate with other persons on golf course property for any other purpose than to participate in an authorized use of the golf course during the hours the golf course is open for business. 
(c)  The provisions of this section do not apply to agents, representatives, licensees or employees of the city; provided, however, that such persons are engaged in the performance of their duties. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to play golf using driving-range golf balls which are identified as such by a clearly marked colored or black circle circumventing the golf ball. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to disregard any order issued by the golf course marshal relating to the means or manner of play at the golf course. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a golf cart upon any area except designated golf cart areas except as authorized by the golf course manager. 
(g)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(Code 1966, § 21-1)  
Sec. 74-112. - Violation and penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate, participate or acquiesce in the violation of any of the provisions of this article or who shall fail to comply therewith or with any requirements thereof, shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(b)  The penalty provided in subsection (a) of this section should not be construed as exclusive, and the city hereby provides that any other remedy available to it in the enforcement of this article, in law or in equity, is not intended to be, and is not, foreclosed by the provision of such penalty. 
(c)  The penalties prescribed in subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not preclude a civil action for monetary damages or other relief brought by the city against a person violating this article or against the parent, guardian, managing conservator, possessory conservator, or other person having the duty of control or reasonable discipline of a child under V.T.C.A., Family Code §§ 33.01—33.03, where such child has violated this article. 
(d)  Any violation of this article or any other rule established by the golf course manager may result in a temporary or permanent forfeiture of the right to play golf at the golf course at the direction of the golf course manager. 
(Code 1966, §§ 20¾-8, 20¾-9)  
Secs. 74-113—74-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADVISORY BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference— Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-76 et seq.; procedure for appointment and terms and qualifications of board members, § 2-77; substantial evidence rule in effect regarding appeals from decisions of boards, commissions and committees, § 2-82. 
 
Sec. 74-126. - Definition. 
Whenever used in this article, the term "advisory board" shall mean the golf course advisory board created by section 74-127. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-21) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 74-127. - Created. 
There is hereby created and established a golf course advisory board for the city. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-22)  
Sec. 74-128. - Composition; appointment, terms, etc. 
The advisory board shall be composed of seven members who shall be appointed and serve pursuant to sections 2-76 through 2-82. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-23; Ord. No. 2011-20, § I, 4-11-11)  
Sec. 74-129. - Ex officio members. 
The board of commissioners may designate such officer or commissioner of the city as it sees fit to serve as an ex officio member of the advisory board, without voting privilege, who shall act in an advisory capacity only. The golf course manager shall also be an ex officio member of the advisory board, without voting privilege. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-24)  
Sec. 74-130. - Compensation. 
No salary or compensation shall be paid to the members of the advisory board for their services. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-25)  
Sec. 74-131. - Regular meetings. 
The advisory board shall meet once a month in regular session, the time and place to be set by the advisory board, to consider all matters pertaining to the business, operation and use to be made of the golf course and all facilities and equipment pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-28)  
Sec. 74-132. - Special meetings. 
The golf course manager or chairman of the advisory board shall have the right to call such special meetings of the advisory board as may be necessary. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-29)  
Sec. 74-133. - Quorum. 
Four of the regular voting members of the advisory board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-27; Ord. No. 2011-20, § II, 4-11-11)  
Sec. 74-134. - General duties. 
The advisory board shall work in close cooperation with the golf course manager and shall keep informed as to all aspects of the golf course operations, including, but not limited to, management, regulations, rules, purposes, maintenance, policies and ordinances established by the board of commissioners, and it shall stimulate use of the golf course facilities and equipment. It shall, from time to time, transmit information, reports, suggestions, recommendations and advice to the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-30)  
Sec. 74-135. - Recommendations to board of commissioners. 
Any and all recommendations made by the advisory board to the board of commissioners shall be by a majority of a quorum. A minority of the advisory board members shall have a right to make a minority recommendation in writing to the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-31)  
Sec. 74-136. - Subcommittees. 
The advisory board is authorized to establish subcommittees for specific operational functions, with a chairman for each subcommittee. 
(Code 1966, § 20¾-32)  
Secs. 74-137—74-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - QUINTA MAZATLAN  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 74-151. - Management and operation. 
Quinta Mazatlan shall be under the management and oversight of the parks and recreation department. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05)  
Sec. 74-152. - Manager. 
The administrator in charge of Quinta shall be the Quinta Mazatlan Manager. The director of parks and recreation or his designee shall serve as the Quinta Mazatlan Manager in the absence of the manager. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05)  
Sec. 74-153. - Use fees. 
The Quinta Mazatlan Manager is responsible for the collection of the fees due the city for the use of all Quinta facilities and equipment. The fees for use of the Quinta Mazatlan facilities will be set from time to time by minute order of the board of commissioners upon the recommendation of Friends of Quinta Mazatlan, Inc. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05; Ord. No. 2016-25, § I, 5-9-16)  
Sec. 74-154. - Sale of merchandise; concessions. 
(a)  The use of any portion of Quinta Mazatlan by any for profit individual, group, firm or corporation for the purpose of selling merchandise is generally not allowed but exceptions may be given in writing by the manager as part of the lease agreement where such use is only ancillary to the primary use of the facility. Sale of merchandise by tax-exempt/nonprofit charitable organizations or civic groups may be permitted upon the written approval of the manager. 
(b)  Only the city and its assigns shall have the right to operate concessions for the sale of food, drinks (including alcoholic beverages), programs, novelties, and souvenirs. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05)  
Sec. 74-155. - Damaging Quinta Mazatlan property. 
It is unlawful for any person to intentionally cut, mutilate, mark, deface, defoliate, or otherwise destroy or cause injury, in whole or in part, to any part or portion of the Quinta Mazatlan premises, facilities or equipment. A violation of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-14. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05)  
Sec. 74-156. - Use of Quinta Mazatlan. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into, pass through, or congregate on the Quinta property at a time, whether night or day, when such property is closed to the general public. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into, pass through, or congregate on the property for any other purpose than to participate in an authorized use of Quinta Mazatlan during the hours Quinta is open for business. 
(c)  It shall unlawful for any person to walk, stand or in any other manner traverse or use any portion of the wooded area, except those areas designated as pedestrian walkways or trails. 
(d)  The provisions of this section do not apply to agents, representatives, licensees or employees of the city; provided, however, that such persons are engaged in the performance of their duties. 
(e)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be subject to a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14. 
(f)  Any person, group or organization violating any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to summary ejection by either a member of the staff of the parks and recreation department or a police officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05)  
Secs. 74-157—74-175. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADVISORY BOARD 
 
Sec. 74-176. - Definition. 
Whenever used in this article, the term "advisory board" shall mean Friends of Quinta Mazatlan, Inc. created by section 74-177. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05; Ord. No. 2016-25, § I, 5-9-16)  
Sec. 74-177. - Created. 
At the direction of the city commission, the Friends of Quinta Mazatlan, Inc., a Texas non-profit corporation, was created and filed with the Texas Secretary of State's Office. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05; Ord. No. 2016-25, § I, 5-9-16)  
Sec. 74-178. - Composition; appointment, terms, etc. 
(a) The advisory board shall not be less than seven and not more than 14. Friends of Quinta Mazatlan, Inc., may recruit and recommend appointments to the board of commissioners. The mayor and each commissioner shall make two appointments to the board as otherwise provided under chapter 2, article III of this Code. 
(b) The provisions of chapter 2 article III Boards, Committees and Commissions shall be applicable to Friends of Quinta Mazatlan, Inc. and such board shall be designated as a board under section 2-76. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05; Ord. No. 2010-16, § I, 3-8-10; Ord. No. 2016-25, § I, 5-9-16)  
Sec. 74-179. - Ex-officio members. 
The board of commissioners may designate such officer or commissioner of the city as it sees fit to serve as an ex officio member of the advisory board, without voting privilege, which shall act in an advisory capacity only. The McAllen Convention Center Director and the Quinta Mazatlan Manager shall also be ex-officio members of the advisory board, without voting privilege. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05; Ord. No. 2016-25, § I, 5-9-16)  
Sec. 74-180. - Special meetings. 
The Quinta Mazatlan Manager or chairman of the advisory board shall have the right to call such special meetings of the advisory board as may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05)  
Sec. 74-181. - Quorum. 
A simple (half plus one) majority of the current members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business of any meeting of the board. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05)  
Sec. 74-182. - General duties. 
The advisory board shall work in close cooperation with the Quinta Mazatlan Manager and shall keep informed as to all aspects of Quinta's mission as follows: 
(1)  Provision of opportunities for recreational and environmental learning activities that will promote an appreciation of birds and the natural environment. 
(2)  Encouragement of wildlife habitat stewardship and restoration. 
(3)  Demonstration of the benefits of nature tourism. 
(4)  Provide a meeting and special event venue for the city. 
The advisory board shall work in close cooperation with the Quinta Mazatlan Manager and shall keep informed as to all aspects of Quinta's operations, including, but not limited to, management, regulations, rules, purposes, maintenance, policies and ordinances established by the board of commissioners. It shall, from time to time, transmit information, reports, suggestions, recommendations and advice to the board of commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 2005-66, § 1, 8-22-05)  
Secs. 74-183—74-200. - Reserved.  
Chapter 78 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Vehicles used in vending, § 102-153; requirement for conditional use for produce stands, § 138-118. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 78-1. - Outdoor display and sale of merchandise prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to display and sell any new or used goods or materials, including farm products or agricultural products in their natural state, outdoors on any open or unimproved lot or parcel or on any open area of a lot or parcel with a structure unless excepted or permitted by this chapter. 
(Code 1966, § 19-21; Ord. No. 1998-82, § 1, 8-24-98)  
Sec. 78-2. - Exceptions. 
The outdoor display and sale of merchandise on an open or unimproved lot or open area of a lot or parcel with a structure is only allowed in the following situations: 
(1)  On the premises or a lot or parcel in which a retail business is operated in a structure and where the display or sale of merchandise is related to the general operations of such business. The outdoor display and sale of merchandise shall not result in an elimination, temporarily or permanently, of the number of off-street parking ordinance. Such structure must comply with all building requirements and other requirements mandated by this Code. 
(2)  Temporary seasonal display and sales of merchandise, to-wit: 
a.  Fall pumpkins; 
b.  Christmas trees; 
c.  Easter confetti eggs (cascarones); 
d.  Flowers and floral bouquets. 
Except for subsection 2(d), such display or sale shall be limited to six weeks and the seller must apply for and receive a permit issued under the provision of this article. 
(3)  For subsection (2)(d) hereinabove, the display or sale shall be limited to fourteen days before certain holidays, namely: 
a.  Mother's Day (being the second Sunday in May); 
b.  Father's Day (being the third Sunday in June); 
c.  Valentine's Day (being the fourteenth calendar day of February). 
The seller still must apply for and receive a permit issued under the provision of this article. 
(4)  The display or sale of agricultural products on the site from which those products were actually harvested or at a farmers' market location for which a conditional use permit has been obtained and maintained under this Code. 
(5)  The display and sale of merchandise related to a garage sale provided that the display is limited to the address location and duration of the garage sale permit otherwise issued under the provisions of this Code. 
(6)  The display and sale of merchandise at a flea market location for which a conditional use permit has been obtained and maintained under this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1998-82, § 2, 8-24-98; Ord. No. 2019-38, § I, 7-8-19)  
Sec. 78-3. - Permit requirements. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit required by this section 78-2 subsections (2) and (3), shall file a written application, with the city planning director at least ten days prior to the beginning date of the contemplated display or sale of goods. Such application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Full name, address and location of the principal office or place of business of the applicant, and if the applicant is a partnership or firm or joint venture, the full names and addresses of the authorized officers signing the application therefor. If the applicant is a corporation, the applicant shall state the state or county of the location and the names and addresses of its authorized officers. 
(2)  The location of the open air display and sale, including the street address and lot or block number thereof. If the applicant is not the owner of such location, then the applicant shall also provide the lease, license or other evidence of permission of the owner to occupy the premises for the purposes of the application. 
(3)  If the applicant also requires a license for itinerant vendors under the provisions of article II hereof, then the requirements for application for itinerant vendors may be merged with the application for an open-air permit and the same may be issued by either the city secretary or city planning department under the procedures as promulgated by the city manager therefor. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued except under the following conditions: 
(1)  The location of the premises for which a permit is granted shall be in the proper zoned district for such type of commercial activity. 
(2)  The location shall contain an authorized curb cut for access from a public street. 
(3)  The location shall have sufficient paved parking for the purposes of the activity on the premises. 
(4)  The premises shall have access to permanent restroom facilities on-site. 
(5)  The premises shall have access to on-site garbage and trash dumpster provided by the city or other licensed garbage and trash collection entity under the city regulations. 
(6)  The maximum time for which a permit may be issued shall be for a period not to exceed six weeks. 
(7)  The applicant shall pay an application fee of $100.00 for the purposes of covering the administrative costs for processing such application. 
(8)  The premises shall comply with fire department requirements. 
(Ord. No. 1998-82, § 2, 8-24-98; Ord. No. 1999-38, § 1, 4-12-99; Ord. No. 2016-58, § IX, 9-26-16)  
Sec. 78-4. - Planning director to issue permit. 
The planning director or his/her designee, shall issue to any applicant applying therefor, who has complied with all the requirements of this article, a permit authorizing the open-air displaying and sale of goods within the city. Such permit is not transferable and shall only be applicable to the person or entity applying and receiving such permit. 
(Ord. No. 1998-82, § 2, 8-24-98)  
Sec. 78-5. - Display of permit required. 
Such permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises where the open-air permitted activity is authorized and shall remain so displayed so long as any goods or merchandise are displayed and sold under the authority of such permit. 
(Ord. No. 1998-82, § 2, 8-24-98)  
Sec. 78-6. - Additional license required. 
The granting of a permit as provided for in this division shall not excuse any person from applying for and receiving any other license or permit required by the City of McAllen or State of Texas or any other regulatory authority having jurisdiction therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1998-82, § 2, 8-24-98)  
Sec. 78-7. - Appeal of a decision for failure to issue a license. 
(a)  Provided that all the information is furnished by the applicant, the planning director or his or her designee shall issue a permit or deny the issuance of a permit within ten business days after the date of filing an application in compliance with the requirements therefor. Should the director of planning refuse to issue the permit, the director of planning shall issue the reasons for such refusal. 
(b)  Any applicant who has been refused a permit by the planning director, shall have the right to appeal the decision to the city manager by filing a written notice of appeal to the city manager's officer's officer within ten business days from the date of the receipt of the denial of the permit by the planning director. The city manager shall issue a decision within ten business days from the date on appeal as perfected by the applicant. The city manager shall issue a decision in writing as to whether or not the permit should be issued or the decision of the planning director should be upheld and shall give the reasons therefor. Such notice of the decision of the city manager shall be mailed to the applicant within five business days after the decision of the city manager is established. The city manager is authorized and directed to establish procedures relating to the consideration of the denial of a permit. 
(Ord. No. 1998-82, § 2, 8-24-98)  
Secs. 78-8—78-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ITINERANT VENDORS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 78-26. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Itinerant vendor means and includes and shall be construed to mean and include all persons, firms and corporations, as well as their agents and employees, who engage in the temporary or transient business in the city of exposing or offering to expose plates or films to make negatives for the making of pictures or photographs, or who engage in the temporary or transient business in the city of selling or offering for sale any goods or merchandise, or exhibiting for sale or exhibiting goods or merchandise for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, or who, for the purpose of carrying on such business or conducting such exhibits thereof, either hire, rent, lease or occupy any room or space in any building, structure, other enclosure, vacant lot or any other property whatever in the city, in, through, or from which any goods or merchandise may be sold, offered for sale, exhibited for sale or exhibited for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof. The term "itinerant vendor," as defined in this section, shall not include or be construed to include any person engaged in interstate commerce nor any person upon whom the provisions of this article would impose a direct and unlawful burden on interstate commerce. 
Temporary means and shall be construed to mean any business transacted or conducted in the city for which firm arrangements have not been made for the hire, rental or lease of premises in or upon which such business is to be operated or conducted for a period of at least 120 days. 
Transient means any such business of any itinerant vendor as may be operated or conducted by persons, firms or corporations, or by their agents or employees, who reside away from the city or who have fixed places of business in places other than the city, or who move stocks of goods or merchandise or samples thereof into the city with the purpose or intention of removing them or the unsold portion thereof away from the city before the expiration of 120 days. 
(Code 1966, § 22-11) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 78-27. - Exemptions from article. 
This article is not and shall not be held to be applicable to: 
(1)  Ordinary commercial travelers who sell or exhibit for sale goods or merchandise to parties engaged in the business of buying and selling and dealing in goods or merchandise. 
(2)  Vendors of farm produce, poultry, stock, or agricultural products in their natural state. 
(3)  Sales of goods or merchandise donated by the owners thereof, the proceeds whereof are to be applied to any charitable or philanthropic purpose. 
(Code 1966, § 22-12)  
Sec. 78-28. - Enforcement of article. 
The duly constituted authorities of the city, including the police department, city secretary and others having the duty of enforcing the ordinances of the city, shall enforce the provisions of this article and allow no itinerant vendor to conduct his business without full compliance with the terms of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 22-13)  
Secs. 78-29—78-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Substantial evidence rule in effect in appeals from decisions or orders of city officers or employees, § 2-196. 
 
Sec. 78-41. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any itinerant vendor, or for any person as agent, employee or servant of any itinerant vendor, to sell, or offer or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, any goods, wares, merchandise, or other personal property in the city, without having an unexpired license issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1966, § 22-19)  
Sec. 78-42. - Application. 
Any person desiring a license required by this division shall file a written application, verified by affidavit as to the truthfulness of its contents, with the city secretary at least ten days prior to the beginning date of the contemplated sale or exhibit to be held in the city. Such application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full name, address and location of the principal office or place of business of the applicant and, if the applicant is a partnership, firm or joint adventure, the full names and addresses of all members thereof, and if a corporation, the state or county chartering it and the names and addresses of its officers. 
(2)  The kind and character of goods, wares, merchandise or other personal property to be sold or offered or exhibited for sale or exhibited for the purpose of taking orders for sale in the city. 
(3)  In cases where such business is not to be conducted by the applicant in person, the name and legal relationship to the applicant of the person who is to be present in the city in charge and control of such business. 
(4)  The location and description of the premises or space in or upon which such transient or temporary business is proposed to be conducted, the ownership of such premises, and the terms of any parole arrangement that may have been made for the use of such premises. If a written lease of such premises has been made, the application shall so state and a copy of such written lease, verified by affidavit as to the truth of its contents, shall be filed with the application. 
(5)  If the applicant is a corporation, it shall file with its application a certified copy of its charter, and if it is not incorporated under the laws of this state, a certified copy of its present permit to do business in the state shall accompany the application. 
(Code 1966, § 22-20)  
Sec. 78-43. - Bond required of applicant. 
Each applicant for a license under this division shall furnish and deliver to the city secretary, prior to issuance of the license, a bond in the amount of $2,000.00, with the itinerant vendor in whose behalf such application is made as principal and two or more good and sufficient individual sureties satisfactory to the city secretary, such sureties to be residents of this county, or one corporate surety which shall have authorized agents in this county. Such bond shall be payable at McAllen, Hidalgo County, Texas, to the mayor of the city, and his successors in office for the benefit of any person legally entitled to recover thereon, and conditioned that the parties thereto will pay all damages to any person caused by or arising from or growing out of any fraudulent or wrongful or illegal act of such itinerant vendor in the conduct of such business in the city. Such bond shall provide that any person for whose benefit the bond is made may sue thereon in his own right without joining the mayor or the city, but successive recoveries may be had thereon to the full extent of the amount therein named and prescribed in this section, and that it shall remain in full force and effect for the entire duration of the license to secure which it is furnished, plus any renewals thereof, and for two years thereafter. 
(Code 1966, § 22-21)  
Sec. 78-44. - Fee. 
The fee for a license required by this division shall be $100.00. The fee shall be paid prior to the issuance of the license. Such fee shall be compensated to the city for the services required of it in connection with such license and to enable the city to partially defray the expense of enforcing the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 22-22; Ord. No. 2002-57, § 1, 9-11-02)  
Sec. 78-45. - Issuance. 
The city secretary shall issue to any itinerant vendor applying therefor, who has complied with all the requirements of this division, a license authorizing such applicant, as an itinerant vendor, to sell, offer for sale, or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, in the city, his goods or merchandise. 
(Code 1966, § 22-23)  
Sec. 78-46. - Not transferable; authorizes only one person to conduct business. 
The license provided for in this division shall not be transferable nor give authority to more than one person to conduct a business as an itinerant vendor, but any person having obtained such license may have the assistance of one or more persons in conducting such business. 
(Code 1966, § 22-24)  
Sec. 78-47. - Term. 
A license issued under this division shall continue in force so long as the sale or exhibit authorized thereby is continuously held in the city, or until the expiration date thereof, but in no event shall it continue more than 120 days from its issuance. 
(Code 1966, § 22-25)  
Sec. 78-48. - Display. 
A license issued under this division shall be prominently displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises where the sale or exhibit authorized thereby is being conducted and shall remain so displayed so long as any goods or merchandise are being so sold or exhibited. 
(Code 1966, § 22-26)  
Chapter 82 - PERSONNEL[1]
