This article shall be effective within the geographical limits of the city, including any areas subsequently annexed by the city. As to any person holding a franchise agreement or other contract with the city as of the effective date of this article that authorizes the use of the city's public rights-of-way, this chapter shall only be effective to such person to the extent that it does not conflict with said franchise or other contractual agreement. This article shall not apply to the McAllen Public Utilities with respect to the requirements for any fees or costs required herein nor as to any civil or criminal penalties imposed herein nor the obligation to obtain any permit required herein, it being the intent of this article that the McAllen Public Utilities abide by and comply with all of the technical and construction standards contained herein. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02)  
Sec. 94-29. - Definitions. 
[As used in this article, the following words shall have the following meaning:] 
Facility or facilities means any type of tangible item placed in the right-of-way. 
Public utility means any water, sewer, gas, electric, telephone, telegraph, telecommunication, cable television or similar type facility. 
Street or public way or public right-of-way or public rights-of-way or rights-of-way or right-of-way means the surface of, and the space above and below a public street, road, highway, freeway, land, path, public way or place, alley, court, boulevard, parkway, drive, or other easement now or hereafter held by or under the control of the city, to which the city holds the property rights in regard to the use for utilities, excluding easements not intended for public works or public utility facilities but shall not include property of city which is not a dedicated public right-of-way, street, highway, or alley. Neither the inclusion of this definition nor the provisions hereof shall be construed to grant any right or privilege to utilize or occupy the city rights-of-way absent an expressed agreement of the city or by authority expressly granted by state law, 
User means any person or entity of any type that places or seeks to place, or uses, facilities of any type in the city's public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02)  
Sec. 94-30. - Reserved.  
Sec. 94-31. - Civil penalties. 
(a)  If the city has reason to believe that a user is in violation of this article, the city should notify the user in writing of the violation setting forth the nature of the violation. Within a reasonable time, but not less than ten calendar days of receipt of such notice, the user shall respond in writing to provide explanation or documentation to support the user's position that either (1) the violation did not occur; or, (2) that the user has cured or is taking reasonable steps to cure the violation in an appropriate and timely manner. If the user fails to comply with this provision, the penalties set out in this article may be imposed and the provisions of section 90-40 of this chapter may be applied. In addition, if in the reasonable judgment of city, a violation of this article is ongoing and such violation represents an immediate threat to the health, safety, and/or welfare of the citizens or an imminent danger which might result in the loss of property, the city may issue an immediate stop work and/or other appropriate order and/or take other appropriate action to remedy such situation. 
(b)  Civil penalties may be imposed for the violation of any provision of this chapter, as follows: 
(1)  Up to $1,000.00 for each violation, and each day of a continuing violation may be considered a new violation; and/or 
(2)  If applicable, default and revocation of any or all permits granted to allow work in the rights-of-way, subject to the procedural guidelines noted in this chapter and any agreement which applies to the right-of-way user, and further subject to any limitations imposed by federal or state law. 
(c)  In imposing the penalties and the amount, the city may weigh all applicable factors, such as damages caused by the violation, reasons for the violation, the seriousness of the violation, and all other factors. 
(d)  Monetary civil penalties may be imposed in the manner prescribed by either local or state law. 
(e)  In addition, the city commission may order specific performance of any actions required by this chapter or required by a franchise, license or permit, including the permit authorizing work to be performed in the right-of-way, or any other agreement or authorization. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02)  
Sec. 94-32. - Right-of-way construction. 
(a)  No person shall commence or continue with the construction, installation or operation of facilities in, on, under or above the rights-of-way in the city except as provided by the ordinances of the city and the directives of the engineering department. Further, no person shall continue with the operation of facilities in, on, under or above the rights-of-way if that person lacks the necessary authority from the city or state or federal law. 
(b)  No person shall erect, install, construct, repair, replace or maintain its facilities in such a fashion as to unduly burden the present or future use of the streets or public ways. If city, in its reasonable judgment, determines that any portion of a facility is an undue burden, the person who installed same, at their expense, shall modify its facilities or take such other actions as city may determine is in the public interest to remove or alleviate the burden, within a reasonable time period. A decision by the city pursuant to this section is subject to the appeal process set out in section 94-45 of this chapter. 
(c)  The cost of the installation, construction, operation, or removal of facilities shall be borne by the person installing and/or using same. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02)  
Sec. 94-33. - Registration and construction permits. 
(a)  Registration certificate. In order to protect the public health, safety and welfare, all public utility installation constructors, including public utility companies and all other users using or desiring to use the rights-of-way of city must register with the city. Registration and permits will be issued in the name of the person who will own the facilities. 
Registration shall include: 
(1)  The name of the ultimate user of the right-of-way; 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the person or persons who will be contact person(s) for the installer and owner of the public utility facility user; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of any contractor or subcontractor who will be working in the right-of-way on behalf of the user, to the extent such information is known and available at the time of registration and, if not known at that time, said information shall be provided as soon as practical following registration; 
(4)  The name(s) and telephone number of an emergency contact who shall be available 24 hours a day. 
(b)  Construction permits. 
(1)  No person, entity, user or proposed user shall perform any construction or installation of facilities in the rights-of-way without first obtaining a construction permit, except as provided herein, if such construction or installation will require the breaking of pavement and/or the closure of a traffic lane for a period of time greater than four hours. For purposes of this subsection, the phrase "construction or installation of facilities" does not include the installation of facilities necessary to initiate service to a customer's property or the repair or maintenance of existing facilities, unless such repair or maintenance requires the breaking of pavement or the closure of a traffic lane for a period of time greater than four hours. 
a.  Emergency responses related to the repair or replacement of existing facilities or the restoration of existing utility service to customers that would otherwise require a permit but for the emergency nature of that work may be undertaken without first obtaining a permit; however, the city's engineering department should be notified, verbally or in writing, as soon as possible after receipt of notice of the emergency, additionally, the user should provide a reasonably detailed description of the work performed in the right-of-way before the close of business the next business day following any construction related to an emergency response, such description to include a reasonably detailed description of the work performed in the right-of-way. An updated map of any facilities that were moved, repaired or constructed shall be submitted to the city within 60 days following such emergency work. 
(2)  The permit shall state to whom it is issued, location of work, location of facilities, and estimated dates and times work is to take place and any other special, reasonable conditions set out by the city engineer or his/her designee. 
(3)  The person requesting a permit will provide the city engineer or his/her designee with the following: 
a.  The proposed, approximate location and route of all facilities to be constructed or installed and the applicant's plan for right-of-way construction; 
b.  Engineering plans which will be on a scale acceptable to the city engineering department, but in no event larger than one inch equals 50 feet unless otherwise approved by the engineering department; 
c.  Description of the location of all right-of-way and utility easements which applicant plans to use; 
d.  Description of all known existing public utilities in the area of applicant's proposed route; 
e.  Detail of what applicant proposes to install, such as pipe size, number of interducts, valves, etc.; 
f.  Detail of plans to remove and replace asphalt, concrete in street to City of McAllen standards; 
g.  Drawings of any bores, trenches, handholes, manholes, switch gear, transformers, pedestals, etc., including depth; 
h.  Handhole and/or manhole typical of type of manholes and/or handholes applicant plans to use or access; 
i.  Complete legend of drawings submitted by applicant which may be provided by reference to previously submitted documents; 
j.  Four sets of engineering plans; 
k.  If known at the time application is made, and if not, within a reasonable time thereafter and not later than 24 hours prior to the start of construction, the name, address and telephone numbers of the contractor who will perform the actual construction, including the name and telephone number of an individual with the contractor who will be available at all times during construction; provided, however, that such information will not be necessary to make the application administratively complete. 
l.  The construction and installation methods to be employed for the protection of existing structures, fixtures, and facilities within or adjacent to the right-of-way, and the estimated dates and times work will occur, all of which (methods, dates, times, etc.) are subject to approval of the city engineer or his/her designee; and 
m.  Proof of insurance or net worth as required. 
n.  A nonrefundable application fee of $350.00, unless the applicant has an existing franchise or other contractual agreement that establishes the fee to be paid for the use of the city's rights-of-way or is otherwise exempt from the payment of such fee by applicable law. The permit application must also be signed by a representative of the owner of the facilities to be constructed. 
Upon the receipt of all necessary information and necessary documentation the city engineer may issue the permit; provided, however, the city specifically reserves the right to deny access to any user where, in the judgment of the city, the use or proposed use of the rights-of-way are inconsistent with and/or unreasonably impair the public use of the rights-of-way. In the event that the city engineer denies any permit, the applicant will be informed of the basis for such denial and, if applicable, the conditions under which the work might be permitted. 
(4)  All construction and installation in the right-of-way shall be in accordance with the permit for the facilities. The city engineer or his/her designee shall be provided access to the work and to such further information as he or she may reasonably require to ensure compliance with the permit. 
(5)  A copy of the construction permit and approved engineering plans shall be maintained at the construction site and made available for inspection by the city engineer or his/her designee at all times when construction or installation work is occurring. 
(6)  All construction or installation work authorized by permit must be completed in the time specified in the construction permit. If the work cannot be completed in the specified time periods, the permittee may request an extension from the city engineer or his/her designee. The request for extension should be submitted to the city engineer prior to the expiration of the specified time period and, if such extension is so requested, construction or installation work authorized by the initial permit may be continued during the time period that the city engineer is considering the request for an extension. 
(7)  Insurance and bonds. 
a.  An applicant must provide proof of liability insurance in the amount of $1,000,000.00 as approved by the city's legal department. Such requirements may be waived by the city engineer or his/her designee, if the applicant provides acceptable evidence of self-insurance backed by assets equal to but not less than a net worth in the amount of at least $1,000,000.00 as approved by the city engineer or his/her designee and the director of financial services or his/her designee. 
b.  The coverage must be on an "occurrence" basis and must include coverage for personal injury, contractual liability, premises liability, medical damages, underground, explosion and collapse hazards. 
c.  Each policy must include a cancellation provision in which the insurance company is required to notify the city in writing not fewer than 30 days before canceling, refusing to renew, or reducing policy limits. 
d.  The applicant shall file the required original certificate of insurance prior to any commencement of work. The certificate shall state the policy number; name of insurance company, name and address of the agent or authorized representative of the insurance company; name, address and telephone number of the insured; policy expiration date; and specific coverage amounts. 
e.  Applicant shall file a surety bond from a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Texas in the amount of $15,000.00 to guarantee the restoration of the right-of-way in the event the applicant leaves a job site in the right-of-way unfinished, incomplete, unsafe or otherwise not restored according to city specifications, unless the applicant has an existing franchise or other contractual agreement that establishes the fee to be paid by the user for the use of the city's rights-of-way or is otherwise exempt from the payment of such a surety by applicable law. This requirement may be waived or modified upon a showing of good cause. Such good cause may include, but is not necessarily limited to, a showing of sufficient financial responsibility to adequately protect the city in an amount at least equal to the bond requirement. 
(8)  A request for a permit must be submitted at least seven working days before the commencement of work proposed in the request, unless waived by the city engineer or his/her designee or exempted pursuant to subsection (b)(1)a. of this section for emergency responses. 
(9)  Request for permits will be approved or disapproved by the city engineer or his/her designee within a reasonable time of receiving all the necessary information. The city engineer or his/her designee will use his/her best efforts to approve or disapprove a request for permit as soon as possible. Should a user need expedited approval of a permit, that fact should be made known to the city engineer at the time the request for permit is filed with the city. 
(10)  The engineering department may require a pre-construction meeting with the permittee and their construction contractor. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02)  
Sec. 94-34. - Construction standards. 
(a)  For any work requiring the issuance of a permit, the engineering department must be notified 24 hours in advance that construction is ready to proceed by either the right-of-way user, their contractor or representative. 
(b)  All construction shall be in conformance with all city codes and applicable local, state and federal laws. 
(c)  For any work requiring the issuance of a permit, three feet by three feet informational signs stating the identify of the person doing the work, telephone number and permittee's identity and telephone number shall be placed at the location where construction is to occur 24 hours prior to the beginning of work in the right-of-way and shall continue to be posted at the location during the entire time the work is occurring. 
(d)  Erosion control measure (i.e. silt fence) and advance warning signs, markers, cones and barricades must be in place before work begins. Plans must be approved at least 24 hours prior to construction. 
(e)  Permittee may be required to show proof of EPA approved plans relating to stormwater and erosion when applicable or a letter stating they are not required to obtain such plans. 
(f)  Except for emergency responses described in subsection (b)(1)a. of section 94-33, no lane closure on major thoroughfares will be allowed between 7:30 a.m. and 5:30 p.m. unless the engineering department grants prior approval. Arrow boards will be required on lane closures, with all barricades, advance warning signs and 36-inch reflector cones placed according to the specifications of the engineering department. 
(g)  Without affecting the legal relationship between a permittee and it's contractors, permittees are responsible for the workmanship and any damages by all contractors or subcontractors. A responsible representative of the permittee will be available to the engineering department at all times during construction. 
(h)  Permittee shall be responsible for stormwater management erosion control that complies with city, state and federal guidelines. Requirements shall include, but not be limited to, silt fencing around any excavation that will be left overnight, silt fencing in erosion areas until reasonable vegetation is established, barricade fencing around open holes, and high erosion areas will require wire-backed silt fencing. 
(i)  Permittee or contractor or subcontractor will notify the engineering department and the effected utility immediately of any damage to other utilities, either city or privately owned. 
(j)  Except as otherwise required by an emergency situation or condition, when a street or sidewalk cut is required, prior approval must be obtained from the engineering department and all requirements of the engineering department shall be followed. Repair of all street and sidewalk removals must be made promptly to avoid safety hazards to vehicle and pedestrian traffic. Trench plates may be required by the engineering department. 
(k)  Newly installed facilities must not interfere with other existing public utilities, in particular gravity-dependent facilities. 
(l)  Underground utilities must be installed at a minimum depths as specified by the engineering department, which minimum depth shall be consistent with applicable laws, rules, regulations and other safety codes. 
(m)  The permittee will be responsible for verifying the location both horizontal and vertical of all potentially affected facilities prior to any excavation or boring. All directional boring shall have locator place bore marks and depths while bore is in progress. Locator shall place mark at each stem with paint dot and depth at least every other stem. 
(n)  Except for emergency responses described in subsection (b)(1)a. of this section, the working hours in the rights-of-way shall be 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. Work that needs to be performed during hours other than those set out above shall be performed only with the approval of the city engineering department which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. Requests to perform work outside the above-described working hours should be, to the extent reasonably possible, requested least 24 hours in advance. Any inspections outside the hours described above shall be at the expense of the permittee. 
(o)  Contractors working for permittee are responsible for obtaining line locates from all affected public utilities prior to any excavation. 
(p)  Placement of all manholes and/or manholes must be approved in advance by the engineering department. 
(q)  Unless otherwise required by law, no underground installation or other work activities may be initiated when it is reasonably foreseeable that weather conditions will prohibit proper restoration of disturbed areas in a timely manner. The city engineer or his/her designee may waive the preceding requirement on a case by case basis, with conditions appropriate to the circumstances. 
(r)  While any portion of the streets or public ways are open, reasonable barriers, lights at night and other warnings shall be utilized for the safety of the users of the streets or public ways in compliance with applicable government regulations requiring and pertaining to such barriers or as reasonably requested by the city engineer or his/her designee. 
(s)  For all work in the streets or public ways which may disturb the normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, roadway closure or partial closure practices, as delineated in the Texas Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices or comparable manual and in the standards established by the city engineer or his/her designee shall be used and an alternate traffic routing plan shall be submitted to the engineering department prior to change in traffic flow. 
(t)  With the prior approval of the engineering department, users of the rights-of-way may trim trees upon and overhanging the streets so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming into contact with facilities. No trimming shall be performed in the streets or public ways without previously informing the engineering department. Except in emergencies all trimming of trees on public property shall have the advance approval of the city engineer or his/her designee and all trimming of trees on private property shall require notice to the property owner. Users of the public rights-of-way shall use reasonable efforts to avoid or minimize the disturbance of trees, shrubs, and ground cover properly within the public rights-of-way. 
(u)  Throughout the period of construction or reconstruction, the city shall be given notice a reasonable time before the commencement of construction or reconstruction in any block (meaning an area typically bounded by four streets) preferably not less than three business days before such commencement. The city shall be given a monthly estimated schedule of construction or reconstruction areas and planned street disturbances. 
(v)  All users of the public's rights-of-way shall endeavor to provide advance notice, appropriate to the circumstances, prior to entry whenever desiring to enter or cross any private property within the city or work in abutting streets or rights-of-ways. Work performed in an emergency in easements or rights-of-way is exempted from this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02)  
Sec. 94-35. - "Plans of record" plans. 
(a)  Rights-of-way users will provide the city engineer or his/her designee with "plans of record" within a reasonable time after completion of facilities in the right-of-way and on an annual basis thereafter indicating the location of new utility facilities that have been installed within public rights-of-way and, to the extent possible, pre-existing facilities. Users, that have facilities in the right-of-way existing as of the date of this article who have existing and available plans indicating the location of those facilities shall provide copies of those plans to the city not later than 90 days after the effective date of this article. The plans for existing facilities shall be provided to the city in the format specified by the city engineer or his/her designee, if readily available; otherwise, such plans shall be provided in the user's existing format. Submittal of "plans of record" for newly installed facilities should be provided in digital format, if readily available, as well as written format, or in any other format mutually agreed between the city engineering department and the user. 
(b)  If the release of information related to the location of any utilities or of plans of record submitted under this section would jeopardize public safety, the information shall be considered confidential. In addition, if plans of record submitted under this section include information expressly designated by the user as a trade secret or other confidential information protected from disclosure by state law, the city may not disclose that information to the public without the consent of the user unless otherwise compelled by an opinion of the Attorney General pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, as amended, or by a court having jurisdiction over the matter pursuant to applicable law. This subsection may not be construed to authorize a user to designate all matters in its plans of record as confidential or as trade secrets. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02)  
Sec. 94-36. - Conformance with public improvements. 
To the extent not prohibited by applicable federal or state law, whenever, by reasons of widening, straightening or relocation of streets, water or sewer line projects, or any other public works projects, (i.e. install or improve storm drains, water lines, sewer lines) it shall be deemed necessary by the governing body of the city to remove, alter, change, adapt, or conform the underground or overhead facilities of a right-of-way user, such alterations shall be made by the owner of the facilities at their expense within 30 days from receipt of notice to make the alterations, unless a different schedule has been approved by the city engineer or his/her designee. In such cases, users shall, at their own cost and expense, protect, support, disconnect, relocate or remove from the streets or public ways any portion of their facilities required to do so by city. The city may also temporarily disconnect, remove or relocate any user's facilities which have not been disconnected, removed or relocated within a reasonable period of time after a request from the city and the user shall reimburse city its entire expense incurred in doing so. Neither city nor any agent, contractor or employee thereof shall be liable to any user, their customers or third parties for any damages caused them or the facilities due to any activities described in this section. In areas of the city where the city engineer or his/her designee finds that the streets or public ways will not readily accommodate further underground facilities, users or proposed users shall meet with the city engineer or his/her designee in conjunction with other right-of-way users to devise a plan to manage future undergrounding. The city may require, among other things, that user's conduits be oversized, duplicated, or placed in multiple configurations, and user's shall share the use of their underground conduits and multiple configurations at such locations at reasonable rates. Such rates shall be determined by city if user's and third parties cannot agree on same. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02)  
Sec. 94-37. - Ground equipment. 
(a)  Ground equipment near street corners and intersections. Ground equipment should be minimal and the least intrusive. In accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.102(1), to minimize any obstruction, impediment, or hindrance to the usual travel or public safety on a public right-of-way the maximum line of sight required to add to safe travel of vehicular and pedestrian traffic and in order to maximize that line of sight at street corners and intersections and to minimize hazards at those locations, ground equipment may not be installed within 250 feet of a street corner or a street intersection. 
(b)  Ground equipment near municipal parks. For the safety of municipal park patrons, particularly small children, and to allow full line of sights near municipal park property, the user shall not install ground equipment in a right-of-way that is within a park or within 250 feet of the boundary line of a park, unless approved by the city manager and parks director in writing. 
(c)  In accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.102(1) to enhance the safety requirements of line of sight of pedestrians, particularly small children, the city's designee may deny a request for a proposed location if the user installs network node ground equipment where existing ground equipment within 300 feet already occupies a footprint of 25 square feet or more. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, adopted Aug. 14, 2017, amended the Code by redesignating former §§ 94-37—94-41, 94-43—94-45 as §§ 94-49—94-56. Section I also provided that § 94-42 be deleted from the Code, which pertained to vacation, discontinuance and removal of system, and derived from Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, adopted Jan. 14, 2002. Section III of said ordinance added new provisions to be included as §§ 94-37—94-48 to read as set out herein.  
Sec. 94-38. - Concealment. 
(a)  Concealment of network nodes and node support poles shall be required by the city in design districts with decorative poles and in historic districts pursuant to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.105. 
(b)  It is also the city's preference that all new node support poles be camouflaged, except those located in an area zoned or predominantly industrial area. Companies shall submit their proposal for camouflage with the permit application. 
(c)  The network node facilities shall be concealed or enclosed as much as reasonably possible in an equipment box, cabinet, or other unit that may include ventilation openings. External cables and wires hanging off a pole shall be sheathed or enclosed in a conduit, so that wires are protected and not visible or visually minimized to the extent possible in strict accordance with the city's rights-of-way management ordinance, and other applicable ordinances, except to the extent not consistent with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 284. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-39. - Allowed colors. 
Colors in historic districts and design districts must be approved by the city manager from a palette of approved colors. Unless otherwise provided, all colors shall be earth tones or shall match the background of any structure the facilities are located upon and all efforts shall be made for the colors to be inconspicuous. Colors in areas other than in historic districts and design districts shall conform to colors of other installations of telecommunication providers in the immediately adjacent areas. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-40. - Vacation, discontinuance, removal or relocation. 
(a)  In the event that city closes, abandons, or vacates any rights-of-way that contains facilities, any such closure, abandonment, vacation, or conveyance effectuating same shall be subject to, and conditioned upon, the rights of the users of such rights-of-way. 
(b)  In accordance with applicable law, upon the revocation, termination, or expiration and non-renewal of an applicable franchise agreement, license, or permit, either (a) by mutual agreement of city and a user, (b) by the user's acquiescence or failure to challenge same, or (c) by a final order of a court which a user either does not appeal or from which there is no further right of appeal, then the following shall occur: The user shall immediately discontinue the use of its facilities and all rights of said user to use the streets and public ways shall cease. The user, at the direction of city, shall remove its facilities, including all supporting structures, poles, transmission and distribution portions of the system and other appurtenances, fixtures or property from the streets and public ways, in, over, under, along, or through which they are installed within six months of the revocation, termination, or expiration except that (a) user may abandon its facilities in place with city's consent, and (b) user cannot remove underground facilities without city's consent in advance, which shall not be unreasonably withheld. Prior to any removal the user shall notify city and persons owning property abutting public ways where removal will occur. The user shall also restore any property, public or private, to the condition in which it existed prior the installation, erection or construction of its facilities, including any improvements made to such property subsequent to the construction of its facilities. Restoration of streets and city property, including, but not limited to, the public ways, shall be in accordance with the directions and specifications of city's engineering department, and all generally applicable laws, ordinances and generally applicable regulations, at the user's sole expense. If such removal and restoration is not completed within six months after the revocation, termination, or expiration, all of the user's property remaining in the affected streets and public ways shall, at the option of city, be deemed abandoned and shall, at the option of city, become its property or city may obtain a court order compelling the user to remove same. In the event the user fails or refuses to remove its facilities or to satisfactorily restore all areas to the condition in which they existed prior to the original construction of the facilities, city, at its option, may perform such work and if such work is performed within four years of the revocation, termination or expiration of the applicable franchise agreement, license, or permit collect the costs thereof from the user. No surety on any performance bond shall be discharged until city has certified to the user in writing that the facilities have been dismantled, removed, and all other property restored, to the satisfaction of city. 
(c)  Removal or relocation by user. 
(1)  If the user removes or relocates a micro network node, network node facilities, node support pole or related ground equipment at its own discretion, it shall notify the city manager in writing not less than ten business days prior to removal or relocation. User shall obtain all permits required for relocation or removal of its micro network node, network node facilities, node support poles and related ground equipment prior to relocation or removal. 
(2)  The city shall not issue any refunds for any amounts paid by user for micro network node, network node facilities, node support poles or related ground equipment that have been removed. 
(d)  Removal or relocation required for city project. 
(1)  In accordance with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 284.107, except as provided in existing state and federal law, a user shall relocate or adjust micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment in a public right-of-way in a timely manner and without cost to the municipality managing the public right-of-way 
(2)  User understands and acknowledges that the city may require user to remove or relocate its micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment, or any portion thereof from the right-of-way for city construction projects as allowed by state and federal law, including the common-law. 
(3)  User shall, at the city manager's direction, remove or relocate the same at user's sole cost and expense, except as otherwise provided in existing state and federal law, whenever the city manager reasonably determines that the relocation or removal is needed for any of the following purposes: required for the construction, completion, repair, widening, relocation, or maintenance of, or use in connection with, any city construction or maintenance project of a street or public rights-of-way to enhance the traveling publics use for travel and transportation. 
(4)  If user fails to remove or relocate the micro network node, network node, node support pole or related ground equipment, or portion thereof as requested by the city manager within 90 days of user's receipt of the request, then the city shall be entitled to remove the micro network node, network node, node support pole or related ground equipment, or portion thereof at user's sole cost and expense, without further notice to user. 
(5)  User shall, within 30 days following issuance of invoice for the same, reimburse the city for its reasonable expenses incurred in the removal (including, without limitation, overhead and storage expenses) of the micro network node, network node, node support pole or related ground equipment, or portion thereof. 
(e)  Removal required by city for safety and imminent danger reasons. 
(1)  User shall, at its sole cost and expense, promptly disconnect, remove, or relocate the applicable micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment within the timeframe and in the manner required by the city manager if the city manager reasonably determines that the disconnection, removal, or relocation of any part of a micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment (a) is necessary to protect the public health, safety, welfare, or city property, (b) the micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment, or portion thereof, is adversely affecting proper operation of streetlights or city property, or (c) user fails to obtain all applicable licenses, permits, and certifications required by law for its micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment, or use of any location under applicable law. If the city manager reasonably determines that there is imminent danger to the public, then the city may immediately disconnect, remove, or relocate the applicable micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment at the user's sole cost and expense. 
(2)  The city manager shall provide 90 days written notice to the user before removing a micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment under this section, unless there is imminent danger to the public health, safety, and welfare. 
(3)  User shall reimburse city for the city's actual cost of removal of micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment within 30 days of receiving the invoice from the city. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-41. - Installation and inspections. 
(a)  User shall, at its own cost and expense, install the micro network node, network node facilities, node support poles and related ground equipment in a good and workmanlike manner and in accordance with the requirements promulgated by the city manager, as such may be amended from time to time. User's work shall be subject to the regulation, control and direction of the city manager. All work done in connection with the installation, operation, maintenance, repair, modification, and/or replacement of the micro network node, network node facilities, node support poles and related ground equipment shall be in compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, codes, rules and regulations of the city, applicable county, the state, and the United States ("laws"). 
(b)  The city manager, or designee, may perform visual inspections of any micro network node, network node, node support pole or related ground equipment located in the right-of-way as the city manager deems appropriate without notice. If the inspection requires physical contact with the micro network node, network node, node support poles or related ground equipment, the city manager shall provide written notice to the user within five business days of the planned inspection. User may have a representative present during such inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-42. - As-built maps and records. 
User shall maintain accurate maps and other appropriate records of its network node facilities, node support poles and related ground equipment as they are actually constructed in the rights-of-way, including, upon request, the use of autoCAD/GIS digital format. User will provide additional maps to the city upon request. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-43. - Drug policy. 
It is the policy of the city to achieve a drug-free workforce and workplace. The manufacture, distribution, dispensation, possession, sale, or use of illegal drugs or alcohol by user's employees, contractors, subcontractors, sub-user's, or vendors while on city rights-of-way is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-44. - Ownership. 
No part of a micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment erected or placed on the right-of-way by user will become, or be considered by the city as being affixed to or a part of, the right-of-way. All portions of the micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment constructed, modified, erected, or placed by user on the right-of-way will be and remain the property of user and may be removed by user at any time, provided the user shall notify the city manager prior to any work in the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-45. - Signage. 
(a)  User shall post its name, location identifying information, and emergency telephone number in an area on the cabinet of the network node facility that is visible to the public. Signage required under this section shall not exceed four inches by six inches, unless otherwise required by law (e.g. RF ground notification signs) or the city manager. 
(b)  Except as required by laws or by the utility pole owner, user shall not post any other signage or advertising on the micro network node, network node, node support pole, service pole or utility pole. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-46. - Graffiti abatement. 
As soon as practical, but not later than 14 calendar days from the date user receives notice thereof, user shall remove all graffiti on any of its micro network node, network node, node support pole, and related ground equipment located in the right-of-way. The foregoing shall not relieve the user from complying with any city graffiti or visual blight ordinance or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-47. - Restoration. 
User shall repair any damage to the right-of-way, or any facilities located within the right-of-way, and the property of any third party resulting from user's removal or relocation activities (or any other of user's activities hereunder) within ten calendar days following the date of such removal or relocation, at user's sole cost and expense, including restoration of the right-of-way and such property to substantially the same condition as it was immediately before the date user was granted a permit for the applicable location or did the work at such location (even if user did not first obtain a permit), including restoration or replacement of any damaged trees, shrubs or other vegetation. Such repair, restoration and replacement shall be subject to the sole, reasonable approval of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-48. - User's responsibility. 
User shall be responsible and liable for the acts and omissions of user's employees, temporary employees, officers, directors, consultants, agents, affiliates, subsidiaries, sub-user's and subcontractors in connection with the installations of any micro network node, network node, node support pole and related ground equipment, as if such acts or omissions were user's acts or omissions. 
(Ord. No. 2017-44, § III, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-49. - Improperly installed facilities. 
(a)  Any person doing work in the city rights-of-way shall properly install, repair, upgrade and maintain facilities and shall do so in accordance with this chapter, applicable law, applicable safety codes, and the reasonable directives of the city engineering department. 
(b)  To the extent not prohibited by applicable federal or state laws, rules, regulations or tariffs, facilities shall be considered to be improperly installed, repaired, upgraded or maintained if: 
(1)  The installation, repairs, upgrade or maintenance endangers people; 
(2)  The facilities do not meet the applicable city codes; 
(3)  The facilities are not capable of being located using standard practices; 
(4)  The facilities are not located in the proper place in accordance with the directions provided by the engineering department; 
(5)  The facilities are placed in an area that interferes with city-owned facilities, such as water or sewer lines or streets. Privately owned facilities shall be considered to interfere with city-owned facilities if the privately-owned facility is within three feet horizontally or one foot vertically of city-owned facilities; 
(6)  The facilities cause subsidence/settlement or under deterioration to pavement infrastructure; 
(7)  The facilities are not installed in accordance with this chapter; or 
(8)  The facilities are deemed to be improperly installed by the city engineer or his/her designee. 
(c)  In the event that the city determines that facilities are improperly installed, the user shall be given notice and a reasonable opportunity to cure the improper nature of the installation prior to any remedial action and or civil penalties being imposed by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 94-37.  
Sec. 94-50. - Type and location of facilities. 
(a)  The city engineer may require or approve the location of facilities underground. 
(b)  When poles are used, the types of poles, location, depth, upgrades, etc., shall be subject to the review of the engineering department as part of the permit review process. 
(c)  City engineer or his/her designee may approve size of facilities to be installed pursuant to a permit application or require proof of need to install size of system requesting to be permitted. 
(d)  Users shall identify all facilities placed in the rights-of-way (by color code, stamping, engraving, tags, stickers, or other appropriate method selected by user) so as to distinguish user's facilities from that of all other users. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 94-37.  
Sec. 94-51. - Restoration of property. 
(a)  Users of the right-of-way shall restore property affected by construction of facilities to a condition that is substantially similar to or better than the condition of the property prior to the performance of the work. 
(b)  Restoration includes, but is not limited to, replacing all ground cover with equal to the type of ground cover damaged during work or better either by sodding or seeding, as directed by the engineering department. In addition user shall at its sole cost and expense restore and replace any other property, real or personal, properly within the rights-of-way, which is disturbed, damaged or in any way injured by or on account of user or by its acts or missions, to the same condition as such property was in immediately prior to the disturbance, damage or injury. 
(c)  Restoration must be to the reasonable satisfaction of the engineering department. Nothing herein shall require the user to restore or replace improvements that have been placed within the public rights-of-way in violation of other city ordinances, applicable laws, or other regulations. The restoration shall include, but not necessarily be limited to: 
(1)  Installation of all manholes and handholes, as required; 
(2)  Backfilling or covering of all bore pits, potholes, trenches or any other holes daily, unless other safety measures are approved by the engineering department; 
(3)  Leveling of all trenches and backhoe lines; 
(4)  Restoration of excavation side to city specifications; 
(5)  Restoration of all landscaping. 
(d)  All locate flags shall be removed during the cleanup process by the permittee or his/her contractor at the completion of the work. 
(e)  Restoration must be made in a timely manner as specified by approved engineering department schedules and to the satisfaction of the city engineer or his/her designee. If restoration is not satisfactory and performed in a timely manner, after notice and a reasonable opportunity to properly restore, all work in progress, except that related to the problem, may be halted and a hold may be placed on any related permits or permit applications until all restoration is complete. 
(f)  In the event that a user and/or its contractors and/or subcontractors fail to make such restorations or repairs within the time specified by the city, city shall be entitled to complete the repair or restoration and the user shall pay the reasonable costs of city for such repair. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 94-37.  
Sec. 94-52. - Failure to comply with chapter. 
If any of the provisions of this chapter are not followed, and following the notice and opportunity to cure provisions of section 94-31 of this chapter, a permit may be revoked by the city manager or the city engineer or his/her designee. If a person has not followed the terms and conditions of this chapter in work done pursuant to a prior permit, new permits may be denied or additional terms required. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 94-37.  
Sec. 94-53. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Removal of obsolete facilities/cooperation. When a user opens a trench, accesses a conduit or boring, or is working on aerial locations, to the extent the user is reasonably able to do so, it shall remove all unusable and/or obsolete facilities (excluding those held for future use) from such locations. When a user opens a trench or access to borings, it shall, to the extent it is reasonably able to do so, notify all other recipients of franchise agreements, franchisees, permittees, and other user's of such locations in advance of such work, so that they may remove their obsolete facilities from such locations or add new facilities. Users shall cooperate with one another in such activities. When a user receives notification from another user that it is opening a trench or access to borings, said user shall, to the extent it is reasonably able to do so, remove all of its obsolete facilities from such location while they are open. 
(b)  Location of facilities other than public rights-of-way. 
(1)  Easements: Any easements over or under private property necessary for the construction or operation of facilities shall be arranged by the user thereof. Any easements over or under property owned by City other than the public ways shall be separately negotiated with city. 
(c)  Joint use by city. To the extent not prohibited by applicable state or federal law, users shall permit, without charge, the joint use of excess height, space and capacity in its poles, conduits and facilities located in the streets or public ways by city or other governmental entities. 
(d)  Temporary re-location. Upon ten business days notice and in compliance with all applicable federal and state laws, rules, regulations and tariffs and applicable safety codes, users shall either temporarily raise or lower wires or other equipment upon the request of any person, including without limitation, a person holding a building moving permit issued by city. A user so affected may charge a reasonable rate for this service, not to exceed its actual costs with an advance deposit of the estimated cost, or as otherwise provided by applicable federal or state law, rule, regulation or tariff. 
(e)  Pavement cut coordination/additional fees. Users shall coordinate construction programs and all other work in the streets and public ways with city's program for street construction, rebuilding and resurfacing (collectively, "street resurfacing"). All users shall meet with the city engineer or his/her designee at least twice per year to this end. 
(f)  Temporary license. The city manager, in consultation with the city engineer and the city attorney, may grant a temporary license on a month-to-moth basis if a license, franchise, or abandonment application is being processed by the city and if failure to grant a temporary license will subject the applicant to a substantial hardship. 
(g)  Waiver. Any provision of this chapter that is not required by state law or the city Charter may be waived or modified by the city commission, in its sole discretion, in the license or franchise granting use of the city's rights-of-way. Additionally, if on the effective date of this chapter, a person holds a franchise agreement or other contract with the city that authorizes the use of the city's rights-of-way, that person will be exempted from any provision of this chapter that would impose additional fees upon that person that are not contained within the franchise agreement or contract or that are in direct conflict with the terms of the franchise agreement or contract. 
(h)  Effect on existing facilities. Nothing in this article shall be construed so as to require facilities previously installed and existing in the rights-of-way as of the effective date of this article to be removed and/or re-installed so as to be in compliance herewith; provided, however, that the city engineer may require existing facilities to be re-installed, relocated, repaired, and/or removed if the city engineer determines that the facilities were improperly installed and such facilities create a threat to the public health or safety. In all other respects, all facilities, whether installed prior or subsequent to the effective date of this article, shall be subject to and in compliance with this chapter. 
(i)  Landscaping. Landscaping and other improvements placed within the rights-of-way must not unduly interfere or impair the use of those rights-of-way for roadway, transportation, communication, utility, or other such uses and such landscaping and other improvements shall conform to the guidelines as may be issued from time to time by city's engineering department. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 94-37.  
Sec. 94-54. - Franchise required. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed so as to permit a use of the public rights-of-way within the city without first obtaining any required permission and/or franchise from city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 94-37.  
Sec. 94-55. - Fee for use of public rights-of-way. 
Except for those persons holding an existing franchise agreement or other contract with the city as of the affective date of this chapter that authorizes the use of the city's public rights-of-way are those persons whose fees for the use of the city's public rights-of-way are established by applicable federal or state law, rule, regulation or tariff, persons using the city's public rights-of-way shall be charges filing fees for such use: unless otherwise specifically set out in an applicable franchise agreement or controlling state law, the fees for use of the city's public rights-of-way are as follows: 
(1)  The annual fee for a license to use a public right-of-way for the following uses is: 
a.  Fee for railroad crossing: not less than $50.00 per track crossing the public right-of-way or an amount determined by the city engineer or his/her designee and established in this article granting the franchise. The fee will not be assessed for a railroad crossing where the railroad crossing existed before the public right-of-way was established. 
b.  Fee for encroachment of historically significant structures (as determined by city) into public right-of-way: $350.00. 
c.  Fee for newspaper racks placed in the public right-of-way: $5.00 each. 
d.  Fee for landscaping and appurtenant irrigation systems: $350.00. 
e.  Fee for awnings and other uses determined to be in the best interest of the public: as established by the city commission. 
(2)  The annual fee for use of the public right-of-way for uses other than those listed in subsection (1) is $350.00 or as calculated in accordance with one of the following formulas, whichever is greater: 
a.  Fee for use of public right-of-way, including but not limited to sidewalk vendors (where allowed): area × market value × 85 percent × 12 percent. 
b.  Fee for subsurface use only: area × market value × 30 percent × 12 percent. 
c.  Fee for air rights only: area × market value × 85 percent × 85 percent × 12 percent. 
Fee for commercial parking (if permitted by city): 50 percent of gross receipts. 
(3)  Whether or not stated in this article granting the license, franchise, or permit, the city commission retains the right to increase or decrease the annual fee. 
(4)  As used in this section, and unless otherwise determined by the city commission, the "market value" of the area licensed shall be based on the per square foot appraised value, as determined by the Hidalgo County Appraisal District, of a fee simple interest in a useable tract of abutting property. 
(5)  The city engineer shall, not less than biannually, review the market value of licensed areas for which fees are based upon market value. If it is determined that the market value of a licensed area has decreased, the city shall notify the licensee/franchisee in writing that the annual fee has been decreased. If it is determined that the market value of a licensed area has increased, the city shall notify the licensee/franchisee in writing that the annual fee has been increased. If the licensee/franchisee is unwilling to accept the increased fee, the licensee/franchisee may terminate the license/franchise and receive any refund due for the prepaid portion of the current year's fee. All increases/decreases in licensee/franchise fees made pursuant to this section shall be reported to the city commission before taking effect. 
(6)  It shall be presumed for purposes of this section and the formulas contained herein that a linear foot of right-of-way usage equates to a square foot of area in the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 94-37.  
Sec. 94-56. - Appeal process. 
Appeal from a denial or revocation of a permit or from any other decision, direction, or requirement issued pursuant to this chapter shall be first to the city manager. The city manager shall allow or deny the appeal within three business days of receipt of same by the city. If the appeal is denied, the city manager shall issue a written statement setting out the reasons for the denial. If the city manager denies the appeal, the user may then appeal the city manager's decision to the city commission by filing a written notice of the user's intention to appeal, in writing, with the city secretary and a copy to the city attorney. Any such appeal shall be filed within 15 days after the city manager's denial. If an appeal to the city commission is filed, the city commission shall set a time and a place for hearing the appeal and shall notify the user in writing of said time and place. Such hearing shall be held within 20 business days of the filing of the appeal and the user shall be provided at least five business days notice of the date, time and place of the hearing, unless such time periods are waived by the user. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 1, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § I, 8-14-17) 
Editor's note— See editor's note following § 94-37.  
Secs. 94-57—94-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, adopted Aug. 14, 2017, amended Art. III, §§ 94-46—94-52, by redesignating as Art. III, §§ 94-71—94-77. 
 
Sec. 94-71. - Violation of article provisions. 
In addition to any penalty which may be prescribed for the failure of any person to construct, reconstruct, repair or otherwise improve any street, sidewalk, curb or gutter in violation of the provisions of this article, such street, sidewalk, curb or gutter may be corrected or made to comply with this article under such rules and regulations as may be adopted or prescribed by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1966, § 26-17; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-72. - Power of board of commissioners. 
The board of commissioners shall have the power in their discretion by resolution passed by a majority vote, to order the construction, reconstruction, repair or improvement of dedicated streets, sidewalks, curbs or gutters along any street, avenue, public place, alley or part or section thereof within the city, or in front of any property abutting upon the same. Such resolution shall in general terms describe such dedicated streets, sidewalks, curbs or gutters, and the street, avenue, square, alley or place, or part or section thereof, along which any such street, sidewalk, curb or gutter is to be constructed, reconstructed or repaired. The city shall have the power to assess the whole cost of such dedicated street, sidewalk, curb or gutter, or part of same, against the property abutting or fronting thereon, and against the owner thereof. 
(Code 1966, § 26-18; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-73. - Specifications. 
Specifications for street, sidewalk, driveway and curb and gutter construction, repair or other improvement within the city shall be as prescribed by the board of commissioners from time to time. 
(Code 1966, § 26-19; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-74. - Permit required. 
No person shall construct, reconstruct, repair or otherwise improve any sidewalk, curb, gutter or any street paving within the city without first obtaining from the city building official a permit to do so. 
(Code 1966, § 26-20; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-75. - Bond required. 
No person shall construct, reconstruct, repair or otherwise improve any sidewalk, curb, gutter or street paving in the city without first having executed and delivered to the city a bond in the sum of $1,000.00, payable to the city with two or more good and sufficient personal sureties thereon, or an approved surety company as surety, which bond shall be conditioned as follows: 
(1)  That all work shall be done in a good and workmanlike manner, and that such person shall faithfully and strictly comply with the specifications and with the terms of this article and such other applicable provisions of this Code, ordinances, resolutions or regulations that may be passed by the board of commissioners. 
(2)  That the city shall be fully indemnified and be held whole and harmless from any and all cost and expense of damage, whether real or asserted, on account of any injury done to any person or property in the prosecution of such work, or that may arise out of or be occasioned by the performance of such work. 
(3)  That the person shall, without additional cost to the person for whom the work was done, maintain all sidewalks, curbs, gutters or street paving so constructed, reconstructed or repaired by such person for a period of one year from the date of such construction, reconstruction or repair, to the satisfaction of the city engineer, and shall reconstruct or repair such sidewalk, curb, gutter or street paving, to the satisfaction of the city engineer, at any time within one year after the construction, reconstruction or repair of such sidewalk, curb, gutter or street paving after ten days' notice from the city engineer to reconstruct or repair the same. The opinion of the city engineer as to the necessity of such reconstruction or repair shall be binding on the parties thereto. 
(4)  That such bond shall be in force for one year after any sidewalk, curb, gutter or street paving is constructed, reconstructed or repaired, and one recovery shall not exhaust such bond, but such bond shall be a continuing obligation against the sureties thereon until the entire amount therein provided for shall have been exhausted. 
(5)  That if such bond shall be decreased on account of any recovery which may be obtained, arising out of the violation of any condition of such bond, the board of commissioners shall require, upon notice of such a fact, an additional bond to be given by any such person in accordance with this article in an amount sufficient, when added to the unexhausted amount of the original bond, to be at all times equal to the sum of $1,000.00. 
(6)  That the city may for itself or for the use and benefit of any person injured or damaged by reason of any defective construction, reconstruction or repair of any sidewalk, curb, gutter or street paving by any person, maintain suit on such bond in any court having jurisdiction thereof, or suit may be maintained thereon by any person injured or damaged by reason of the failure of any person who shall construct, reconstruct or repair any sidewalk, curb, gutter or street paving in the city to observe the conditions of such bond. 
(7)  That such bond shall expire on January 1 of each year, and shall thereafter be reexecuted by any such person for a period of one year from such date; provided that any person constructing, reconstructing or repairing any sidewalk, curb, gutter or street paving at any time after January 1 of any year shall execute a bond for the unexpired portion of such year; that is, until January 1 of the succeeding year, it being the intention of this section that all bonds shall expire on January 1 of each year, and as near as practicable that all bonds shall be executed for a period of one year. 
(8)  That the board of commissioners shall have the right to increase the amount of the bond of any such person at any time it deems it necessary to protect the interests of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 26-21; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-76. - Supervision of work. 
Any person who shall construct, reconstruct, repair or otherwise improve any sidewalk, curb, gutter or street in the city shall do so under the supervision of the city engineer and in accordance with the specifications set forth in this article or such other specifications as may be prepared by the city engineer and adopted by the board of commissioners. 
(Code 1966, § 26-22; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-77. - Paving, curb and gutter in subdivisions. 
(a)  In all cases wherein subdivision plats are submitted for approval by the board of commissioners as a prerequisite to filing of such plats for record in the office of the county clerk, it shall be a prerequisite to final approval thereof by the board of commissioners that paving, curb and gutter have been laid by the owner or subdivider over all streets shown on such subdivision, in accordance with plans and specifications provided by the city for street paving, and as approved by the city engineer. In lieu of actual paving, such owner or subdivider may deposit with the city a sum of money equal to the estimated costs of such paving as determined by the city engineer, or such owner or subdivider may file with the city a good and sufficient bond executed by himself as principal and a good reputable surety company doing business in the state as surety, subject to approval by the board of commissioners, guaranteeing that such paving, curb and gutter will be laid in accordance with city plans and specifications and subject to approval of city engineer within a period of one year from date of approval of such plat. If money deposit is made, the city may, at its option, proceed with such work at any time and pay for such work from such deposit. If bond is filed and the owner fails to comply with the paving requirement within the required period, the city may thereupon proceed with such paving and the principal and surety on such bond shall be liable for the cost of such paving, curb and gutter. 
(b)  No approval of any plat by the city planning and zoning commission shall waive any of the provisions of this article. The city reserves the right to withhold all city utility connections to any lot in any subdivision until such paving, curb and gutter are laid. 
(Code 1966, § 26-23; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17) 
Charter reference— Platting of property, art. 1, § 5.  
Secs. 94-78—94-88. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SIGHT OBSTRUCTIONS AT INTERSECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, adopted Aug. 14, 2017, amended the Code by redesignating §§ 94-56—94-60 of Art. IV as §§ 94-78—-94-85. In order to maintain the style of the Code, and at the editor's discretion, said sections have been redesignated as Art IV, §§ 94-89—94-93. 
 
Sec. 94-89. - Obstructions prohibited. 
No person shall erect, permit or maintain the existence of any wall, fence or other structure, except utility poles, traffic signs and devices, and street name signs, or plant or permit the growth or existence of any tree, hedge, shrub or other similar growth of a height greater than three feet from the street gutter flow line upon his property where such property is bounded on two adjacent sides by the public right-of-way for a road, street, alley, or other public passageway, at angles to each other, the area so restricted being the area of the corner of such property, more particularly described as being that area in the form of a triangle, bounded by two intersecting boundaries of the present or future street curbline for a distance of 25 feet (ten feet for alleys) on each of such boundaries from the points of intersection, and bounded by a third side determined by drawing of a straight line from the points of the two intersecting boundaries 25 feet (ten feet for alleys) from their intersection. 
(Code 1966, § 26-52; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-90. - Preexisting structures excepted; application against preexisting shrubs, etc. 
Section 94-56 shall not apply to any business building, family building, apartment house, or other structures existing as of March 20, 1962, and not in violation of any applicable provision of this Code, or state law or city ordinance. Also, section 94-56 shall not apply to a single tree existing in the specified triangle as of December 1, 1973; provided, however, that no limbs, leaves, or other growth on the tree shall be allowed to exist at a height of more than three feet and less than eight feet above the street gutter flow line. No other exceptions shall be granted for the existence of other trees, shrubs, or other growth in any area prohibited by section 94-56 in the city. 
(Code 1966, § 26-53; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2006-83, § 2, 8-14-06; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-91. - Minimum clearance of trees. 
(a)  No person who is an owner or occupant of any private premises or property within the city shall permit the growth or existence of any tree, hedge, shrub or other similar growth where such tree, hedge, shrub or other similar growth shall overhang or project onto any public street or right-of-way so designated as a state highway or major arterial as defined and delineated in the thoroughfare plan as contained in Foresight McAllen, the official comprehensive plan for the city, adopted and on file with the city secretary, at a height of not less than 13 feet, six inches, and on all other city streets at a height of not less than 12 feet from the street level. No person as owner or occupant of any private premises or property located in the city shall permit the growth or existence of any tree, hedge, shrub or other similar growth where such obstruction interferes with the visibility of traffic control signs or devices by operators of vehicles upon public streets or by pedestrians upon public streets or sidewalks. 
(b)  There is hereby imposed a penalty as prescribed in section 1-14, plus state court cost, for the conviction of any person for violation of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1966, § 26-54; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-92. - Flashing lights and signs. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following words shall have the following meaning: 
Flashing light or sign means any light-producing device wherein any one or any group of light sources goes on and off, or gives the appearance of going on or off, from any direction from which the source is visible at a frequency of between 30 and 180 times per minute. 
High intensity light means any light-producing device which uses internal or external reflectorization or magnification to increase light intensity or directional focusing. 
(b)  Prohibited uses. It shall be unlawful, whether individually or through an agent, employee or representative, to place, erect, install or use any flashing light or sign of a red, yellow, amber or orange color within 100 feet horizontal distance of any public street or highway right-of-way line within the city, or for any high intensity light to be used within 100 feet of a street or highway in a manner such that the rays of the high intensity light are directed horizontally upon the roadway of any street or highway within the city. 
(c)  Exemptions. Exemptions from the provisions of this section are official traffic control devices, street lights, emergency vehicles, construction warning lights, aircraft beacons or warning lights, and any other lights or signs required by law. 
(Code 1966, § 26-54.1; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Sec. 94-93. - Enforcement of article provisions. 
The existence of any structure or growth prohibited by this article is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a danger to the free uninterrupted flow of traffic upon the public ways and a danger to the use of such public ways by operators of vehicles and by pedestrians. In addition to any penalty which may be imposed for the violation of this article, the city shall have the right, without being guilty of trespass and without being liable for damages, to enter onto any property to trim and remove such obstructions in order to carry out the purpose and intent of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 26-55; Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 1-14-02; Ord. No. 2017-44, § II, 8-14-17)  
Chapter 98 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Finance, § 2-271 et seq.; fiscal year, § 2-272. 
State Law reference— City tax assessor and collector authorized, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 6.22; taxation, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 1.001 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 98-1. - Tax on sale of telecommunications services. 
(a)  A tax is hereby authorized on all telecommunications services sold within the city. For purposes of this section, the sale of telecommunications services is consummated at the location of the telephone or other telecommunications device from which the call or other communication originates. If the point of origin cannot be determined, the sale is consummated at the address to which the call or other communication is billed. 
(b)  The application of the exemption provided for in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(a) is hereby repealed by the city as authorized by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(b). 
(c)  The rate of tax imposed by this section shall be the same as the rate imposed by the city for all other local sales and use taxes as authorized by the state legislature. 
(d)  The city secretary shall forward to the state comptroller by United States registered or certified mail a copy of this section along with a copy of the minutes of the board of commissioners' vote and discussion on this section. 
(e)  This section shall become effective as of October 1, 1987. 
(Code 1966, § 27-5)  
Sec. 98-2. - Tax on sale of residential use of gas and electricity within the city. 
(a)  A tax is hereby authorized and imposed on all receipts from residential use of gas and electricity within the city, as is provided for by state law. 
(b)  The exemption provided for in § 321.105, Tax Code, V.A.T.C.S., is hereby vacated by the city as authorized by § 321.105 thereof. 
(c)  The rate of tax imposed by this section shall be the same as the rate imposed by the city for all other local sales and use taxes as authorized by the legislature of the state. 
(d)  The city secretary shall forward to the comptroller of the state by United States registered mail a copy of this section along with a copy of the minutes of the city commission's vote on this section. 
(e)  This section shall be and is hereby declared to be cumulative of all other ordinances of the city, and this section shall not operate to repeal or affect any such other ordinances. The tax provided for hereunder shall not serve as an offset to, be in lieu of or in any way reduce any amount payable to the city pursuant to any franchise, street use, ordinance, charter provision, or statute or, without limitation by the foregoing enumeration, otherwise payable by any provider of gas or electricity within the city, it being the express intent hereof that all such obligations, impositions and agreements of every kind and nature shall remain in full force and effect without reduction or limitation hereby. 
(Ord. No. 2012-13, § II, 2-27-12) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-13, § II, adopted Feb. 27, 2012, enacted provisions which did not specify manner of inclusion. Hence, to facilitate indexing, said provisions have been codified herein as § 98-2.  
Secs. 98-3—98-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 98-26—98-35. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - HOMESTEAD EXEMPTIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2004-89, § 1, adopted Oct. 25, 2004, amended former Art. II, Div. 2, Subdivs. I—III, §§ 98-46—98-50, 98-61—98-66, to read as herein set out in Art. II, Div. 2, Subdivs. I and II, §§ 98-36, 98-37, 98-46, 98-47. Former Subdivisions II and III pertained to elderly persons and disabled persons. See also the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 
 
Subdivision I. - Tax Code Sec. 11.13 (d)—(f) Exemption 
 
Sec. 98-36. - Amount of and type of exemption. 
Upon complying with and maintaining all of the requirements for an exemption under Section 11.43 and Sections 11.431 Texas Tax Code as such sections presently exists or may hereinafter be amended, $10,000.00 of the appraised value of a residence homestead of an individual who is disabled or is 65 years of age or older shall be exempt from ad valorem taxes levied by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2004-89, § 1, 10-25-04)  
Sec. 98-37. - Effective date.
