Sec. 102-189. - Maximum limit in school zones. 
(a)  The maximum speed limit authorized on any street in the city adjacent to any public school shall be as posted and during the times indicated on the signs or whenever the flashing beacon is activated for the posted speed limit. The independent school district may request in writing, by and through its authorized officers, that the times specified therefor be increased or reduced in order to coincide with the arrival or dismissal of students at any particular school or schools, and the traffic safety coordinator is authorized to change the hours of maximum speed limitations on school signs and flashing beacons as applicable, and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle upon any street so marked at a greater speed than as posted thereon, which speed is hereby found to be reasonable and prudent under the conditions aforesaid. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions as set out in subsection (a) of this section, during the hours of 7:30 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 4:00 p.m. on the days when school is in session, the maximum speed limit authorized on the following street in the city adjacent to any public school is fixed at 35 miles per hour: 
On McColl Road (F.M. 2061) beginning at a point 1,350 feet north of the north curbline of Nolana Loop and proceeding northward to 200 feet south of the south curbline of Violet Avenue. 
Provided, however, should the administration of Good Shepherd School request in writing, by and through its authorized officers, that the times as specified in this subsection be increased or reduced in order to coincide with the arrival or dismissal of students at any particular school or schools, the traffic safety coordinator is authorized to change the hours of maximum speed limitations on school signs and flashing beacons, as applicable, and it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle upon any street so marked at a greater speed than 35 miles per hour, which speed is hereby found to be reasonable and prudent under the conditions aforesaid. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the provisions as set out in subsection (a) of this section, during the times the beacon is activated, the maximum speed limit authorized on the following street in the city adjacent to any public school is fixed at 30 miles per hour: 
On Ware Road beginning at a point 75 feet north of the curbline of Quince Avenue proceeding northward to a point 500 feet north of Vine Avenue. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the provisions as set out in subsection (a) of this section, during the hours the flashing beacon is activated, the maximum speed limit authorized on the following street in the city adjacent to any public school is fixed at 30 miles per hour: 
On Three Mile Line (Tulip), F.M. 1924, from a point 500 feet east and 500 feet west of Rooth Road (North 29th Street). 
(e)  The traffic safety coordinator is hereby authorized to construct and install proper traffic control signs, signals and markings at designated areas to carry out the purposes of this section. 
(Code 1966, § 29-72)  
Sec. 102-190. - Maximum limit in residential alleys. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, the term "alley" shall mean any improved right-of-way, whether caliche or asphalt, having no legal or official name, other than an alley of 20 feet or less in width. The term "residential alley" shall mean any alley located within a residential area or designated on the city zoning map or located in an area where residential-type structures are located. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or drive any vehicle on any residential alley within the city at a speed greater than ten miles per hour. This speed limit shall be enforceable whether or not signs are erected designating such speed in accordance with this article. 
(Code 1966, § 29-73)  
Secs. 102-191—102-200. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - TRUCK ROUTES 
 
Sec. 102-201. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Hazardous material means a substance or material, including a hazardous substance, which has been designated as such under 49 U.S. Code Section 5103 and determined by the United States Secretary of Transportation to be capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health, safety, or property when transported in commerce. 
Hazardous material route means a roadway designated as such in this article and upon which hazardous materials are authorized to be transported. 
Non-radioactive hazardous material route means a roadway designated as such in this article and upon which non-radioactive hazardous materials are authorized to be transported. 
Road tractor means a motor vehicle designed or used for drawing other vehicles or loads, and not so constructed as to independently carry thereon a load or any part of the weight of the vehicle or load being drawn. 
Semi-trailer means a vehicle or trailer used or designed to be used in conjunction with a motor vehicle that carries or supports some part or all of its weight or load. 
Truck means any motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property with a manufacturer's rated gross vehicle weight exceeding 10,000 pounds, and is not intended to include those trucks commonly known as pickup trucks, panel delivery trucks, and carryall trucks. 
Truck route means a roadway designated as such in this article and upon which the operation of trucks, semi-trailers or road tractors is authorized. 
Truck traffic means vehicular traffic of trucks, semi-trailers or road tractors. 
(Code 1966, § 29-52; Ord. No. 2004-23, § 1, 3-8-04; Ord. No. 2011-09, § I, 2-28-11) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 102-202. - Truck routes established. 
(a)  Designated truck routes. All state-maintained roadways are hereby designated as truck routes, unless signed otherwise. Truck traffic on city-maintained roadways is prohibited, unless signed otherwise. 
(b)  Prohibition. The operation of any truck, semi-trailer or road tractor on any street within the city other than those streets or highways specifically designated in subsection (a) of this section is expressly prohibited as against the public health and safety, and declared to be unlawful. 
(c)  Exceptions. The prohibition set forth in this section does not apply to: 
(1)  The operation of trucks, semi-trailers and road tractors traveling on streets other than designated truck routes strictly for the purposes of pickup or delivery to specific locations, or to obtain service, repairs, lodging or fuel in the normal course of business, when there is no other alternate designated truck route of access to such location requiring a stop within the city provided that all vehicles departing from an established truck route under one of the stated exceptions shall immediately thereafter return to a designated truck route by the most direct means practical; 
(2)  Recreational vehicles and personal trailers. As used in this ordinance recreational vehicles means a vehicular portable structure designed for a temporary or short-term occupancy for travel, recreational or vacation uses, including vacation travel trailers, converted buses, tent trailers or similar devices used for temporary portable housing. As used in this section a personal trailer means a wheeled device hauled by a personal motor vehicle upon a road or highway for other than commercial purposes, including a horse trailer, dog trailer, car trailer, motorcycle trailer, boat trailer, lawn equipment trailer, gooseneck trailer, and any other trailer designed or used to carry animals, boats, large items, or motor-driven means of transportation; 
(3)  Street construction, maintenance and repair vehicles engaged in the construction, maintenance, or repair of city streets; 
(4)  Authorized emergency vehicles responding to emergency calls; 
(5)  Vehicles used or operated by the city performing city business, including transit uses, or 
(6)  Vehicles used by a city franchisee for the franchisee's approved activities. 
(d)  Affirmative defense. It is an affirmative defense to prosecution for an offense under this section that the defendant was operating the motor vehicle for a purpose specified in subsection (c) hereof. 
(e)  Signs. The traffic safety coordinator shall place and maintain traffic control signs evidencing the prohibition or permission of truck traffic on the portion or portions of roadways set out in subsection (a) of this section, which such signs shall conform to current standards as set out in the Texas Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices with regard to shape, size, color, letter size and style, mounting and location. 
(Code 1966, § 29-53; Ord. No. 2004-23, § 2, 3-8-04)  
Sec. 102-203. - Non-radioactive hazardous material routes established. 
(a)  The following roadways, approved under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 644-202, are the designated non-radioactive hazardous material routes in the City of McAllen: 
(1)  U.S. 83 Expressway between Jackson Road and Taylor Road. 
(2)  Military Highway (F.M. 1016) between 10th Street (SH 336) and Taylor Road. 
(3)  10th Street (SH 336) between Military Highway (F.M. 1016) and the southern city limit. 
(b)  Prohibition. The operation of any truck, semi-trailer or road tractor carrying non-radioactive hazardous material on any street within the city other than those streets or highways specifically designated in subsection (a) of this section; is expressly prohibited as against the public health and safety, and declared to be unlawful. 
(c)  Exceptions. The prohibition set forth in this section does not apply to the operation of such vehicle carrying non-radioactive hazardous material traveling on streets other than designated non-radioactive hazardous material routes strictly for the purposes of pickup or delivery to specific locations when there is no other alternate designated non-radioactive hazardous material truck route to such location requiring a stop within the city and provided that after such deviation that such vehicle immediately thereafter return to a designated non-radioactive hazardous material truck route by the most direct means practical. 
(Ord. No. 2004-23, § 3, 3-8-04; Ord. No. 2011-09, § I, 2-28-11) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-09, § I, adopted Feb. 28, 2011, changed the title of § 102-203 from hazardous material routes established to non-radioactive hazardous material routes established.  
Secs. 102-204—102-210. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - VULNERABLE ROAD USERS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-47, § 1, adopted June 24, 2013, set out provisions intended for use as div. 5, §§ 102-230—102-232. To avoid duplication of section numbers and to preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as div. 5, §§ 102-211—102-213. 
 
Sec. 102-211. - Definitions. 
In this division: 
Commercial motor vehicle means a motor vehicle or combination of motor vehicles used to transport passengers or property that: 
(1)  Has a gross combination weight or a gross combination weight rating of 26,001 or more pounds, including a towed unit with a gross vehicle weight or a gross vehicle weight rating of more than 10,000 pounds; 
(2)  Has a gross vehicle weight or a gross vehicle weight rating of 26,001 or more pounds; 
(3)  Is designed to transport 16 or more passengers, including the driver; or 
(4)  Is transporting hazardous materials and is required to be placarded. 
Roadway means any public right-of-way that may be used for motor vehicle traffic, including any highway, road, street or alley, and any similar or equivalent street or vehicular passageway in a private subdivision. 
Vulnerable road user means a person who is: 
(1)  A pedestrian, including a runner or physically disabled person; 
(2)  Using or operating equipment other than a motor vehicle, including, but not limited to, a bicycle, handcycle, or other type of human-powered vehicle; or 
(3)  Highway construction and maintenance worker, tow truck operator, utility worker, stranded motorist or passenger. 
(Ord. No. 2013-47, § 1, 6-24-13)  
Sec. 102-212. - Vulnerable road users—Rules of the road. 
(a)  An operator of a motor vehicle passing a vulnerable road user operating on a highway or street shall: 
(1)  If the highway has two or more marked lanes running in the same direction, vacate such lane; or 
(2)  Pass the vulnerable road user at a safe distance. 
(b)  For the purpose of subsection (a)(2), when road conditions allow, safe distance is at least: 
(1)  Three feet if the operator's vehicle is a passenger car or light truck; or 
(2)  Six feet if the operator's vehicle is a truck, other than a light truck, or a commercial motor vehicle. 
(c)  An operator of a motor vehicle that is making a left turn at a roadway intersection, including an intersection with an alley or private road or driveway, shall yield the right-of-way to a vulnerable road user who is approaching from the opposite direction and is in the intersection, or is in such proximity to the intersection as to be an immediate hazard. 
(d)  An operator of a motor vehicle may not overtake a vulnerable road user traveling in the same direction and subsequently make a turn in front of the vulnerable road user unless the operator is safely clear of the vulnerable road user and shall continue to remain safely clear throughout the course of turn, taking into account the speed at which the vulnerable road user is traveling and the braking requirements of the motor vehicle making the turn. 
(e)  An operator of a motor vehicle may not maneuver the vehicle in a manner that: 
(1)  Causes intimidation or harasses a vulnerable road user; or 
(2)  Threatens a vulnerable road user. 
(f)  An operator of a motor vehicle may not throw or project any object or substance at or against a vulnerable road user. 
(g)  An operator of a motor vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any vulnerable road user on a roadway or in an intersection of roadways. 
(h)  Vulnerable road users must use hand signals to signal their intent to stop, turn left, or turn right. The vulnerable road user must use the following signals: 
(1)  Stop - Extend the left hand and arm downward. 
(2)  Left turn - Extend the left hand and arm horizontally. 
(3)  Right turn - Extend the left hand and arm upward, or extend the right hand and arm horizontally. 
(i)  A vulnerable road user may not operate at nighttime unless equipped with the following: 
(1)  Headlamp - A lamp on the front of the user that emits a white light visible from a distance of at least 500 feet in front of the user. 
(2)  Red reflector/red lamp - A user must be equipped with either a red reflector which is visible from a distance of 300 feet from the rear of the user, or a red lamp visible from a distance of 500 feet from the rear of the user. 
(j)  A vulnerable road user operating a bicycle shall: 
(1)  Ride only on or astride a permanent and regular seat attached to the bicycle. 
(2)  Not use a bicycle to carry more persons than the bicycle is designed or equipped to carry. 
(3)  Ride as near as practicable to the right curb or edge of the roadway when moving slower than the other traffic on the roadway, unless: 
a.  The person is passing another vehicle moving in the same direction; 
b.  The person is preparing to turn left at an intersection or onto a private road or driveway; 
c.  A condition on or of the roadway, including a fixed or moving object, parked or moving vehicle, pedestrian, animal, or surface hazard prevents the person from safely riding next to the right curb or edge of the roadway; or 
d.  The person is operating a bicycle in an outside lane that is: 
1.  Less than 14 feet in width and does not have a designated bicycle lane adjacent to that lane; or 
2.  Too narrow for a bicycle and a motor vehicle to safely travel side by side. 
(4)  Be equipped with a brake capable of making a braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement. 
(5)  Not ride more than two abreast unless they are riding on a part of a roadway set aside for the exclusive operation of bicycles. 
(k)  Both the operator of a motor vehicle and vulnerable road user on a roadway or public right-of-way shall exercise due care and comply with all applicable city ordinances and state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2013-47, § 1, 6-24-13)  
Sec. 102-213. - Penalty for violation of division. 
Any person who violates any provision of this division shall, upon conviction, be fined as provided in section 1-14 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2013-47, § 1, 6-24-13)  
Secs. 102-214—102-225. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[11] 
Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Operation of vehicles and parking at the airport, § 18-76 et seq.; regulations regarding vehicles and parking in parks and recreation areas, § 74-81; wreckers, § 114-226 et seq. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate standing and parking of vehicles, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(1). 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 102-226. - Prohibited in specified places. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  Any parking place where official signs prohibiting stopping are installed or may be installed by the traffic safety coordinator. 
(2)  a.  In a fire lane established around or adjacent to any building where such area has prominently displayed thereon a sign on the pavement, a stand or other object adjacent thereto, the words "Fire Lane — Parking Prohibited," and the fire lane is clearly delineated by proper markings. No person shall be guilty of a violation of this subsection unless the fire lane is clearly marked and identified. 
b.  Within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger. It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under this subsection, if a parking space is marked within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
c.  Within 15 feet of a fire hydrant except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger. 
d.  In front of a public or private driveway except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger. 
e.  On all or part of a sidewalk. 
f.  On the roadway side of a vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(3)  On the westbound and eastbound access roads of U.S. Highway Expressway 83 from South Second Street to South Tenth Street. 
(4)  On the westbound access or frontage road of U.S. Highway Expressway 83 from the northwest corner of Tenth Street along the north curbline of such access or frontage road to the existing curb cut entrance to the civic center parking lot. 
(5)  On the east and west sides of McColl Road (F.M. 2061) from Loop 374 north to Jasmine Avenue. 
(6)  On the west and east sides of the roadway of South 33rd Street from Loop 374 South to Dallas Avenue. 
(7)  On the east side of the roadway of 17th Street (Guerra Avenue) from U.S. Business 83 to Austin Avenue. 
(8)  On the west side of the roadway of 12th Street from Lindberg Avenue to U.S. Expressway 83. 
(9)  On the south side of roadway in the 1600 through 1700 blocks of U.S. Business 83 (Loop 374). 
(10)  On the north side of frontage road westbound 2100 through 2200 U.S. Expressway 83. 
(11)  On the east and west sides of South Tenth Street (S.H. 336) between Wichita Avenue and a point 300 feet south of the intersection of South Second Street Loop and South Tenth Street. 
(12)  On the north and south sides of Dove Avenue, from North Tenth Street (State Highway 336) to 23rd Street (F.M. 1926 or Depot Road). 
(13)  On the east and west sides of Main Street, from South Frontage (U.S. 83 Expressway) to McAllen-Miller International Airport parking lot. 
(14)  On both sides of South Second Street, from Ridge Road to South Tenth Street. 
(15)  On the north and south sides of Uvalde Avenue, from South Main Street to South 23rd Street. 
(16)  On the north side of Military Highway (F.M. 1016), also known as Acapulco Avenue, from South 42nd Street, thence west 200 feet. 
(17)  On the north and south sides of Savannah Avenue between South Second Street and its intersection with Ridge Road. 
(18)  On the north and south sides of Ridge Road between South Second Street and Cynthia Street.

(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any prohibited area specified in this section or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(c)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, including a semi-trailer or truck, for the purposes of loading or unloading, during the hours from 6:00 a.m. through 12:00 p.m. on either side of 23rd Street, from Pecan Avenue to Expressway 83. 
(d)  (1)  A person commits an offense by stopping, parking or standing any motor vehicle upon a public street, alley, parkway, boulevard or public place located: (A) within or abutting any City of McAllen residentially zoned area; and (B) within one-quarter mile of a major arterial street or highway. 
(2)  This section will not apply to the following: 
a.  Residents of the geographic area described hereinabove, and their guests; 
b.  Street construction, maintenance and repair equipment;

e.  Where it is lawful to park a commercial motor vehicle for the purpose of accepting or delivering transportable goods; or 
f.  A motor vehicle with a mechanical defect, making it unsafe to proceed further, in which event, it shall be lawful to stand or park the vehicle during the time necessary to make emergency repairs, not to exceed 48 hours. 
(3)  Further, this section will not apply during any public event sponsored by the City of McAllen, including an hour before and after such an event.

No. 2016-85, § I, 12-12-16; Ord. No. 2017-02, § I, 1-23-17; Ord. No. 2018-49, § I, 7-9-18; Ord. No. 2020-10, § I, 3-9-20) 
State Law reference— Stopping, standing or parking restricted in certain places, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 95.  
Sec. 102-227. - Prohibited for certain purposes. 
No person shall park a vehicle upon any street for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing, dismantling or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Code 1966, § 29-81)  
Sec. 102-228. - Prohibited for more than 48 hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle owned by him or under his control on any street, alley or other public way in the city for a period of time in excess of 48 hours. 
(Code 1966, § 29-82)  
Sec. 102-229. - Designation and marking of parking spaces and areas where parking is prohibited or limited. 
(a)  The traffic safety coordinator shall cause parking spaces to be maintained and marked off in and on such streets and parts thereof as he may designate, and he shall cause spaces or areas in which parking is prohibited at any time, or where parking is restricted to time limits, to be marked off, identified as to type of parking allowed or prohibited, and maintained in and on such part or parts of streets. All such spaces or areas shall be clearly indicated by appropriate signs or by markings on the pavement or curb. 
(b)  In areas designated as time limit parking areas, parking may be limited to any period prescribed by the traffic safety coordinator, such areas to be designated with clearly distinguished markings or signs at both ends of the time limit area and at reasonable intervals between the beginning and ending of such time limit area, indicating the time allowed for parking in such area. 
(c)  Any prohibition of or time limit on parking established under this section shall apply on such days and between such hours as prescribed by the traffic safety coordinator. 
(Code 1966, § 29-83)  
Sec. 102-230. - Parking in prohibited areas; overtime parking. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name or owned or operated by him or in his possession or under his control to be or remain in any space or area in which parking is prohibited as provided in this division or in a time limit parking area for a longer period of time than that designated by the markings on the street or by signs clearly visible. 
(Code 1966, § 29-84)  
Sec. 102-231. - Parallel and angle parking. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall stand or park a vehicle in a roadway other than parallel with the edge of the roadway headed in the direction of lawful traffic movement and with the right-hand wheels of the vehicle within 18 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except that where a space is signed or marked, then no part of the vehicle, or any trailer, extension or projection therefrom may extend beyond the perimeter represented by the curb or edge of the roadway, the signs or markings within which the vehicle must be stopped or parked, and an imaginary line on the space's side closest to the roadway running between the ends of the signs or markings On one-way roadways, unless signs prohibit it, vehicles may also stand or be parked on the left side of the roadway, with the left-hand wheels within 18 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, and the same aforementioned exception will apply where a space is signed or marked. 
(b)  The traffic operations division shall determine upon which streets angle parking shall be permitted and shall mark or sign such streets, but such angle parking shall not be indicated upon any federal aid or state highway within this city unless the state highway engineer has determined that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic. Angle parking shall not be indicated or permitted at any place where passing traffic would thereby be caused or required to drive upon the left side of the street or upon any railway tracks. 
(c)  Upon those streets which have been signed or marked for angle parking, no person shall park or stand a vehicle other than at the angle to the curb or edge of the roadway indicated by such signs or markings. 
(d)  In any parking facility maintained by the city or upon any street where parking spaces have been marked by lines on the pavement as determined by the traffic operations division, whether for parallel or angle parking, no person shall stand or park a vehicle outside of the lines of such marked parking space in such a manner as to obstruct traffic or another parking space. 
(Code 1966, § 29-86; Ord. No. 2008-12, § 1, 2-25-08) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, § 96.  
Sec. 102-232. - Parking in alleys. 
(a)  Residence district. No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in a residence district in such a manner or under such conditions as to block the alley or leave less than ten feet of the width of the roadway available for the free movement of vehicular traffic, and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance or exit to any abutting property. 
(b)  Business district. No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in a business district and no person shall stop or stand a vehicle within an alley in a business district in such a manner or under such conditions as to block the alley or leave insufficient width of the roadway available for the free movement of vehicular traffic or to block the driveway entrance or exit to any abutting property. In no case shall a stop for loading or unloading of materials or merchandise exceed 30 minutes in an alley in a business district. 
(c)  Central Business District (CBD). No person shall park and leave unattended a vehicle within any portion of an alley in the CBD. Notwithstanding the general prohibition against parking as provided in this section, a person may stop a vehicle for loading or unloading of materials or merchandise and may remain parked while actively participating in loading or unloading operations and related activities. Any operator of a vehicle that is parked for such purposes within any portion of an alley shall remove the vehicle from the alley upon request of a peace officer or fire department personnel or a staff member of the traffic safety division. 
(Code 1966, § 29-87)  
Sec. 102-233. - Parking of wide vehicles in residential and commercial zones. 
It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any vehicle, including, but not limited to, a house trailer or mobile unit, having a width at its widest part in excess of 80 inches, to park or station such vehicle on a street of the city which is in or adjacent to any property zoned as residential or commercial property under the city's zoning ordinance, subject however, to the exception that such vehicles may be parked temporarily for loading or unloading which must be completed within a reasonable time. 
(Code 1966, § 29-88; Ord. No. 2018-36, § 1, 6-11-18) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2018-36, § 1, adopted June 11, 2018, changed the title of § 102-233 from "Parking of wide vehicles in residential zones" to read as herein set out.  
Sec. 102-234. - Parking of trucks in angle parking space. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle or truck having a designated carrying capacity in excess of one-half of one ton in any angle parking space on any street in the city. This section shall not apply to any motor vehicle or truck temporarily parked in such space for the purpose of loading or unloading furniture, fixtures or other merchandise, provided that the owner, driver or other person in charge of such motor vehicle or truck is at the location and is in the act of loading or unloading the motor vehicle or truck, and provided further that proper flares, signs or other protective signals are placed at the parked truck or vehicle for the protection of the public and persons using the street. 
(Code 1966, § 29-89)  
Sec. 102-235. - Permit to back to curb for loading or unloading. 
The traffic safety coordinator is authorized to issue special permits to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials, subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized in this section, and it shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(Code 1966, § 29-90)  
Sec. 102-236. - Loading zones. 
(a)  The traffic safety coordinator is hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones, and he shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating such loading zones and stating the hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when regulations applicable to such curb loading zones are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(d)  The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily at a place marked as a freight curb loading zone for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any motor vehicle used for the transportation of materials which is waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1966, § 29-91)  
Sec. 102-237. - Bus stops, etc. 
(a)  The traffic safety coordinator is hereby authorized and required to establish bus stops and stands for other passenger common-carrier motor vehicles on such public streets in such places and in such numbers as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. Every such bus stop or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs. 
(b)  The driver of a bus shall not park upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a bus stop, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading and unloading passengers. 
(c)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop when any such stop has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus. 
(Code 1966, § 29-92)  
Sec. 102-238. - Presumption that owner of vehicle illegally parked vehicle. 
In any prosecution charging a violation of any ordinance or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such ordinance or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(Code 1966, § 29-93)  
Secs. 102-239, 102-240. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2001-78, § 1, adopted Dec. 10, 2001, repealed §§ 102-239 and 102-240, which pertained to moving parking or standing vehicles and fees for impoundment of vehicles. See the Code Comparative Table.  
Sec. 102-241. - Issuance of citations by non-police officer personnel. 
(a)  Any parking violation citation authorized to be issued by a police officer in this chapter may also be issued by other designated and authorized agents of the traffic safety department. 
(b)  That the traffic safety coordinator may appoint any disabled person who is a citizen of the United States, is a resident of the city, and who has not previously been convicted of a felony to enforce the provisions of Texas Transportation Code, Subtitle H, Parking, Towing and Storage of Vehicles, Chapter 681, and section 102-242 of this Code. 
(c)  That each person appointed pursuant to this section shall complete an application promulgated by the traffic safety coordinator and satisfactorily complete a course of training on disabled parking enforcement. 
(d)  Any qualified disabled person so appointed shall have the power to serve citations and file charges for violation for failure to comply with V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 681, and section 102-242 of this Code, in the same manner as any law enforcement officer of the city subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  No person so appointed shall be deemed a peace officer, nor an employee of the state, the county or the city, nor receive any compensation therefrom. 
(2)  No appointed person shall be required to complete training as a peace officer. 
(3)  No appointed person shall have the power or duty to enforce other traffic or criminal laws nor have the power of arrest or commit an assault or breach of the peace in carrying out the authority hereunder. 
(4)  No appointed person shall possess or carry firearms or other weapons for the purpose of enforcing the disabled parking law. 
(5)  No appointed person shall be entitled to any indemnification from the state, the county, or the city for any injury or property damage sustained as a result of enforcement activities. Each appointed person shall specifically acknowledge that such person has no rights to any claim of injury or property damage resulting from disabled parking enforcement activities. 
(6)  No government, agency, department or officer of the state, the county or the city shall be liable or accountable for any act or omission of any person appointed to issue disabled parking citations pursuant to this section. Each authorized person shall specifically hold harmless the city, its employees, officers, and agents, from liability for any such act or omission by such authorized person. 
(Code 1966, § 29-95; Ord. No. 1994-2, § I, 1-10-94; Ord. No. 1995-44, § I, 8-28-95; Ord. No. 2004-51, § 1, 6-28-04)  
Sec. 102-242. - Designation of parking spaces and areas for exclusive use of vehicles transporting disabled persons. 
(a)  The city engineer or his or her designee is hereby authorized to designate any parking space or area on any public street or in any parking lot maintained by the city for public use for the exclusive use of properly designated vehicles transporting temporarily or permanently disabled persons. Vehicles used for transporting disabled persons as provided for under this section shall meet the registration requirements of Chapter 502 Subchapter F, Transportation Code and such parking areas shall be marked as required by subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The city engineer or his or her designee is hereby authorized and directed to establish rules and regulations setting out the minimum dimensions and identification markers for delineating exclusive parking spaces for vehicles transporting temporary or permanently disabled persons, which such rules shall at least comply with the rules promulgated by the state purchasing and general service commission relating thereto; provided; however, such rules may require greater designation criteria than required by the state purchasing and general service commission. A copy of such rules shall be kept on file with the city engineer or his designee, the traffic safety director and the city secretary. 
The parking spaces designated for the exclusive use of properly designated vehicles transporting temporarily or permanently disabled person shall be in compliance with: 
(1)  Section 5(c), Article 9102, V.A.C.S.; 
(2)  Texas Accessibility Standards (TAS); 
(3)  Transportation Code Subtitle H, Parking, Towing, and Storage of Vehicles, Chapter 681, 
as such laws or regulations exist or may hereinafter be amended. A copy of the current laws or regulation aforementioned laws or regulations shall be kept on file with the city engineer or his or her designee, the traffic safety director and the city secretary. 
(c)  Any person who owns or controls private property used for parking of motor vehicles in accordance with article VII of chapter 138 of the McAllen Code, may designate one or more uncovered parking spaces or areas on such property for the exclusive use of vehicles transporting temporary or permanently disabled persons by designating and identifying such parking spaces according to the standards established under subsection (b) of this section relating to the identification requirements for handicapped parking. 
The city engineer or his designee is hereby authorized and directed to issue city approval to each such space or area exclusively designated for handicapped parking which meets the requirements as set out in subsection (b). Any person owning or controlling private property that has been designated for handicapped parking shall be eligible for inspection by the city engineer or his designee who shall cause an inspection to be made on such parking space or area, and if such parking space or area meets with the requirements as set out in subsection (b) of this section, he shall issue such approval certificate for each parking space or area so designated which shall be displayed on the parking area or space. 
(d)  Section 681.011 Transportation Code, relating to offenses for illegally parking in a parking space or parking area designated specifically for the disabled, is hereby made applicable to any parking space or parking area for the disabled in any parking space or area on any public street or in any parking areas maintained by the city for which such exclusive use is designated or on any private parking area or parking space designated for exclusive use as provided for in (c) of this chapter. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section by illegally parking in any of such areas or spaces shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed by Section 681.011 Transportation Code. 
(Ord. No. 2000-42, § 1, 5-22-00)  
Sec. 102-243. - Penalties for violations of article. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as prescribed by section 1-14. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this article, as applicable, may voluntarily deposit the notice of violation of the ticket provided in this article along with the following fine, depending on the type of the violation: 
(1)  Parked overtime: 
If paid before 6:30 p.m. the next day .....$4.00 
After 6:30 p.m. the next day .....7.00 
(2)  Parked in no parking zone .....15.00 
(3)  Parked out of lines .....15.00 
(4)  Parked in loading zone .....15.00 
(5)  Blocking crosswalk .....15.00 
(6)  Blocking alley .....15.00 
(7)  Parked within 20 fee of intersection .....15.00 
(8)  Parked over 18 inches from curb .....15.00 
(9)  Blocking driveway .....15.00 
(10)  Parked within 15 feet of fire hydrant .....15.00 
(11)  Blocking sidewalk .....15.00 
(12)  Double parking .....15.00 
Such deposit as provided in this subsection shall thereby exempt such person from the penalty provided for such violation in this section, and under such circumstances the penalty for such violation shall be a fine as provided in this subsection. Any person who voluntarily deposits such amount in U.S. currency, as provided in this section, shall be deemed to have entered a plea of guilty to such violation and tendered payment of the fine provided in this section. 
(c)  If the $4.00 fine for overtime parking is not deposited as set forth in subsection (b) of this section in the traf-o-teria box later than 6:30 p.m. on the date following such violation, the fine will be $7.00 payable at the traffic safety department within the city, provided it is paid within ten days of the date of issuance of the overtime parking citation. Thereafter, the accused will be subject to a fine upon conviction in accordance with the provisions of section 1-14 of this Code. If any of the other fines as provided for in subsection (b) of this section are not deposited within ten days of the date of issuance of the notice of violation, thereafter the accused will be subject to a fine upon conviction of not to exceed the amount as set out in section 1-14. If payment is not received or a hearing requested within 60 days of the notice of violation, the fine may be assigned to a third party for collection efforts in accordance with Article 103.0031 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. Notwithstanding the assignment of a fine to a third party, the accused retains the right to request a hearing. 
(d)  Revenues from fines paid for violations of any provision of this article within the Heart of the City shall be deposited into the Downtown Services Parking Fund established by the city for the exclusive purpose of alleviating the parking needs of the Heart of the City. 
(Code 1966, § 29-112; Ord. No. 1992-97, § I, 12-28-92; Ord. No. 1998-64, § 2, 7-13-98; Ord. No. 2001-78, § 3, 12-10-01; Ord. No. 2002-51, § 1, 8-26-02; Ord. No. 2005-95, § 2, 11-14-05; Ord. No. 2006-04, § 1, 1-16-06; Ord. No. 2008-30, § 3, 4-28-08; Ord. No. 2017-36, § I, 7-10-17)  
Sec. 102-244. - Vehicle impoundment without notice. 
A vehicle may be impounded with or without citation and without giving prior notice to its owner only under the following circumstances: 
(1)  The vehicle is impeding or likely to impede the normal flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic; 
(2)  The vehicle poses an immediate danger to the public safety; 
(3)  The vehicle is illegally parked within ten feet of a fire hydrant, 
(4)  The vehicle, without a valid designated plate or placard issued under state law, is parked in a stall or space clearly marked and designated for use by disabled persons; 
(5)  A police officer reasonably believes that the vehicle is stolen; 
(6)  A police officer reasonably believes that the vehicle or its contents constitute evidence of an offense and such impoundment is reasonably necessary to obtain or preserve such evidence; providing, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize seizure of a vehicle without a warrant where a warrant would otherwise be required; 
(7)  The vehicle was in the possession of a person taken into custody by a law enforcement officer and no other reasonable disposition of the vehicle is available, or the vehicle was in the possession of a person arrested for a felony traffic violation; 
(8)  A police officer reasonably believes that the vehicle's operator, in violation of state law, is driving while uninsured or without a valid driver's license and no other reasonable disposition of the vehicle is available; or 
(9)  The vehicle is parked in the public rights-of-way or on other publicly owned or controlled property in violation of any law, ordinance, or regulation, and there are three or more parking citations issued against the vehicle that have not been responded to, either by payment of the penalty or appearance at a hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2001-78, § 2, 12-10-01)  
Sec. 102-245. - Vehicle impoundment after notice. 
A vehicle not subject to impoundment under section 102-244 may be impounded with notice in compliance with this section. Notice of such proposed impoundment must be securely attached to and conspicuously displayed on the vehicle for a period of 72 hours prior to such impoundment. Where the vehicle's owner is ascertainable, notice must also be mailed to the owner at the address on the vehicle's registration. A vehicle may only be towed with notice for the following reasons: 
(1)  When such vehicle is parked and/or used in violation of any law, ordinance, or regulation; or 
(2)  When such vehicle is an abandoned or junked vehicle; or 
(3)  When such vehicle is so mechanically defective as to be unsafe for operation, provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to prevent the operation of any such defective vehicle to a place for correction of defective equipment in the manner directed by a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 2001-78, § 2, 12-10-01)  
Sec. 102-246. - Notice of impoundment. 
(a)  After a vehicle has been towed pursuant to this division, notice shall be provided to the registered owner(s) and any other person(s) who reasonably appear to have an interest in the vehicle. Notice will be mailed to such person(s) within 24 hours after the towing of the vehicle, Saturdays, Sundays and holidays excluded, and will state: 
(1)  That the vehicle has been towed, and a description of that vehicle, including the make, model, color, year, license, and vehicle identification number; 
(2)  The location of the vehicle and that it may be reclaimed only upon evidence that the claimant is the owner or person entitled to possession; 
(3)  The address and telephone number of the person or facility that may be contacted for information on the charges that must be paid before the vehicle will be released and the procedures for obtaining the release of the vehicle; 
(4)  That the vehicle and its contents are subject to a lien for the towing and storage charges, and a vehicle not claimed within 30 days after the mailing date of the notice is subject to sale by the storage facility; 
(5)  That the owner may request a hearing concerning the legality of the impoundment, and the method for requesting such a hearing; and 
(6)  An itemized statement of the administrative and parking violation fine amount due to the city at the time of notice. 
(b)  Notice need not be mailed when a vehicle does not display license plates or other identifying markings by which the registration or ownership of the vehicle can be determined, or when the identity of the owner of the vehicle is not available from the appropriate motor vehicle license and registration authority. 
(Ord. No. 2001-78, § 2, 12-10-01)  
Sec. 102-247. - Redemption of impounded vehicles. 
Vehicles impounded by the city shall be redeemed only under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Only the registered owner, or a person authorized by the registered owner, may redeem an impounded vehicle. A person redeeming an impounded vehicle must produce a valid driver's license. A vehicle impounded for reasons of unpaid parking citations or due to the driver's arrest can only be released pursuant to a written order from the police department, traffic safety office, or municipal court that all penalties, fines, or forfeitures owed by the registered owner have been satisfied by full payment or the posting of a bond pending a hearing. 
(2)  Any person redeeming a vehicle impounded by the city shall pay the towing contractor for costs of impoundment and an administrative fee and traffic fines prior to redeeming the vehicle. The administrative fee shall be for the purpose of offsetting, to the extent practicable, the cost to the city of implementing, enforcing, and administering the impounding of vehicles, and shall be deposited in an appropriate account. The administrative fee shall be $50.00 and may be refunded pursuant to section 102-250. 
(Ord. No. 2001-78, § 2, 12-10-01)  
Sec. 102-248. - Request for hearing on impoundment. 
(a)  After a vehicle has been impounded pursuant to this chapter, the registered owner(s) and any other person(s) who reasonably appear to have an interest in the vehicle are entitled to request a hearing to contest the validity of the impoundment of the vehicle. The request for a hearing must be in writing and will state the grounds upon which the person requesting the hearing believes the impoundment invalid or unjustified, and such other information as the municipal court judge may require. 
(b)  The municipal court judge shall set and conduct an administrative hearing on the matter within 14 days of receipt of a proper request filed pursuant to this section, except where a vehicle has not yet been released from impoundment, in which case the municipal court judge will set and conduct the hearing within 72 hours of receipt of the request, not including Saturdays, Sundays, or federally sanctioned holidays. 
(c)  The owner(s) and any other person(s) who have an interest in the vehicle are only entitled to one hearing for each tow of that vehicle. Any person who fails to appear at the hearing without good cause will not be entitled to have such hearing rescheduled. 
(Ord. No. 2001-78, § 2, 12-10-01)  
Sec. 102-249. - Hearing procedure. 
(a)  The hearing shall afford a reasonable opportunity for person(s) to demonstrate by the statements of witnesses and other evidence that the impoundment of the vehicle was invalid or unjustified. The municipal court judge shall establish the necessary rules and regulations regarding the conduct of such hearings. 
(b)  The municipal court judge shall determine whether the impoundment was proper and whether the removal, towing, storage, parking violation fines and administrative fees were proper. The municipal court judge has discretion to consolidate the impoundment hearing and the parking citation hearing. 
(Ord. No. 2001-78, § 2, 12-10-01)  
Sec. 102-250. - Result of hearing. 
(a)  If the municipal court judge finds that the impoundment of the vehicle was invalid or unjustified, the municipal court judge will order the vehicle to be immediately released, and the owner(s) or any other person(s) who have an interest in the vehicle shall not be held liable for any tow and/or storage charges. If the costs of impoundment, the administrative fee and parking violation fine have already been paid, the municipal court judge shall enter judgment against the city in the amount of the costs of impoundment and administrative fee, and if applicable the parking violation fine. 
(b)  If the municipal court judge finds that the impoundment of the vehicle was valid and justified, the municipal court judge will order that the vehicle continue to be held until all fee charges and fine charges are paid. The city will be responsible in cases where the impoundment is valid and justified for charges that have accrued from the date that the hearing was requested to be held hereunder. 
(c)  Unless the hearings are consolidated by the municipal court judge, no determination of facts made at a hearing under this section shall have any collateral estoppel effect on subsequent criminal prosecution and shall not preclude litigation of those same facts in a subsequent criminal prosecution. 
(d)  The decision of the municipal court judge shall be the final decision by the city. Any person aggrieved by a decision may file a petition for judicial review in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided in paragraphs (a) and (b) above, the city shall have no liability for damage that may be caused by removal of a vehicle or for any towing or storage fees. 
(Ord. No. 2001-78, § 2, 12-10-01)  
Secs. 102-251—102-255. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PARKING METERS 
 
Sec. 102-256. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Operator means and includes every individual who shall operate a vehicle as the owner thereof or as the agent, employee or permittee of the owner. 
Park or parking means the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers or merchandise. 
Parking lot means any lot, piece, parcel or tract of land owned, leased or operated by the city for the purpose of providing parking spaces for vehicles and which has been duly designated as a parking meter zone as provided in this division. 
Traf-o-teria box means any box or container erected, installed and maintained by the city for use by the public in depositing in such box or container the notice of violation and money. 
Vehicle means any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported upon a street or highway. 
(Code 1966, § 29-100) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 102-257. - Meter zones.

(2)  Offstreet parking meter zones. The following parking meter zones are hereby established for offstreet parking areas:
