The area immediately east of the Old Federal Building found within Lots 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14, Block 29, original townsite of McAllen, Hidalgo County, Texas, and bounded on the north by Chicago Avenue, on the south by the north lot line of Lot 15, and on the east by the west rights-of-way of an alley. 
f.  The area found within Lot 3, Block 29, original townsite of McAllen, Hidalgo County, Texas, and bounded on the north by the north lot line of Lot 3, on the south by the south lot line of Lot 3, on the east by the west rights-of-way of South Broadway Avenue, and on the west by the east rights-of-way of an existing alley. 
(b)  The following described area is no longer an onstreet parking meter zone and shall be deleted from the map referenced in subsection (c) of this section: 
The streets surrounding and adjacent to Archer Park on the park side only, that is, North Main Street and North Broadway between Ash and Beech Avenues, and Ash Avenue and Beech Avenue between North Broadway and North Main Street. 
(c)  The parking meter zones, both onstreet and offstreet, described in this section are designated on the map which is on file in the office of the traffic safety coordinator. 
(Code 1966, § 29-101)  
Sec. 102-258. - Installation; adjustment, etc., of meters. 
(a)  The city manager, or such other officers or employees of the city as he may select, is hereby authorized to install and maintain, or cause to be installed and maintained, parking meters in and on such parts of the parking meter zones, the installation and maintenance of which meters are or may be authorized by the board of commissioners from time to time; and the city manager shall provide for the regulation, control, operation and maintenance of such parking meters in good workable condition. One parking meter shall be placed or set upon the curb alongside of or next to each of the parking spaces designated on a public street, as provided in this article, or, if such parking space is on a parking lot, such meter shall be placed alongside of or at the inside end of such parking space, and shall be so set as to show or display a signal showing whether the parking space alongside of or next to such parking space is or is not legally in use. Each parking meter shall be installed and set to display upon the deposit of two twenty-five-cent coins (quarters) of the United States therein, a signal indicating legal parking for that period of time conforming to a limit of parking time and charge therefor which is established by this division, which signal shall continue to operate from the time of deposit of such coins therein until the expiration of the time fixed for which such deposited coins are payment. Each parking meter shall also be so arranged that upon the expiration of such legal parking time, it will indicate by a mechanical operation and dropping or appearance of proper signal, that the lawful parking period fixed by this division has expired. 
(b)  No parking meter shall be installed in any loading zone established pursuant to section 102-236. 
(Code 1966, § 29-102; Ord. No. 2006-04, § 2, 1-16-06; Ord. No. 2006-122, § 1, 12-11-06)  
Sec. 102-259. - Installation, location, of traf-o-teria boxes. 
The city manager shall cause to be erected in any parking meter zone one or more traf-o-teria boxes. Such traf-o-teria boxes shall be conspicuously located on each parking lot and in each block of a street designated as a parking meter zone and shall have the words "Traf-O-Teria Box" plainly painted thereon. 
(Code 1966, § 29-103)  
Sec. 102-260. - Designation of and manner of parking in metered parking spaces. 
(a)  In the parking meter zone, the city manager and traffic safety coordinator are authorized to cause parking spaces to be designated and maintained. All spaces for parking of vehicles shall be designated by white lines or marks painted on the surface of the street or the parking lot, laid out at an angle to the curb or parallel to the curb, if on a public street, and shall be so laid out that there shall be one parking space for and immediately adjacent to each parking meter. 
(b)  Any vehicle parked in any parking space on a public street in a parking meter zone shall be parked at an angle to the curb or parallel to the curb, as the case may be, and shall be parked wholly within the lines marked on the streets for such parking space as provided in this division. Any vehicle parked in a parking space on a parking lot shall also be parked wholly within the lines marked for such parking space, as provided in this division. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle across any such lines or marks or to park such vehicle in such way that the vehicle shall not be wholly within the area so designated by such lines or marks on the street or parking lot surface. 
(Code 1966, § 29-104)  
Sec. 102-261. - Time limits on parking; amount of deposit. 
The following lengths of time for parking a vehicle in a parking space, and the amounts of money charged for such lengths of time, respectively, for so using parking spaces are hereby established: 
(1)  When such parking space is located upon a public street: 
(a)  60 minutes or one hour for $0.50, and according to the markings and instructions on such meter and the mechanism therein. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any operator of a vehicle to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle in his possession or under this control to be or remain in any parking space alongside of or next to which any parking meter is placed while the meter is displaying a signal showing that such vehicle shall have already been parked beyond the period of time fixed by this division, for which payment has been made by deposit of a coin or coins in the parking meter alongside of or next to such parking space. The display of a sign showing illegal parking by any parking meter while a vehicle is parked in a parking space adjoining such parking meter shall be prima facie evidence that the vehicle has been parked overtime and beyond the period of time fixed by this division. 
(2)  When such parking space is located upon a city owned or leased parking lot: 
a.  Each 60 minutes or one hour for $0.50 up to a limit of ten hours. 
(Code 1966, § 29-105; Ord. No. 2001-28, § 1, 4-9-01; Ord. No. 2001-78, § 4, 12-10-01; Ord. No. 2006-04, § 3, 1-16-06; Ord. No. 2006-122, § 2, 12-11-06)  
Sec. 102-262. - Deposit required; overtime parking; parking adjacent to expired meter. 
(a)  When any vehicle shall be parked in any place alongside of or next to which there is located, under this division, a parking meter, the operator of such vehicle shall, upon entering such marked parking space, immediately deposit one of the coins indicated on the meter for the length of time desired in accordance with the directions or instructions on each particular meter, in the slot made therefor. The coin shall be deposited in the parking meter alongside of or next to the parking space, and the parking space may then be used by such vehicle during the parking time limit for which such deposited coin is payment, as provided by this division. The failure to deposit such coin shall be unlawful and a violation of this division. Further parking time may be secured after expiration of the time secured by deposit of the first coin, by immediately depositing an additional coin or coins in such meter, not to exceed a continuous elapsed parking time of two hours, if such parking space is located upon a public street. If the vehicle shall remain parked in any such parking space beyond the parking time limit for which such deposited coin or coins is payment, the parking meter shall display a sign showing illegal parking, and in that event, such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and beyond the period of time fixed by this division, and such overtime parking of a vehicle shall be a violation of this division and punished as set out in this division. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any operator of a vehicle to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle in his possession or under his control to be or remain in any parking space alongside of or next to which any parking meter is placed while the meter is displaying a signal showing that such vehicle shall have already been parked beyond the period of time fixed by this division, for which payment has been made by deposit of a coin or coins in the parking meter alongside of or next to such parking space. The display of a sign showing illegal parking by any parking meter while a vehicle is parked in a parking space adjoining such parking meter shall be prima facie evidence that the vehicle has been parked overtime and beyond the period of time fixed by this division. 
(c)  After a notice of a violation of this section has been attached to any vehicle pursuant to this chapter, each additional hour thereafter during which such vehicle remains in such parking space in violation of the provisions of this section shall constitute a separate offense for which an additional notice shall be attached to such vehicle. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall apply on all days other than legal holidays and Sundays, but only between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
(Code 1966, § 29-106)  
Sec. 102-263. - Use of metered spaces for loading or unloading. 
It shall be unlawful for any operator of a vehicle to stop or park the vehicle in a parking space for which a parking meter has been installed under this division, for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise, supplies or materials, except where the place of business for which the vehicle is to be loaded or unloaded does not have either a usable entrance from an adjoining alley or an officially designated loading zone on that part of the street adjacent to such place of business. Where there is neither a usable entrance from an alley to a place of business nor an officially designated loading zone on that part of the street adjacent to such place of business, the operator of a vehicle may, without making the deposit required by this division, use not to exceed two parking spaces for loading or unloading at such place of business, for the length of time necessary to expeditiously load or unload the vehicle and give or secure delivery receipts therefor. It shall be unlawful for any operator to use more than two parking spaces for such loading or unloading or for a longer time than necessary to expeditiously load or unload and give or secure a delivery receipt therefor. 
(Code 1966, § 29-107)  
Sec. 102-264. - Parking of trucks or trailers in meter zones. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any operator in charge or control of any vehicle which has an overall length of 20 feet or more, or any vehicle having a trailer attached thereto, to park such vehicle in any parking meter space in a parking meter zone. This subsection shall not prohibit the parking of a motor truck for the purpose of loading or unloading as permitted under section 102-263. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any operator or other person to park a motor vehicle or truck having a designated carrying capacity in excess of one-half ton upon a parking lot designated as a parking meter zone. 
(c)  The provisions of this section apply on all days and on all hours of both daytime and nighttime. 
(Code 1966, § 29-108)  
Sec. 102-265. - Deposit of slugs prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug, device or substitute for a coin of the United States. 
(Code 1966, § 29-109)  
Sec. 102-266. - Defacing, injuring, tampering with, etc., meters. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the provisions of this division. It shall also be unlawful for any person to attempt to deface, injure, tamper with, open or wilfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the provisions of this division. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except a police officer of the city, to strike, hit, beat, tamper with, or attempt to strike, hit, beat or tamper with any parking meter for the purpose of taking, removing or obtaining money from such parking meter, or for the purpose of causing such meter to register time thereon, without first depositing money in such meter in coin or coins of the United States, as provided in this division. 
(Code 1966, § 29-110)  
Sec. 102-267. - Collection and disposition of meter and traf-o-teria box funds. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the traffic safety coordinator, with the approval of the city manager, to designate personnel of his department to make regular collections of the money deposited in parking meters and traf-o-teria boxes. It shall be the duty of those persons so designated to pick up the coins as deposited in the meters and traf-o-teria boxes, and to deliver such coins to the director of finance as soon as practicable after removal from such meter or traf-o-teria box. A separate record shall be kept of funds collected from such meters and boxes on parking lots, and from meters and boxes on street parking zones. It shall be the duty of the director of finance to count the funds taken from such meters and boxes. Funds from meters and funds collected from traf-o-teria boxes shall be deposited to the general fund of the city. 
(b)  Revenues from parking meters on parking lot zones within the Heart of the City shall be applied first to the cost of meters within the Heart of the City, their maintenance, supervision of the property lying therein, and the cost of improvements thereon, after which any revenues will be deposited into the Heart of the City Parking Fund, a fund established by the city for the exclusive purpose of alleviating the parking needs of the Heart of the City. 
(c)  Each person designated to collect money from parking meters and traf-o-teria boxes shall, if directed by the city manager to do so, execute a fiduciary bond in the sum of $1,000.00 payable to the city, conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties in collecting and delivering all such monies, which bond shall be executed by a corporate surety duly authorized under the laws of the state to execute such bonds. The premiums for such bonds shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1966, § 29-111; Ord. No. 2005-95, § 3, 11-14-05)  
Secs. 102-268—102-280. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PUBLIC PARKING LOTS 
 
Sec. 102-281. - Texas Uniform Act regulating traffic made applicable to parking lots. 
There is hereby adopted and made applicable to all parking lots in the city the Texas Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, codified as Chapters 541 through 552 of the Texas Transportation Code, and such act is hereby made applicable to private property commonly used by the public, such as supermarket or shopping center parking lots, parking areas provided for business establishments for the convenience of their customers, clients or patrons, parking lots owned and operated by the state, or any other parking area owned and operated for the convenience of and commonly used by the public, including but not limited to the common parking areas of multi-family housing areas. 
(Code 1966, § 19-10; Ord. No. 2004-51, § 1, 6-28-04)  
Sec. 102-282. - Statement of public policy; acts prohibited. 
(a)  Applicability and public purpose statement. As used in this section, the term "parking lot" shall mean any area in, at or adjacent to a restaurant, drive-in restaurant, store retail or whole-sale business establishment, office building, professional building, recreational building, multi-family residential area, referred to in this section as a premises, or any public building or space used, designed or intended for the parking of any type of vehicle, including motor vehicles, by members of the general public, and maintained for the convenience of customers, clients, patients, members or patrons of one or more business establishments, public offices or organizations. 
(b)  Prohibited acts. The following acts or conduct of any person upon entering, driving on, parking on or leaving any parking lot are hereby declared to be unlawful, and any person found guilty of any such act or conduct shall be guilty of a misdemeanor: 
(1)  To enter a parking lot in a motor vehicle of any kind and use such parking lot for racing or as a shortcut to other property or a street. 
(2)  To race the motor of any vehicle, needlessly bring to a sudden start or stop any vehicle, blow the horn of such vehicle needlessly, or to create any loud or unseemly noise, nuisance or disturbance whereby the quiet and good order of the premises or the adjacent neighborhood are disturbed. 
(3)  For two or more persons to congregate inside or outside of a motor vehicle parked thereon, when not otherwise engaged in a lawful pursuit relating to the use of the premises and without the owner's consent. 
(4)  To throw, deposit, leave or permit to come to rest upon any parking lot any litter, except in the receptacles provided for such litter, as set forth in this division. Litter is defined as any trash; paper; napkins; straws; cups or containers made of paper, plastic or other similar material; bottles; glass; candy or gum wrappers; remnants of food; cans or remnants or parts thereof or any material of an insanitary nature. 
(5)  To leave a motor vehicle unattended on a parking lot, except for the purpose of entering into a premises, or returning therefrom, except with the consent and approval of the owner or operator or manager of such parking lot. 
For the purposes of this section, the fact that a premises is closed shall constitute prima facie proof that a person is not engaged in a lawful pursuit relating to the use of the premises. Furthermore, if any parking lot is clearly marked by any sign or device declaring time limits or other restrictions relating to parking, then a violation by any person of such restrictions shall be prima facie proof of such owner's nonconsent to any person parking or congregating on such parking lot. 
(Code 1966, § 19-23; Ord. No. 2004-51, § 1, 6-28-04)  
Sec. 102-283. - Duties of owner, lessee, manager or operator. 
It is hereby declared to be the duty of the owner, lessee, manager or operator of a drive-in restaurant or parking lot to: 
(1)  Provide on the premises not less than one receptacle for the receipt of litter, readily accessible and available to the customers, patrons or users of such business or parking lot. If more than one receptacle is required in order to hold all of the litter that may be placed therein, then it shall be the duty of the owner, lessee, manager or operator to furnish such additional number of receptacles as is reasonably necessary under normal conditions to hold such litter. 
(2)  Maintain quiet and good order upon the premises, and to prohibit disorderly or immoral conduct or lingering or loitering thereon, and to prohibit noise or nuisances thereon. 
(3)  Clean the premises and to remove all litter therefrom and place such litter within receptacles within one hour after the daily closing time of any business located on or in connection with such parking lot. If the business operates continuously without closing, then the owner or operator shall clean the premises and remove all litter therefrom at least twice a day, between the hours of 11:00 a.m. and noon, and between 11:00 p.m. and midnight. It shall further be the duty of the owner, lessee, manager or operator to prevent any litter from blowing upon or being permitted to come to rest upon the streets of the city or upon any public or private property. 
(Code 1966, § 19-24)  
Sec. 102-284. - Authority to remove vehicles. 
(a)  The owner, lessee, manager or operator of any drive-in restaurant or parking lot shall have the right to tow away or cause to be towed away from any such parking lot any vehicle which has been left there unattended or abandoned, provided that there has been placed on such premises in a conspicuous place a sign in letters at least three inches in height, which states that any vehicle left unoccupied, unattended or abandoned on the parking lot shall be towed away at the cost of the owner thereof. 
(b)  Any person whose vehicle has been towed away pursuant to this section shall, in order to redeem or repossess such vehicle, pay the towing charges, not to exceed the maximum rate of fees authorized to be charged for such services under chapter 114, article V of this Code. 
(Code 1966, § 19-25)  
Sec. 102-285. - Penalty for violation of division. 
The penalty upon conviction for a violation of this division shall be as prescribed in section 1-4. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1966, § 19-26)  
Secs. 102-286—102-305. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PARADES AND PROCESSIONS 
 
Sec. 102-306. - Title. 
This article shall be known and may be cited as the parade ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(a))  
Sec. 102-307. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Parade means any parade, march, ceremony, show, exhibition, pageant, pedestrian race, run, marathon or walkathon, or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, park or other public place in the city. 
Parade permit means a permit as required by this article. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(b)) 
Cross reference— Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 102-308. - Parade permit. 
(a)  Required. No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the city manager. 
(b)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions. 
(2)  Students going to and from school classes or participating in educational activities, provided such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities. 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(c)  Application. A person seeking issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the city secretary's office on forms provided by such office. 
(1)  Filing period. Unless for good cause shown, an application for a parade permit shall be filed with the city manager not less than 20 days nor more than 60 days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. 
(2)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade. 
b.  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
d.  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the city secretary a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
e.  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
f.  The hours when such parade will start and terminate. 
g.  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly areas. 
h.  The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point. 
i.  The location by streets of any assembly and disassembly areas for such parade. 
j.  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals, and description of the vehicles. 
k.  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
l.  The interval of space to be maintained between units of such parade. 
m.  Any additional information which the city manager shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether or not a permit should be issued. 
(3)  Continuing application. An applicant may file one application for a number of recurring parades within the same calendar year where the applicant is able to demonstrate that the events are essentially the same format and are to be held on certain dates. The city manager may issue one permit for all such events. 
(4)  Fee. A fee of $20.00 shall be paid at the time an application for a parade permit is filed. However, for applications requesting expedited processing (less than five days), a single fee of $25.00 shall be paid at the time of application for a parade permit is filed. 
(d)  Notice to city and other officials. Upon receipt of a parade permit application, the city secretary shall send a copy thereof to the following officials for their review and recommendations: 
(1)  Chief of police. 
(2)  City attorney. 
(3)  Fire chief. 
(4)  Director of the department of public works. 
(5)  Director of parks and recreation. 
(6)  Traffic safety coordinator. 
(7)  Risk manager. 
The city secretary shall thereafter forward the original application and recommendations to the city manager for his consideration. 
(e)  Standards for issuance. The city manager shall issue a permit as provided for under this article when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. The city manager, at the expense of the applicant, may require the provision of barricades and/or the provision of police or security personnel at the expense of the applicant to ensure the protection and safety of persons and property as a condition of granting such permit. 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provide disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(8)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. 
(f)  Notice of rejection. Within two business days following the city secretary's receipt of all the recommendations from the officials referred to in subsection (d) hereof, the city manager shall act upon the application for a parade permit and cause the city secretary, within two business days of his decision, to issue the permit or, if denied, to mail to the applicant a notice stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(g)  Appeal procedure. Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of a parade permit to the board of commissioners. The appeal shall be taken within three days after denial by filing a notice of appeal with the board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall act upon the appeal at the next regular meeting of the board of commissioners at which notice requests under state law can be met. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(c)—(h); Ord. No. 2006-103, § 6, 10-9-06; Ord. No. 2016-58, § I, 9-26-16; Ord. No. 2016-58, § II, 9-26-16)  
Sec. 102-309. - Alternative permit. 
The city manager, in denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within three days after notice of the action of the city manager, file a written notice of acceptance with the city manager. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of, a parade permit under this article. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(i))  
Sec. 102-310. - Contents of permit. 
Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Date and starting and ending time. 
(2)  Type of parade activity authorized. 
(3)  Special limitations or conditions required. 
(4)  Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the parade. 
(5)  The starting and ending areas and the portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(6)  The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof. 
(7)  The name of the parade chairperson. 
(8)  Such other information as the city manager shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(j))  
Sec. 102-311. - Duties of permittee. 
A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(k))  
Sec. 102-312. - Possession of permit. 
The parade chairperson or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(l))  
Sec. 102-313. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(b)  Driving through parades. No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(c)  Parking on parade route. The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police may post signs or take other action to notify the public to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. 
(d)  Handouts prohibited. No person shall throw, give or offer any material, candy, pamphlets or any other article as a participant in a parade to any spectators viewing such parade. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(m))  
Sec. 102-314. - Compliance with permit conditions. 
It shall be illegal for any person issued a permit under this article to violate the terms thereof. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(o))  
Sec. 102-315. - Revocation of permit. 
The city manager shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this article upon violation of the standards for issuance as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1966, § 29-16(n))  
Sec. 102-316. - Identification of funeral processions. 
A funeral procession shall be identified as such by the display upon the outside of each vehicle therein of a pennant or other identifying insignia or by such other method as may be determined and designated by the police department. 
(Code 1966, § 29-17)  
Sec. 102-317. - Driving in processions. 
Each driver in a funeral or other procession of vehicles shall drive as near to the righthand edge of the roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1966, § 29-47)  
Sec. 102-318. - Driving between vehicles in processions. 
No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this article. This section shall not apply at intersections where traffic is controlled by traffic control signals or police officers. 
(Code 1966, § 29-48)  
Chapter 106 - UTILITIES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 106-1. - Trespass on canal and right-of-way of Hidalgo County Water Improvement District No. Three. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except when legally authorized, to enter or trespass upon the canal and right-of-way of Hidalgo County Water Improvement District Number Three within the city, and particularly, but not limited to, that part thereof enclosed by a cyclone-type fence, such canal and right-of-way being that property located parallel to and west of 18th Street and its projections within the city and commonly known as Hidalgo County Water Improvement District Number Three canal and canal right-of-way. Exception is made within such right-of-way as to the areas thereof which have been dedicated for public use as street and walk rights-of-way. 
(b)  Appropriate signs and markers, including no trespass signs, in connection with the provisions and intent of this section shall be appropriately placed on the property described in subsection (a) of this section to designate the prohibited area. 
(Code 1966, § 30-7)  
Secs. 106-2—106-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC UTILITY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-27, § II, adopted May 8, 2017, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II, §§ 106-26—106-31, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1966, §§ 30-1; 30-2(a), 30-3, 30-4; Ord. No. 1992-96, § II, adopted Dec. 32,1992; Ord. No. 2002-69, § 1, adopted Oct. 14, 2002; and Ord. No. 2009-12, § I, 2-23-09). 
Cross reference— Meetings of the public utility board of trustees, § 2-45; boards, committees and commissions, § 2-76 et seq.; procedure for appointment and terms and qualifications of board members, § 2-77; substantial evidence rule in effect regarding appeals from decisions of board, committees and commissions, § 2-82; the planning and zoning commission and the public utility board shall make recommendation regarding any amendments to the subdivision ordinance, § 134-3. 
 
Sec. 106-26. - Appointment of members; rights and duties. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority contained in Vernon's Ann. Civ. St., art. 1115, Tex. Water Code § 13.001-13.515 and as provided in the revenue bond ordinances of the city for water and sewer utility improvements, the complete management and control of the sewer, water system and reclaimed water of the city is vested in a board of trustees known as the Board of Trustees of the McAllen Public Utility and referred to in this chapter as the "public utility board." The members of the public utility board shall be elected as provided for in the ordinances providing for the issuance of revenue bonds for the water and utility system. The rights and duties of the public utility board shall be as set out in the water and sewer utility bond ordinances subject to amendment by the board of commissioners, amending such bond ordinances by providing for additional water and sewer revenue bonds or by the amendment of the Code of Ordinances; all such amendments are subject to the rights of all and any outstanding water and sewer utility bondholders. 
(b)  The members of the public utility board, as provided in this section, except for the place reserved for the mayor as member of the public utility board, shall be denominated as place "A", place "B", place "C", and place "D" for the purposes of the election thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-27. - Appointment of officers and employees. 
The public utility board shall appoint and employ all officers and employees which it may deem desirable and necessary in the operation of the water, reclaimed water and sewer system. The utility manager, upon the advice and consent of the public utility board, shall act as manager of the utility system. To the extent practicable, the board shall utilize the personnel and facilities of the city to reduce the expenses of maintaining and operating the utility system. All such services shall be rendered by the city on an actual cost basis to the McAllen Utility Systems. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-28. - Duties and responsibilities of utility manager. 
In carrying out the duties of utility manager of the water, reclaimed water and sewer utility system, the utility manager shall, to the extent practicable, follow the provisions of and have the duties and responsibilities as required under his position as utility manager as set out in section 2-211 et seq. In carrying out such duties, the utility manager shall be under the control of the public utility board. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-29. - Joint purchases and expenditures with the city. 
In carrying out the duties of utility manager of the utility system, it is recognized that it is often advantageous and expedient to provide for joint purchases and/or expenditures by the city and the utility system for certain goods and services rendered to those entities. It is hereby provided that, prior to the entering into of any contract or the letting of any bid by the board of commissioners, wherein such contract or expenditures includes the expenditure by the water, reclaimed water and sewer utility system, that such item shall be referred to and presented to the public utility board for their approval, concurrence and recommendation. At the time of the presentation before the public utility board, the proposed proration formula for the payment on the expenditure between the city and the utility system shall be presented to the public utility board. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-30. - Continuation of prior ordinances, etc. 
The codification of the provisions relating to the public utility board, as set out in this chapter, shall neither enlarge nor diminish the duties, powers, and authority of the public utility board as heretofore provided for in those certain presently outstanding bond ordinances providing for the issuance of water and sewer revenue bonds as heretofore passed by the board of commissioners. The action of the board of commissioners in setting out the provisions relating to the public utility board in this chapter does not create any legal interest or rights not heretofore vested in such public utility board or the board of commissioners relating to the operation of the public utility system or the means of purchases or expenditures for the city or the public utility system. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-31. - Agenda. 
(a)  All reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, contract documents, petitions or other matters submitted by appointed officials of the city or public utility system, to be considered by the public utility board shall be submitted to the utility manager's office for approval not later than five working days prior to the meeting in which the matter will be heard. The utility manager or the utility board chairman shall have the authority to waive this requirement. 
(b)  Any two utility board members or the chairman may place items on the agenda by giving the utility manager written notice concerning such item by requesting that an item be placed on the next board meeting agenda, or a request to place an item on a subsequent agenda may be made during a meeting of the board. 
(c)  In the case of an item which has been requested by a person not being an elected or appointed official of the city or public utility system, then in such case such items shall be placed in the informational section of the next available utility board agenda. Such item may only be made a regular agenda item upon the majority vote of the utility board members, subject to the provisions of the Texas Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Secs. 106-32—106-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WATER[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2017-27, § II`, adopted May 8, 2017, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. III, §§ 106-51, 106-52,106-66—106-71, 106-81—106-87, 106-101—106-104, 106-116—106-125 pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Cross reference— Plumbing code adopted, § 22-136 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 106-51. - Establishment of rules and regulations for water service. 
The public utility board is authorized and directed to establish such rules, regulations and conditions from time to time for the furnishing of water and reclaimed water to customers as in its judgment shall be proper. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-52. - Public utility department to pay street rental. 
(a)  The public utility department shall be charged, as a rental for the use of the streets, alleys, highways, easements and public places within the city, a sum equal to two percent of the gross receipts of such department received from business conducted within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  The rental charged to the public utility department under subsection (a) shall be computed and paid annually on March 15 of each and every year for the preceding year, and shall be paid to the city tax collector. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Secs. 106-53—106-65. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 106-66. - Prohibited connections and/or line taps. 
(a)  It shall be illegal for any person, corporate or otherwise, or any business enterprise, for profit or otherwise, to connect or tap into a city water service line or city reclaimed water service line prior to having first applied for a water meter or a reclaimed water meter from the city's planning department. This prohibition shall apply with equal force to connections or tappings into fire hydrant plugs, mains, and/or lines. 
(b)  In the case of building construction, residential or otherwise, the application shall have been presented to the city's planning department prior to the placement of such construction's building foundation. 
(c)  A fee of $50.00 for the first occurrence shall be charged in addition to any fines resulting from illegal connections or tappings as set out in this section. Repeat offenders will be charged a fee of $500.00 per occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17; Ord. No. 2018-65, § I, 9-24-18; Ord. No. 2018-65, § I, 9-24-18)  
Sec. 106-67. - Notice of proposed connections. 
In the case of connections into a fire hydrant plug, main or line, it shall be the applicant's responsibility to notify the city's utility department of the proposed connection and/or tap. The notification shall be in writing, and shall state therein the exact location of such connection and/or tap as well as its reasonably expected period of use. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-68. - Approval of connections; termination. 
(a)  No connection and/or tap into any fire hydrant plug, main or line shall be allowed unless the following enumerated conditions have been met, namely: 
(1)  The applicant receives a written approval by the city's utility department agent-in-charge as to such proposal and its particulars; and 
(2)  A fee is paid by the applicant in the amount then applicable, payable at the city's utilities department and prior to the installation of a water meter or reclaimed water meter. 
(b)  Upon approval, as provided in this section, the connection and/or tap shall be effectuated by a utility department work crew. The fee, as provided for in this section, shall also be applicable whenever the established connection and/or tap is subsequently relocated for use by the applicant elsewhere. As is the case in the initial installment, any subsequent relocation shall be effectuated by a utility department work crew. 
(c)  Upon the termination of any connection and/or tap, it shall be the applicant's responsibility to notify the city's utility department in writing immediately after such termination. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-69. - Penalty for violation of division. 
Any person, corporate or otherwise, or any business enterprise, for profit or otherwise, who fails to comply with any provision of this division, or any of its particulars, shall be held liable for a fine as provided in section 1-14. This fine shall be exclusive of any additional charges, fines and fees which may become established for such matters as labor and replacement costs, and other pertinent charges. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-70. - Damage to fire hydrant, utility line, etc. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to negligently or intentionally damage or otherwise alter an existing "header" device, fire hydrant, main, reclaimed water main, water service utility line or reclaimed water line or any other water service utility line or similar property or device (collectively, referred to as "facility") belonging to the city in such a manner as to make such facility's future utilization impossible or unfeasible for proper usage. It shall be unlawful for any person to commence excavation work in, on or adjacent to any city road or road right-of-way or any other location where city facilities lines are reasonably anticipated to be located without contacting the engineering department of the city requesting a facility's location marking for such area of excavation. Any person who shall damage or otherwise alter any city facility as provided for in this section shall be liable in monetary damages for its replacement and repair. In any claim or cause of action by the city against any such person for monetary damages as provided for in this section, the failure by any such person to request a facility location marking from the city engineer's office shall constitute a prima facie case of negligence by such person in the damage of such city facility. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-71. - Costs assessed for repair of damaged facilities. 
(a)  Whenever any person causes a break or damage to any existing facility as provided for in section 106-70, there is hereby imposed, and such person shall be liable to the city for payment for loss of water or reclaimed water resulting in such break and/or damage of such facility and the cost of repairs as follows: 
(1)  Damage to a six-inch water line, six-inch reclaimed water line or smaller (water or reclaimed water loss), plus actual time and materials for repair .....$65.00 
(2)  Each additional inch of pipe size above six inches, per inch .....10.00 
(b)  Any person damaging or otherwise altering any city water or reclaimed water utility facility as provided for in section 106-70, shall immediately contact the city utility department at city hall if such break occurs during normal business hours, Monday through Friday, and the public utility department if such break occurs after normal business hours or on weekends, and such departments are listed in the local telephone directory. Such notification shall include the location of the damaged or broken city water or reclaimed water utility facility and any other information as required by the responding city personnel. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to give such notification as required in this subsection. 
(c)  The city finance department shall cause a bill to be prepared for any reasonable cost to repair any damages as provided for in subsection (a) of this section and shall submit the bill to the person responsible therefor, who shall remit payment therefor within ten days of the receipt of such billing or shall contact the utility manager or his authorized representative stating the reasons and lack of justification for payment of such bill. Should any such person fail to pay such bill when due, then such person shall not be eligible to receive any further city service relating to any construction site or any other similar type business of such person relating to the type of construction or excavation work for which the original damage or break to the city water or reclaimed water utility facility was caused as provided for in this division. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Secs. 106-72—106-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - RATES AND CHARGES 
 
Sec. 106-81. - Rate schedules established. 
There are hereby established four schedules of rates to be charged for the consumption of water supplied through the city water system, as follows: 
(1)  Standard water rate schedule within the city for City of McAllen customers under the city's certificate of convenience and necessity. 
(2)  Standard water rate schedule for areas previously covered by Sharyland Water Supply Corporation Certificate of Convenience and Necessity relating to any buyout phases whereby the city has entered into agreements with Sharyland Water Supply Corporation for buyout of their certified area. 
(3)  Standard water rate schedule outside the city. 
(4)  Reclaimed water rate schedule 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-82. - Standard water rate schedule within the city. 
(a)  Except as provided by subsection (b) hereof, the rate to be charged for water furnished and consumed by single-family residence, multifamily, commercial and industrial customers is as follows: 
(1)  Minimum monthly base fee charges shall be made, and bills rendered at $9.95 per month, regardless of meter size. 
(2)  Commodity charges: 
Residential: $1.45 per 1,000 gallons for the first 7,999 gallons; $1.75 for the next 8,000 to 12,999 gallons; $1.95 for 13,000 to 17,999 gallons, and $2.05 per 1,000 gallons thereafter. 
Multifamily: $1.45 per 1,000 gallons for all usage under last fiscal year's average monthly usage, and $1.95 per 1,000 gallons for all usage above last fiscal year's average monthly usage. 
Commercial: $1.45 per 1,000 gallons for all usage under last fiscal year's average monthly usage, and $1.95 per 1,000 gallons for all usage above last fiscal year's average monthly usage. 
Industrial: $1.45 per 1,000 gallons for all usage under last fiscal year's average monthly usage, and $1.95 per 1,000 gallons for all usage above last fiscal year's average monthly usage. 
Irrigation/pool services: $1.95 per 1,000 gallons. 
(3)  Traveling meters: 
Minimum monthly base fee charges shall be made, and bills rendered at $50.00 per month, regardless of meter size. Commodity charges shall be made as indicated in item (2) above. The traveling meter shall be retrieved by city after three months of zero consumption usage. 
(b)  Provide that until the buyout cost is recovered and 30 days after approved by the utility board, the monthly charges shall be made, and bills rendered accordingly on all accounts located or to be located on or after May 1, 1995, in the areas covered by Sharyland Water Supply Corporation's Certificate of Convenience and Necessity buyout Phase #2, #3, #4, #5A, and #6 as shown in the agreements between the McAllen Public Utility Board and Sharyland Water Supply Corporation covering the same, as follows: 
(1)  Residential connection ( 5/8 ? or ¾? meter): 
0 to 3,000 gallons .....$9.00 
(2)  Commercial connection ( 5/8 ? or ¾? meter): 
0 to 3,000 gallons .....15.00 
(3)  Meters larger than 5/8 ? or ¾?: 
1? meter, 0 to 3,000 gallons .....16.00 
2? meter, 0 to 3,000 gallons .....24.00 
3? meter, 0 to 3,000 gallons .....29.00 
4? meter, 0 to 3,000 gallons .....34.00 
6? meter, 0 to 3,000 gallons .....39.00 
(4)  Charge per 1,000 gallons, after the first 3,000 gallons of usage, for both residential and commercial connections: 
Per Thousand Gallons 
3,000 to 20,000 gallons .....$1.50 
20,001 to 100,000 gallons .....1.60 
100,001 to 150,000 gallons .....1.75 
All over 150,000 gallons .....2.00 
(c)  The penalties and/or remedies provided in division 2 of this article apply to any violation of the provisions of this section. Such penalties or remedies are not exclusive and it is expressly provided that any remedies available by law to the city to enforce the provisions of this section are also applicable to violations of the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17; Ord. No. 2017-51, § I, 9-25-17; Ord. No. 2019-57, § I, 9-23-19)  
Sec. 106-83. - Standard water rate schedule outside the city. 
All customers connected to and using water from the public utility system outside the city limits shall be charged on the schedule of rates set forth in section 106-82 plus an additional charge of 50 percent of the total water bill. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-84. - Reclaimed water rates. 
(a)  Reclaimed water shall mean domestic or municipal wastewater which has been treated to a quality suitable for a beneficial use. 
(b)  All customers connected to and using reclaimed water from the public utility system shall be charged the same fees and costs, such as meter and deposit charges as customers using potable water except the rates for the reclaimed water shall be reduced by 20 percent of the rates applied to the most current domestic base potable water rate or the commodity rate is set at 80 percent of the lowest tiered potable water rate. 
(c)  Commercial and industrial large volume users of reclaimed water contracts and city properties such as public parks and golf courses are not subject to the rates applied in subsection (a) and will be set by the McAllen Public Utility Board on a case by case basis. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17; Ord. No. 2018-65, § I, 9-24-18)  
Sec. 106-85. - Deposit required. 
(a)  A security deposit shall be required for all water and reclaimed water customers in the amounts as approved by minute order, from time to time, by the board of commissioners and as recommended by the McAllen Public Utility Board. This deposit shall be required for all new accounts as provided for in this section, save and except for any existing customer of the water system who shall transfer an account from one location to another or who shall request additional account(s) to be established under such person's name; provided that such customer has not been in default for payment of the utility bills for the prior two years immediately preceding the transfer of or establishment of any new account. Any such customer paying any deposit as provided for in this section and who shall under the same account maintain such account without delinquency for a continuous two-year period from the date of deposit shall be entitled to a refund of such deposit. 
(b)  The security deposit should not only cover the water and reclaimed water account billing of such customers, but shall also be prorated among the sewer amounts due and outstanding and the garbage collection service amounts due and outstanding for any account relating to such security deposit. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-86. - Meter testing. 
Any customer of the water system or the reclaimed water system may have the meter serving such customer tested by the public utility department once per year without charge to the customer. Except as provided for in this section, any request for testing of meters at a shorter interval than one year shall be paid for by the customer requesting such test and the fee therefor shall be $25.00 per test. If any test required to be paid for by the customer results in a finding that such meter is defective to an extent that it creates a substantial disadvantage to the consumer, then the fee to be paid by the consumer shall be waived. The term "substantial disadvantage" as used in this section shall mean that the water charge or reclaimed water charge calculated based on the original meter reading resulted in a 25 percent or greater overcharge to the customer. The one-year period for determining the duration for free meter reading shall commence for all existing customers on the effective date of the ordinance adopting this section and for all future customers commencing on the date of installation of the meter. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)

Sec. 106-88. - Reserve for depreciation. 
(a)  There is hereby created a reserve for depreciation as a separate fund called the Reserve for Depreciation - Water, to be collected out of the amounts collected monthly as a result of the application of the water rates set out in this division, in an amount equal to one-twelfth of 35 percent of the amount contained in the City of McAllen Public Utilities, Water Fund annual budget for each succeeding fiscal year, as a reserve for depreciation, and such amount shall be set aside in Reserve for Depreciation - Water Fund. Such fund is an account (line item) in the budget for the city water system. All expenditures from the reserve for depreciation shall be for replacement items only and either be budgeted or approved by the Board of Trustees of the McAllen Public Utilities. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained herein, the city commission may, upon recommendation by the public utility board, from time to time, authorize, by ordinance, expenditures from the Depreciation Fund for other than replacement items. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17; Ord. No. 2018-65, § I, 9-24-18)  
Secs. 106-89—106-101. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - WELLS 
 
Sec. 106-102. - Temporary permit to drill or develop; bond. 
No water well shall be drilled or developed within the city unless the driller or developer first secures a temporary permit from the city secretary for such purpose. All applications for such permit shall be accompanied by a bond in the amount of $1,000.00, payable to the city, executed by the applicant and a corporate surety authorized to do business in the state and conditioned that the applicant will comply with all provisions of this division. The application to drill shall describe the lot or land upon which the well is proposed to be drilled and such permit shall not be valid beyond 30 days after its issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-103. - Test hole required; information to be given city. 
The driller or developer of a water well shall be required to drill a test hole and completely log each stratum and soil formation encountered in the process of drilling such test hole, and furnish a copy of an electric log and soil formation of the proposed well to the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-104. - Permit for completion; right of city to designate formations to be developed; inspection fee. 
(a)  If the electric log and soil formation indicate favorable conditions for completion of a water well, based upon geological analysis of such soil formation and electric log, the city will issue a final permit for well completion. The city reserves the right to designate which formations are to be developed and which formations are to be sealed off and not developed, a condition to be determined before final issuance of the permit. 
(b)  An inspection fee of $25.00 shall be charged for each final permit granted under this section. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-105. - Backfilling abandoned test hole. 
In the event of abandonment of a test hole for a water well, the driller or developer shall completely backfill such test hole with clay materials free of sand or gravel. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Secs. 106-106—106-116. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - WATER CONSERVATION AND DROUGHT CONTINGENCY PLAN 
 
Sec. 106-117. - Introduction. 
McAllen Public Utility (MPU) provides the public with its water, reclaimed water and sewer services within the city limits. The water and wastewater system is owned and operated by the City of McAllen in Hidalgo County, Texas, and is governed by the McAllen Public Utility Board of Trustees. The amount of water the city water system can store, treat divert, and distribute to customers is limited. MPU wants to avoid waste or unreasonable use of water, which could lead to possible drought and emergency conservation strategies. With an expected population increase over the next 50 years that well exceeds the national average; it is imperative that we maximize efficient water use practices and minimize both direct and indirect water waste. While short-term water shortages and water supply emergencies are often unpreventable, response measures can be determined and implemented in advance to avoid, minimize, or mitigate the risks and impacts of drought-related water shortages and other emergencies. 
The purpose of this plan is to establish a water conservation and drought contingency plan for the city in accordance with Texas Administrative Code Title 30, Chapter 288. The basic goal of the water conservation and drought contingency plan is to ensure an uninterrupted supply of water in an amount sufficient to satisfy essential human needs. The water conservation plan develops a conservation strategy for reducing the volume of water withdrawn from a water supply source, for reducing the loss or waste of water, for increasing the recycling and reclaimed of water, and for preventing the pollution of water. The drought contingency plan is a strategy for temporary supply management and demand management responses to temporary and potentially recurring water supply shortages and other water supply emergencies. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-118. - Utility profile. 
(a)  Demographics. MPU provides water supply and wastewater services within the city limits. The service area is 48.7 square miles. The 2010 U.S. Census data for the population of the city of McAllen is 129,877. The current estimated dynamic population in the winter, when long-term visitor counts are higher, is 138,398; and in the summer, the estimate is 132,338. This figure includes people who live in the city permanently, as well as winter visitors and people who commute here from Mexico. The McAllen city limits population has grown 2.16 percent annually over the past decade and is projected to continue to grow another three percent annually through 2016. 
(b)  Water supply. 
(1)  Raw water supply. The Rio Grande River is the sole source of water for citizens of the city, and MPU has water delivery contracts with four districts, as follows: 
Hidalgo County Irrigation 
District Number 2 	8,111 acre ft/year 
Hidalgo County Water Improvement District Number 3 	13,980 acre ft/year 
United Irrigation District 	11,250 acre ft/year 
Brownsville Irrigation District 	2,000 acre ft/year 
 
(2)  Water treatment system. The city has two water treatment plants: 
Southwest Water Treatment Plant: (rerated in 2010) 47.25 MGD 
Northwest Water Treatment Plant: (rerated in 2011) 11.25 MGD 
Total System Treatment Capacity: 58.5 MGD 
(3)  Water pumpage and storage. Current annual pumpage for 2011 was 109 billion gallons of water. MPU has various pumps located at the Southwest Water Treatment Plant to pump raw water from the raw water reservoir into the plant facilities for treatment. The plant also has high service pumps to pump water from the ground storage tanks into the distribution system. MPU relies on elevated storage and high service pumps for pressure maintenance. 
MPU has seven water towers with a total of 6.75 million gallons of elevated storage, and 11.9 million gallons of ground storage. All ground storage and elevated towers are monitored by a SCADA system. The system allows MPU to monitor flow data and record historical trends in the treatment and distribution system. 
MPU has a total of 713.6 miles of water lines, of which approximately 16 percent are 12 inches in diameter or larger. The MPU system has 7,375 water valves and 4,050 active fire hydrants. 
(4)  Water master plan. An updated water master plan was completed by Freese and Nichols, Inc. in July 2009, to evaluate the integrity of the existing water systems and to recommend a phased capital improvements plan to serve growth through 2025. The recommended improvements will serve as a basis for the design, construction and financing of facilities required to meet MPU's water service needs as a result of projected population growth. 
(c)  Water use characteristics. MPU supplies water for residential, commercial, industrial, and public use. The total per capita use for the city in 2011 is estimated at 172 gallons per capita per day (gpcd) 2. This is an average taken by dividing the total water treated by the population served. The residential gallons per capita per day are estimated at 108 gpcd. Residential gpcd is made by dividing total single-family and multi-family residential water sales by the population served. 
The city's industrial users accounted for 16 percent of total water use. The largest volume industrial user for 2011 was Magic Valley Fresh Frozen, which purchased approximately 84.4 MG of water, or 1.11 percent of total water usage. 
Large sized meters, or those 1.5 inches and larger in size, make up only 4.8 percent of the meters used but use 33.3 percent of the water. Conversely, small sized meters, or those one-inch and below, make up 95.1 percent of all meters, but account for less than 66.7 percent of metered sales. 
(d)  Unaccounted-for water. The city's unaccounted-for water is due to breaks, leaks, meter under- registration, processing, flushing mains, system loss, and un-metered fire hydrants. The amount of unaccounted-for water is determined by the difference between production and sales of water. The average amount of unaccounted-for water loss for the past three years was ten percent. The unaccounted-for loss of water for 2011 was ten percent. 
(e)  MPU operates two wastewater treatment plants. Both treatment plants are based upon extended aeration activated sludge system, with secondary effluent limitations. Treated effluent is discharged into floodways and eventually into the Arroyo Colorado and Laguna Madre Estuary. The average annual treated wastewater volume for 2009—2011 was 5100.8 million gallons. The average monthly amount of treated wastewater for that same period was 425.0 million gallons per month, or 14.2 MGD. The sanitary sewer infrastructure consists of 500 miles of sanitary sewer line, with 44 lift stations within the City of McAllen and ten lift stations within the City of Alton. 
The South Wastewater Treatment Plant is a 10 MGD design flow with 16.2 MGD peak flow capabilities. It is currently 61 percent hydraulically loaded with effluent limitations of 10 mg/l of carbonaceous biochemical oxygen demand; 15 mg/l of total suspended solids; 2 mg/l of ammonia nitrogen and E. coli, CFU or MPN/100 ml 126. 
The North Wastewater Treatment Plant is an 11.25 MGD design flow with 28.125 MGD peak flow capability. The permit limitations include 10 mg/l of biochemical oxygen demand, and 15 mg/l of total suspended solids, 3 mg/l of ammonia nitrogen and 35 mg/l Enterococci bacteria. 
(f)  Wastewater master plan. An updated wastewater master plan was completed by Freese and Nichols, Inc. in July 2009 to evaluate the integrity of the existing wastewater systems and to recommend a phased capital improvements plan to serve growth through 2025. The recommended improvements will serve as a basis for the design, construction and financing of facilities required to meet MPU's wastewater service needs as a result of projected population growth. 
The following is a description of the public utility system.

Sec. 106-119. - Water conservation goals. 
Based on the data found in the utility profile and on careful evaluation of the city's water consumption and practices, MPU has set the following goals to be achieved through the adoption of this water conservation plan: 
(1)  To reduce daily municipal per capita water use to 168 gpcd by the year 2015 and to maintain the unaccounted-for water loss at ten to 12 percent by 2017. Also, to reduce daily municipal per capita water use to 160 gpcd by the year 2020 and to maintain the unaccounted-for water loss at eight to ten percent by 2022. At present, the gpcd ten-year average is 187 and the unaccounted-for water loss is at ten percent. 
(2)  To implement long term cost-effective recovery measures for major causes of unaccounted-for water related to metering. We have implemented a meter change out policy that requires all meters to be changed out after 12 years or 1.5 MG of total flow and an aggressive meter testing program to identify and deal with problem meters. A 2011 audit reflected that our program is working. 
(3)  To increase both public and employee awareness regarding water conservation and water related issues. This will especially be encouraged during summer months when water consumption increases significantly. 
(4)  To investigate the potential for wastewater effluent reclaimed, and to use reclaimed water when practical. 
(5)  To promote xeriscape landscape use like low-water using shrubs and plants, patios, rocks, decks, and walkways in order to reduce the amount of high water consuming landscape area. Businesses as well as residential users will be encouraged to participate. 
(6)  To promote more efficient irrigation techniques for agriculture, industry, and private use through rebates, retrofit, and education. 
(7)  A full time water education specialist is on staff. This specialist will be developing conservation programs and educational offerings to both public and school children audiences to enhance understanding of water utility systems as well as promote water conservation and prevention of pollution of water resources. 
(8)  Wholesale customers will be required to implement and adhere to a water conservation and drought contingency plan. Currently, no wholesale contracts exist. 
(9)  MPU will strive to attain a two percent reduction goal during water conservation stages. 
(Ord. No. 2017-27, § I, 5-8-17)  
Sec. 106-120. - Water conservation strategies. 
(a)  Public education. Water conservation is promoted in the city through the following: 
(1)  Public service announcements have been and will continue to be made regarding water conservation inside and outside the home, as well as in the workplace. For example, tips on efficient lawn watering, repairing leaks in the home, and installing low-flow showerheads and faucet aerators have been publicized on local radio stations, in newspapers, and on television stations. Educational videos and service announcements are and will continue to be shown periodically on the McAllen Cable Network. 
(2)  New customers are given information such as brochures about water conservation when they open a new account with the city. Informative brochures as well as flyers are also on display at City Hall where many customers come in to pay their water bill or take care of business with the utility department and at other city offices. 
(3)  Employee education will also be furthered in the utility by periodic presentations regarding water use and conservation. Posters and additional brochures will also be distributed in City Hall for employee use. City employees who do not work at City Hall will also be sent materials such as pamphlets and brochures to be displayed and read at their facilities. 
Customer Service Week is celebrated within all city departments every October. During this time, the utility has a booth at City Hall to inform citizens on water conservation efforts and to improve public perception and awareness of the utility's conservation efforts. 
MPU's water education specialist will make every effort to work with other city departments, McAllen-area schools, the International Museum of Art and Science (IMAS), and other community groups to promote water conservation education by participating in special public events, educational offerings, and other activities. Examples include co-sponsoring a poster contest, having a booth at festivals or fairs, or hosting community groups for water plant tours. 
(b)  Recycling and reclaimed. MPU currently has a recycle or reclaimed program for water via irrigation of treated wastewater effluent on the city's golf course. Additionally, MPU has contracts to sell Calpine and Duke Energy 5 MGD and 4.8 MGD, respectively, of treated wastewater effluent for reclaimed. MPU began constructing a reclaimed line in 2011 that will eventually supply the Convention Center District and the city's nearby Westside Park with treated wastewater effluent for irrigation and landscape feature use such as decorative water fountains and other water features. After recent developments have requested to purchase reclaimed water from the City for irrigation, the MPU has amended its ordinance to allow for reclaimed water to be used for residential and institutional irrigation purposes. 
(c)  Metering devices and universal metering. 
(1)  Metering devices. New meters, two inches and smaller in size, are bought according to the latest revision of "AWWA New Meter Standard for Cold-Water Meters" in order to specify all materials, design, manufacture, and testing of all meters. The manufacturer will guarantee that all new meters will test at 98.1 to 101 percent accurate at the maximum rate and 95 to 101 percent at the "low flow" rate as designed by AWWA Standards Manual M-6 on a meter size for size basis. This ensures accurate and precise measurement of water diverted. 
Older meters that may be registering too high or low will be replaced as time permits in order to accurately account for water and lower any unaccounted-for water loss. 
(2)  Metering. MPU currently meters all water usage except that of fire hydrants and water loss due to leaks, breaks, processing, flushing of mains, and system loss. MPU, however, does keep track of water used by fire hydrants through the city fire department. 
MPU uses computers to maintain billing, to keep accurate records of water consumption, and to identify high and low water users. MPU will test all meters that appear to show unusually high or low water usage based on fluctuating meter data. Water distribution tests meters based on an "as needed" basis when customers complain or a problem arises. 
The MPU water distribution department is responsible for maintaining all 53,200 connections. Meter readers use a portable meter tester and/or a read-a-flow recorder to test meters in the field. When meters cannot be read in the field, they are taken into a meter shop to be assessed. Priority is always given to water leaks with all other tasks including service calls, maintenance calls, and other water distribution projects. 
Meter management study. In September 2011, JBS Associates, Inc. prepared a report of meter management study for the utility. The study included an analysis of production and metered sales from January 2009 to June 2011, and of individually metered water consumption accounts from February 2008 to January 2011. The report made recommendations that are currently being utilized, such as the recommendation to implement quarterly testing of meter accuracy in the case of zero-consumption or low-use accounts. 
(d)  Water distribution audit and leak survey. In November 1997, JBS Associates, Inc. completed a water distribution audit and leak survey. The audit was conducted to determine causes for unaccounted-for water and develop recommendations for unaccounted-for water recovery in a cost-effective manner. This audit and leak survey is conducted every five years at a minimum. 
A continuous leak detection and repair program is carried out by MPU. Meter readers also check for leaks while reading meters and performing regular maintenance. For the year 2006-2007, a full-scale leak detection project was implemented. 
(e)  Plumbing codes and retrofit program. The city does have plumbing codes pursuant to the 2006 standard plumbing code issued from the International Code Council. Additionally, the 72 nd Texas Legislature passed legislation which requires plumbing fixtures sold in the state after January 1, 1992 to meet strict standards that incorporate efficient water use and conservation in new structures. This law subsequently effects plumbing fixtures sold in the city and will help to eliminate inefficient plumbing fixtures. 
MPU does encourage businesses and homeowners to replace older water fixtures like low-flow showerheads, faucet aerators, and toilet dams, purchased before January 1, 1992, with the newer water efficient replacements. MPU will also advocate the use of low demand water appliances instead of older, high use ones in homes and businesses. 
(f)  Water conservation landscaping. When practical, MPU will advocate the use of drip irrigation for the watering of landscapes for commercial establishments. Also, the use of ornamental fountains will be discouraged except when they recycle and use minimal quantities of water. 
MPU will continue to work with the city parks and recreation department in order to eliminate any wasteful water use. The watering of parks for example will be evaluated and done according to efficient water conserving methods. Municipal pools will also be evaluated for efficient water use. 
Local landscape architects and local nurseries will be asked and encouraged to utilize efficient irrigation systems and native low water using plants and grasses. Xeriscape gardening and landscaping techniques will also be asked to be promoted. 
Licensed irrigation contractors will be asked to use drip irrigation systems, where possible, and to use water conserving irrigation systems like sprinklers which produce large drips instead of a fine mist and a sprinkler layout which accommodates prevailing wind patterns. 
(g)  Conservation oriented water rate structure. The city has established three schedules of rates to be charged for the consumption of water supplied through the city water system, as follows: 
(1)  Standard water rate schedule within the city for city customers under the city's certificate of convenience and necessity. 
(2)  Standard water rate schedule for areas previously covered by Sharyland Water Supply Corporation certificate of convenience and necessity relating to any buyout phases whereby the city has entered into agreements with Sharyland Water Supply Corporation for buyout of their certified area. 
(3)  Standard water rate schedule outside the city. The standard rate to be charged for water furnished and consumed by single-family residence, multi-family, commercial, and industrial customers within the city is as follows: 
a.  Base meter charge: $4.00 per meter 
b.  Commodity charge: Approved September 23, 2008. 
Residential: $1.30 per 1,000 gallons for the first 12,999 gallons and $1.60 for 13,000 to 17,999 and $1.80 per 1,000 gallons thereafter. 
Multi-family: $1.30 per 1,000 gallons for all usage under last fiscal year's average monthly usage, and $1.80 per 1,000 gallons for all usage above last fiscal year's average monthly usage. 
Commercial: $1.30 per 1,000 gallons for all usage under last fiscal year's average monthly usage, and $1.80 per 1,000 gallons for all usage above last fiscal year's average monthly usage. 
Industrial: $1.30 per 1,000 gallons for all usage under last fiscal year's average monthly usage, and $1.80 per 1,000 gallons for all usage above last fiscal year's average monthly usage. 
Irrigation/pool services: $1.80 per 1,000 gallons.
